Throughout most of the 1990s headed sales at several regional metallurgical plants. In 1998 became sales manager at Sinarsky Pipe Works and soon took control of the company. Two years later Sinarsky Works became part of the pipe conglomerate TMK, assembled by MDM Group founders Sergei Popov and Andrei Melnichenko. Pumpyansky became chief executive and acquired a 35% stake in the company, which controlled 3 major pipe plants and later acquired a fourth despite fierce competition from Alfa Group. In October 2006 bought out Melnichenko and Popov and the next month listed TMK on the London Stock Exchange, raising $1 billion.

name: Billionaires
bio: Jet-setting beer magnate turned over operations of his Bavaria brewery to SABMiller in 2005. Now owns significant SABMiller stake. Since 2002 has slashed losses at Valores Bavaria, a holding company with interests in telecom, banks and a recently acquired 70% of Dasigno, an Internet-services company. Keeps homes in New York City, Paris and Baru, his private island off the Caribbean coast of Colombia. Once served as Colombia's ambassador to China.

name: Billionaires
bio: In 1982 graduated from the Moscow Institute of Physics & Technology; then worked as the head of a research lab before Soviet Union collapsed. In 1992 established a precursor to EvrazHolding; made a fortune exporting metals and coal from the Urals and Siberia. After Russia’s financial crisis in 1998, bought up steel companies and coal mines on the cheap, also purchased a big stake in Russia’s electric monopoly RAO UES. In 2006 Russia’s richest man, Roman Abramovich, became Abramov’s partner in Evraz.

name: Billionaires
bio: Father, Rupert Sr., founded early mutual fund shop Franklin Distributors 1947. With half-brother, Rupert, took over 1969, expanded into Franklin Resources, adding Templeton Funds 1992, Fiduciary Trust 2001. Also bought Heine Securities from value investor Michael Price (see) for $610 million in 1996. Charles: Yale grad, former Army lieutenant; son Gregory is president and CEO. Operates in 29 countries, offers more than 200 investment products. Launched BRIC (Brazil, Russia, India, China) fund, first in the U.S.

name: Billionaires
bio: With younger sister ,Alicia, (see) inherited Fomento de Construcciones y Contratas from late father. The two ran the company jointly from 1989 to 1997; Esther then bought out her sister for $800 million. Now owns 38% of $9 billion (sales) group; sits on its supervisory board. A member of Spanish nobility herself, she is married to Fernando Falcó, Marqués de Cubas, scion of an old Spanish family. Apparently loves ballet and classical music.

name: Billionaires
bio: Big-asset timber giant Empresas CMPC saw pulp prices recover in early 2006, driving up revenue. Matte’s net worth is growing along with it. His conglomerate holds 1.7 million acres of pine and eucalyptus in Chile and Argentina. University of Chicago-educated Matte also betting on Chile’s increasing its share of international trade by expanding his massive port complex in Lirquen, Chile. Invests in telecom and financial services, too.

name: Billionaires
bio: Low-profile construction magnate is single-largest shareholder in Tata Sons, holding company of $22 billion (sales) Tata group. Its Tata Consultancy Services is India's largest software exporter; its Tata Steel recently won $12 billion bid to acquire Corus group, Europe's second-largest steel producer. Stepped down from Tata Sons board; younger son Cyrus took spot

name: Billionaires
bio: Third son of Texas wildcatter Perry Bass (d. 2006) studied at Yale, Stanford Business School. Struck out on own after Dad passed family oil business to brother Sid (see). Became active investor. Today his Oak Hill Partnerships manages $20 billion. Early investments included the St. Petersburg Times, Continental Broadcasting. Sold New York’s Plaza Hotel to Donald Trump (see) for big profit 1994. Led $700 million leveraged buyout of Duane Reade drugstore chain 2003. Also owns stake in private jetmaker Aerion; company developing supersonic business planes.

name: Billionaires
bio: Mayor Mike is New York City’s guiding political force; dropped $85 million in 2005 mayoral election, 9 times what opponent Fernando Ferrer spent. Bloomberg LP thriving on strong demand for data terminals at hedge funds. Revenue now exceed $4 billion. News service also growing; hiring new reporters. Donated $150 million to charity in past year; plans to sell company once out of office and give away entire fortune.

name: Billionaires
bio: Made his fortune in mundane business of putting together PCs, MP3 players and cell phones. In 1974 founded Hon Hai Precision, now the world's largest contract manufacturer. Press-shy Gou has been on defensive lately: filed lawsuit, later dropped, against journalists saying he ran sweatshops; accused another journalist of blackmail. None of this put a dent in fortune. Shares of Hon Hai subsidiary Innolux have doubled since listing late last year. Just announced new manufacturing complex in Vietnam. Funding a film studio and donating his own money to rural development in mainland China where his parents lived before they fled the PRC army in 1949 and settled in Taiwan. Recent widower is now followed around by local paparazzi eager to photograph him with beautiful women.

name: Billionaires
bio: Heads copper producer Kazakhmys, which went public on the London Stock Exchange in 2005. Company went through management shake-up this fall when Chief Executive Yong Keu Cha stepped aside; Chairman Kim bought majority of Cha’s shares to keep control; new chief installed in March. Recently bought 25% stake in another Kazakh commodity firm, Eurasian Natural Resources, owned by billionaires Alijan Ibragimov, Patokh Chodiev and Alexander Machkevich (see all) after Kazakh government reportedly demanded changes in management structure; that company is expected to list in London later this year.

name: Billionaires
bio: Inherited majority stake in media empire Publishing & Broadcasting (PBL) after his father died in December 2005. Less than a year later made waves when—-expecting changes in Australia’s media ownership laws—-he spun off PBL media assets, including the Nine TV network and ACP Magazines, into PBL Media, a joint venture with private equity firm CVC Asia Pacific. In the process company received $3.7 billion. Using some of the proceeds to up its bet on gaming. PBL partnered with Lawrence Ho, son of Hong Kong billionaire Stanley Ho, in a Macau casino joint venture, Melco PBL Entertainment. The joint venture recently raised $1.2 billion in an initial public offering on Nasdaq. Packer was also reportedly part of a group of Australian investors trying to buy British luxury-car maker Aston Martin.

name: Billionaires
bio: Fourth generation of Swiss-German industrial fortune heads Holcim, the world's second-largest supplier of cement and concrete. Holds an engineering degree from the Swiss Federal Institute of Technology and a Ph.D. in business administration from Tufts University. Honorary Consul-General of the Republic of Cyprus in Switzerland. His personal wine holdings include the Cuvaison and Chapel Hill labels and the revamped Weingut Schmidheiny, a vineyard in Balgach, Switzerland, where he was born.

name: Billionaires
bio: The co-owner of steel and iron-ore factories like Oskol, Lebedinsky and Mikhailovsky loves to say that the shares he owns in metals companies are his “first love.” Last year, although he had never before been involved in the media business, Usmanov bought Kommersant newspaper from the disgraced former oligarch Boris Berezovsky, apparently encouraged to do so by the Russian government.

name: Billionaires
bio: Corporate lawyer joined father’s Tana Oil & Gas 1980; merged production properties with Texaco 1989 for $476 million stock and cash. Sold Gulf of Mexico operations to Unocal for $110 million 1999. Diversifying ever since: Omni hotels, Gold’s Gym, Mexican dollar-store chain Waldo’s. Still invested in oil; Tana aggressively drilling wells in Gulf of Mexico.

name: Billionaires
bio: Earned his first rubles in late 1980s helping foreign tourists find rooms in Moscow hotels. In 1990 worked as a consultant for Italian confectionary Ferrero Rocher; then started selling Italian vermouth, winning an exclusive contract with Martini & Rossi. In 1998 created the first ever upmarket brand of Russian vodka, Russian Standard. In 1999 with help of McKinsey & Co. set up Russian Standard Bank, pioneering consumer credit market and in 3 years became the market leader. Russian Standard reps are in almost every major home appliance store in Moscow. With an estimated $540 million net profit in 2006, this moneymaker now fully belongs to its founder: In 2006 Tariko bought 6.42% shares from his only partner, the IFC (the World Bank’s financial branch). Also bought URL Vodka.com for $3 million.

name: Billionaires
bio: A former military man who turned out to be a financial whiz. In the 1990s helped privatize Lukoil, which was formed out of the best Russian oil properties; is now Lukoil Chief Vagit Alekperov’s right-hand man. As vice president, responsible for strategic development and external relations. “My wealth is a virtual thing; 99% of my money consists of Lukoil shares,” Fedun has said. An avid soccer fan: when his club, Spartak of Moscow, came in second in the Russian championship, Fedun awarded his players generously; his goalkeeper got a Hummer H2.

name: Billionaires
bio: Former exec at real estate syndicate Property Research started storage business 1972 after stopping at warehouse on road trip and learning it was full. Lost potential customers with confusing signs: people thought “Private Storage” meant closed to the general public. New name brought them in droves. Today Public Storage is the nation’s largest self-storage company, with over 2,000 facilities around the world. Last year bought rival Shurgard for $5.5 billion in hostile takeover; Seattle storage outfit has a window on the coveted European market. Supports cancer causes, particularly childhood leukemia. Donated $200 million to Parker Hughes Cancer Center in St. Paul, Minn., named for late son.

name: Billionaires
bio: Scion of a distinguished family of Iraqi Jews who settled and made its fortune in Asia. Kadoorie and family, including brother-in-law Ronald J. McAulay (see), own big stakes in Hongkong & Shanghai Hotels, which operates the famous Peninsula Hotel in Hong Kong, and CLP Holdings, one of Hong Kong’s power supply companies, now under fire amid reports of worsening air pollution in the city. Was knighted in the U.K. for his extensive charitable and philanthropic activities.

name: Billionaires
bio: Opened first hardware store 1972 after building barns to pay college tuition. Expanded, undercut competition pennies at a time. Today Midwest’s Menards rivals Home Depot, Lowe’s, with 210 stores, 35,000 employees. Paid $216 million in taxes in 2002; IRS asked for $13.3 million more. Road warrior has sponsored Team Menard in the Indy 500 for decades.

name: Billionaires
bio: Stanford grad opened markets to the masses with eponymous discount stock brokerage firm 1971. Accounts skyrocketed during Internet boom, then plummeted when bubble burst. Charles abandoned CEO post 2003; resumed a year later when profits sagged. In 2005 company switched listing from New York Stock Exchange to Nasdaq; believes member companies are more “forward-thinking.” Dyslexic; started the Charles & Helen Schwab Foundation for children with learning disabilities and ADHD.

name: Billionaires
bio: Heads diversified empire that includes Mexico’s biggest silver mine, owned by his Industrias Peñoles; upscale department store El Palacio de Hierro; major insurance company. Also sits on the board of Femsa, the largest soft drink and beer company in Latin America.

name: Billionaires
bio: Founded the JCDecaux outdoor advertising company in 1964. Started out putting ads on “street furniture” such as public toilets and bus shelters. Since then has expanded advertising to airports, malls, subways and billboards. Remains chairman of $2.3 billion (sales) JCDecaux and still oversees strategy. Sons Jean-François and Jean-Charles are cochief executives. Last May, the company won an advertising contract with British Airport Authority to sell ad space in all seven of its U.K. airports. Company touts its “greenness”, placing recycling bins for batteries, glass or other waste near its street furniture.

name: Billionaires
bio: With older sister Esther (see) inherited Fomento de Construcciones y Contratas from late father. The sisters ran the company jointly from 1989 to 1997; sold her share to Esther in 1997 for $800 million. Has invested proceeds in companies such as Acerinox, Inmocaral and Banco Sabadel; hotels in Spain, Italy and Portugal; and U.S. real estate. Her financial adviser is Oscar Fanjul, former chief executive of oil and gas company Repsol, who sits on boards of such companies as the London Stock Exchange  and The Marsh & McLennan Companies. Together they are now creating one of Spain's first hedge funds and hoping to attract outside investors. Through her charitable foundation, sends Spanish fellows to study child psychiatry in England and the U.S. (Columbia, NYU, Pittsburgh). Rumored to be romantically involved with the Duque de Huescar, heir to the Spanish aristocratic house of Alba.

name: Billionaires
bio: Bronx-born son of Russian immigrants worked day jobs at department stores, clerked at Brooks Brothers. Left business school 1967 to design ties for Beau Brummel; launched Polo later that year with $50,000 loan. Built reputation “selling the American Dream.” Sold 28% of company to Goldman Sachs for $138 million 1994; took public 1997. Polo empire runs gamut with men’s and women’s clothing, luggage, house paint, furniture, fragrances. Now expanding into “rebel preppy” with youth-oriented line, Rugby. Car enthusiast owns Colorado ranch, Jamaican island retreat.

name: Billionaires
bio: These are extraordinary times for De Beers, the diamond empire Oppenheimer chairs. In the last few years the firm has sold off a piece of its South African operations, welcomed its first black executive and settled a long-standing price-fixing class suit that prevented it from opening offices in the U.S. The changes continue. In November Nicky sold off a third of his family’s interest in global mining giant Anglo American, founded in 1917 by grandfather Ernest, to Chinese billionaire Larry Yung. The nearly $500 million in proceeds will go toward nonmining-related investments in Africa. On behalf of De Beers, which is experiencing increasing difficulty producing rough diamonds, Oppenheimer courted Russian President Vladimir Putin in September. Two months later De Beers and Alrosa, Russia&#39s state-owned diamond firm, signed a joint prospecting deal.

name: Billionaires
bio: Founding patriarch of the Orascom conglomerate, Sawiris was forced to rebuild his construction company from scratch after it was nationalized by the government in the 1960s. Now serves as chairman of Orascom Construction. His 3 sons (see) run construction, telecommunications and tourism divisions. His foundation sponsors scholarships for Egyptian students to attend universities in the U.S. and Europe.

name: Billionaires
bio: Heated bidding war for Zell&#39s Equity Office Properties finally over after Stephen Schwarzman&#39s (see) Blackstone Group beat out Steven Roth&#39s (see) Vornado with $39 billion all-cash offer last month. Plowing proceeds into his residential, retirement REITs; mulling bid for Tribune Corp. Parents escaped Poland weeks before Nazi invasion; Sam born in Chicago 4 months after family’s arrival in America. Built real estate empire with frat brother Robert Lurie (d. 1990); bought up cheap real estate throughout U.S. from distressed owners, kept buying when values recovered and boomed. Now focused on international development: Equity International Properties’ first fund scored with Mexican homebuilder Homex; second fund targeting Brazil.

name: Billionaires
bio: Investment banker turned beer baron. With former banking partners and fellow billionaires Marcel Telles and Carlos Alberto Sicupira (see both), shares control of global powerhouse brewer InBev of Belgium—a company born of 2004 merger of AmBev of Brazil and Interbrew of Belgium. The Lemann-Telles-Sicupira trio also controls Brazilian retailer Lojas Americanas. Lemann’s fortune was born of success at investment bank Banco Garantia, which he founded 1971 and sold to Credit Suisse First Boston 1998 for $675 million.

name: Billionaires
bio: Hollywood’s richest man sorted mail at famed William Morris Agency after forging university stationery to supply credentials. Founded Asylum Records 1970 (Eagles, Joni Mitchell), then Geffen Records (Aerosmith, Guns N’ Roses). Sold to MCA in 1990 for stock; reaped $710 million when MCA was sold to Matsushita a year later. Founded entertainment boutique DreamWorks with partners Jeffrey Katzenberg, Steven Spielberg (see) 1995. Big hits included Shrek, Gladiator. Spun animation unit public 2004. Last February sold live-action movie studio to Paramount for $1.5 billion; personally netted $175 million. Big holiday hit with Dreamgirls; says he&#39s now done with Hollywood. Bidding against LA rival billionaires Eli Broad and Ronald Burkle (see both) for the Tribune-owned Los Angeles Times. Recently waring with Hillary Clinton over comments he made to New York Times columnists after hosting a fundraiser for presidential candidate Barack Obama.

name: Billionaires
bio: Began building his empire in 1990 when, with partner Vitaly Malkin, set up Rossiysky Kredit Bank. The shares have now been divided, with Ivanishvili getting two-thirds and Malkin one-third. The two share other assets with the same stockholding ratio, but Ivanishvili now focuses on managing his personal portfolio of Russian securities.

name: Billionaires
bio: Once Colombia’s top builder, Sarmiento parlayed his construction fortune into a sprawling financial services empire. His Grupo Aval boasts outfits in commercial lending, retail banking and insurance. Last year borrowed $200 million from Citigroup to buy a controlling stake in Megabanco from Colombian government. Grooming son Luis Carlos Jr. to take over holdings. Recharges in the Bahamas.

name: Billionaires
bio: Chairman and chief executive of United Overseas Bank, the largest in Singapore. A banker for more than 40 years, has been with the company since 1974 and says he's not retiring anytime soon. Was twice named Businessman of the Year at the Singapore Business Awards and recently received lifetime achievement award from peers at Ernst & Young and Credit Suisse. Plays tennis 3 times a week with friends he has known for more than 50 years.

name: Billionaires
bio: Father, Rupert Sr., founded early mutual fund shop Franklin Distributors 1947. With half-brother, Charles, took over 1969, expanded into Franklin Resources, adding Templeton Funds 1992, Fiduciary Trust 2001. Also bought Heine Securities from value investor Michael Price (see) for $610 million in 1996. Rupert: Washington & Lee grad, former Marine; serves as vice chairman. Operates in 29 countries, offers more than 200 investment products. Launched BRIC (Brazil, Russia, India, China) fund, first in the U.S.

name: Billionaires
bio: Deli-owner-turned-shopping-mall-Midas oversees a $44 billion (assets) portfolio of 121 malls in Australia, New Zealand, the U.K. and U.S. Remains Westfield’s executive chairman. Three sons also involved in business: David is Westfield deputy chairman (and oversees family investments); Peter, who heads up U.S. operations, and Steven are group managing directors. As chairman of the Football Federation Australia, Lowy turned around Australia&#39s languishing soccer league.

name: Billionaires
bio: Son of a respected Soviet physicist, studied physics at prestigious Moscow State University. Dropped out in 1991 and with some schoolmates sold computers and established a chain of currency-exchange booths; in 1993 founded MDM Bank, which would later handle the accounts of oil tycoon Roman Abramovich and other businessmen. In 1998 teamed up with metals trader Sergei Popov and two years later they began accumulating an industrial empire. In October 2006 sold their stake in pipe producer TMK to fellow billionaire Dmitry Pumpyansky and in December began dividing up their other businesses. Melnichenko unloaded his stake in MDM and acquired Popov&#39s holding in Eurochem, the largest producer of mineral fertilizers in Russia. They continue to jointly control SUEK, one of Russia’s biggest coal producers.

name: Billionaires
bio: A native of Yekaterinburg, studied to become an electrical engineer but left to go into business. Through the 1990s made his way through the murky world of metals and oil trading in the Urals and Siberia, selling pipes and copper cable. As a client of MDM Bank, got to know the bank&#39s young owner, Andrei Melnichenko (see). After the collapse of the ruble in 1998, convinced Melnichenko to buy Russian steel mills, chemical companies and coal mines on the cheap. The partners established 3 industrial giants: Russia’s largest pipe exporter (TMK), the largest mineral-fertilizer producer in Russia (Eurochem) and SUEK, the country’s largest independent coal producer. But in October 2006 TMK head Dmitry Pumpyansky bought them out, and in December Melnichenko and Popov began dividing up the rest of the business. Melnichenko unloaded his stake in MDM and acquired Popov&#39s stake in Eurochem (see Melnichenko). They continue to jointly control SUEK.

name: Billionaires
bio: Controlling shareholder of TV Azteca, one of Mexico’s two main broadcasters, made fortune in television, retail and cellular services. Gained notoriety in 2005, when the U.S. Securities & Exchange Commission brought a lawsuit against him, alleging that he concealed a deal between a TV Azteca subsidiary and another company he secretly owned—the first lawsuit brought against a foreign company under Sarbanes-Oxley. In September Salinas agreed to pay $7.5 million to settle the accusations but neither admitted nor denied wrongdoing.

name: Billionaires
bio: Well-known designer dressed TomKat for their Italian nuptials last year. Best known for his apparel, Armani now makes perfume, baby clothes, home decor and $10,000 Prive Borgo watches. Also getting into the hotel business with Dubai builder Emaar Properties: Emaar puts up the money, Armani licenses his name. First hotel to open in Milan in 2008; 2 more under construction in Burj Dubai and Marrakech. Expanding A/X clothing stores in China via a joint-venture partnership; also plans new stores in Japan and Central and South America. Spent 2 years in medical school at the University of Bologna before dropping out in 1957 to take a job as a department store buyer. Goes to the gym for at least an hour a day.

name: Billionaires
bio: Owns some 19% of the world's third-largest retailer Metro AG, the group he founded 1964. Metro bought Wal-Mart's underperforming chain of stores in Germany last summer. Beisheim bought a huge plot of land in central Berlin from KarstadtQuelle in 1999 and built a 172,000-square-foot luxury development on it; ownership of the land is now being debated, as Jewish Wertheim family claims property was taken away from them during Nazi era and illegally sold to Beisheim by KarstadtQuelle. Beisheim also manages Beisheim Holding Schweiz AG, which invests in Internet and technology companies. A widower with no children, he divides his time between his homes in Switzerland, Paris and Rottach-Eggern in Germany.

name: Billionaires
bio: Brothers control 18.5% of the Bouygues Group, a diversified industrial group founded by their father in 1952 with interests in telecom, media and construction. Martin is chairman and chief executive. Olivier is deputy chief executive. Over the years the $34 billion (sales) group has helped build the University of Riyadh in Saudi Arabia; the English Channel Tunnel; the Hassan II mosque in Casablanca, Morocco; the Kwun Tong viaduct in Hong Kong; and the restructuring of a wing of the Louvre Museum in Paris.  The company donates to the Toulouse Midi-Pyrénées Association of guide dogs for the blind.

name: Billionaires
bio: Father, Henry (d. 1990), started out in finance, made $4 per week. Founded stone, sand and gravel firm Material Service with 2 brothers in 1919 after getting fired. Built into multimillion-dollar business; merged with General Dynamics 1959. Today Lester retains big stake of General Dynamics; also has stock in JPMorgan Chase, Alltel, Hilton Hotels. Cashed in shares of appliance maker Maytag following $2.7 billion buyout by Whirlpool 2005. Heads Chicago Council on Foreign Relations; championed expansion of O’Hare airport. Also vice chairman of Aspen Institute think tank. Sports fanatic owns pieces of pro baseball’s New York Yankees, basketball’s Chicago Bulls.

name: Billionaires
bio: Cofounder of SAS, world’s largest privately held software company. Sales: $1.7 billion. First met partner John Sall (see) at North Carolina State. Founded SAS 1976; company develops business intelligence programs and platforms. Goodnight: Supports education causes. Avid rock collector has more than 100 fossils, meteorites. Partners believe happy employees are more productive: workers enjoy on-site day care, 35-hour workweek, swimming pool, free M&Ms.

name: Billionaires
bio: The housing market may be cooling, but chrome and porcelain still turning into gold for third-generation chief of Kohler Co. Grandfather founded company 1873 to make hitching posts and cemetery ornaments for midwestern farmers. Today empire includes toilets, sinks, furniture, cabinets, engines, generators. Yale grad also breeds Morgan show horses: “A terrific animal. Beautiful and showy.”

name: Billionaires
bio: Edgy chairman of ESL Investments spent spare time in high school reading corporate reports, financial textbooks. Skull & Bones member at Yale; took summer job at Goldman Sachs. Protégé of Robert Rubin; got an early investment from Richard Rainwater (see). Founded ESL 1988, annual returns averaging 25% since. Spent several hundred million dollars buying distressed Kmart bonds in 2002; merged retail chain with Sears, Roebuck two years later. Company believed to have more than $15 billion under management. Other investments: AutoNation, AutoZone. Client roster includes fellow Forbes 400 members Michael Dell, David Geffen (see both).

name: Billionaires
bio: Brothers were born in Mumbai and raised in the U.K. Simon started out importing carpets and buying real estate; David in metals trading. Later joined together in Transworld, a metals trader that invested heavily in Russia and Kazakhstan. Brothers cashed out of the business and the region after fallout with partners. Fortune is now mostly in real estate. Also make opportunistic investments: in October, with partners Bank of Scotland and Sir Thomas Hunter (see), acquired builder McCarthy & Stone for $2.2 billion; bought 12 Embraer Legacy planes soon after a Legacy jet collided with a passenger jetliner in Brazil, which helped drive down purchase price. David lives in London in the same house he has owned for the past 20 years; Simon resides in Monaco. Both active in their Reuben Foundation which funds healthcare and educational causes.

name: Billionaires
bio: Salesman’s son dropped out of college, took to road selling plush toys. Started line of stuffed animals 1986. Beanie Babies ruled lunch-box set for years; created buying mania by limiting production runs. Estimated $485 million sales down sharply as popularity of bean-filled cuties wanes. Plowed profits into real estate; owns country club in Santa Barbara, office parks in Chicago. Press-shy. Recently built world’s most expensive hotel room at New York’s Four Seasons Hotel: 4,300-square-foot suite has onyx walls and heart-stopping views of Manhattan skyline. One night’s stay: $30,000.

name: Billionaires
bio: Raised in Texas and Florida, became computer whiz at Princeton; worked at hedge funds on Wall Street after graduation. Quit before 30th birthday to sell books on the Internet from Seattle garage with wife. Took Amazon.com public in 1997; company name derived from South American river’s unending tributaries. Survived dot-com bust with discount pricing and free shipping. Books remain big business, but world’s biggest virtual mall now sells everything from clocks and cookware to cameras and clothing. Now peddling groceries. Space cadet: transforming Texas ranch into headquarters, testing facility for his Blue Origin commercial space-travel venture.

name: Billionaires
bio: Worked for rival pachinko manufacturer Heiwa before founding Sankyo in 1966. One of the few listed companies in Japan's pachinko gambling industry, his Sankyo Co. makes gambling-machines. Business is getting a boost from tighter gaming regulations that are forcing many of Japan's 18,000 pachinko parlors to replace old models with versions that pay out less. An avid golfer, uses some of that profit to host a major domestic golf tournament, the Sankyo Ladies Open.

name: Billionaires
bio: Former IBM salesman founded Electronic Data Systems 1962, sold to General Motors 1984 for $2.5 billion. Founded rival information services firm Perot Systems in 1988; public offering 1999. Took time off to concentrate on politics. Unsuccessfully ran for President 1992, 1996; warned of American job losses from free trade agreements. Perot Systems has since set up operations in India. Serves as chairman emeritus; son Ross Perot Jr. acts as chairman, also heads Dallas real estate firm Hillwood; develops commercial, residential properties across the U.S. Owns money management firm Perot Investment; principal investor in intellectual property fund IP Advantage. Author of 7 books (including United We Stand and The Dollar Crisis) spends time supporting military veterans.

name: Billionaires
bio: Founded generic-drug maker Apotex in 1974. Has since relentlessly battled big pharma over exclusivity patents, gradually building the company into the largest Canadian-owned drugmaker, with an estimated $1 billion in revenues. Once reportedly stormed into the offices of a rival, with a sheriff and private investigators in tow, to recover documents later used in a corporate espionage case. Made headlines last year when he successfully brought a generic version of Plavix, Bristol-Myers Squibb's blockbuster heart drug, to market amid a fierce patent dispute that eventually led to the firing of Bristol-Myers chief executive Peter Dolan.

name: Billionaires
bio: The Wertheimers are probably still celebrating: in May, Warren Buffett’s Berkshire Hathaway paid $4 billion for 80% of Iscar, the family’s manufacturer of precision carbide metalworking tools, founded in 1952. (Israeli taxes on the sale: $1 billion.) Wertheimer’s son Eitan will continue to run the company, while father Stef lobbies on behalf of his “Marshall Plan for the Middle East”. In October Wertheimer reportedly met with Israeli Foreign Minister Tzipi Livni and offered up his own funds to revitalize Palestinian refugee camps. The Wertheimers are also invested in dozens of other Israeli businesses, including Blades Technology, a maker of jet-engine blades.

name: Billionaires
bio: Arango, with brothers Manuel and Plácido, founded Bodega Aurrera discount supermarket chain in 1958. Through his Grupo Cifra expanded into VIPS and El Portón restaurants and Suburbia clothing stores. Cifra joined forces with Wal-Mart in the early 1990s and was later bought out and renamed Wal-Mart de México (known as Walmex). Deal extended Sam Walton’s empire south of the border and netted Arango more than $2 billion.

name: Billionaires
bio: In the last few years the Carnival Corp. heiress has been reducing her stake in the cruise line behemoth controlled from Miami by her billionaire brother, Micky Arison. She’s gradually reinvesting the proceeds to shore up control of her Israeli holdings, including Bank Hapoalim, the nation’s largest consumer bank. Arison, who has been often castigated by the Israeli media for her personal and professional dealings, has been earning accolades for recent investments, including $100 million for water-technology development. In February Arison’s third husband, Ofer Glazer, convicted of sexual harassment in 2005, lost his appeal to Israel’s Supreme Court. His 6-month prison sentence began in February.
title: Investor, Philanthropist

name: Billionaires
bio: Runs $2.7 billion (sales) Hubert Burda Media Holding, publisher of such well-known German magazines as Focus, Bunte and Freundin. Well-known philanthropist, supports the Bambi prize (Germany&#39s academy awards) and the Hermann-Lenz Prize for German literature. Last November the Jewish community in Berlin awarded him the Leo Baeck Prize for his efforts at bringing together Jewish and non-Jewish communities in Germany. He is married to well-known German actress Maria Furtwängler

name: Billionaires
bio: Computer Associates&#39 biggest individual shareholder. Haefner&#39s 22% stake can be traced back to 1968 when he sold his data processing business to University Computing, which was later acquired by Computer Associates. His Automobil- und Motoren AG  (AMAG) is Switzerland’s biggest importer of Volkswagen, Seat, Skoda, Audi and Porsche. His Moyglare Stud Farm in Ireland has about 100 horses and has bred winners including Simple Exchange and Media Puzzle.

name: Billionaires
bio: Hotel billionaire heads Hong Leong Group in Singapore, whose interests include London-listed Millennium & Copthorne, one of the world's largest hotel chains with more than 100 hotels located in 17 countries, including the Royal Palm Resort in the Galapagos Islands and the Millennium Biltmore Hotel in Los Angeles. Also a leading real estate developer; the group's City Developments Limited (CDL) owns more than 4 million square feet of land in the island nation of Singapore and is one of the island's biggest commercial landlords with 5 million square feet of office, industrial and retail space. In 2006 CDL launched the island's first branded residential project, St. Regis Residences, a 173-unit ultraluxurious residential development that has attracted buyers from all over the world. The group also launched Singapore's first hotel REIT in June 2006 when its Hong Leong Finance spun off and listed its CDL Hospitality Trusts in June 2006. Also has interests in his cousin Quek Leng Chan's (see) empire.

name: Billionaires
bio: Mikhelson's father headed the largest pipeline construction trust in the Soviet Union. From that Mikhelson managed to build independent gas company Novatek, which has large deposits in Yamal-Nenets region (northwestern Siberia). Mikhelson has proven to be complementary to state-ownedCK Gazprom, since he supplies Russian regions with gas at local prices, allowing the gas giant to keep more reserves on hand for lucrative export markets. Last year Gazprom bought nearly 20% of Novatek from Mikhelson and his partners, a deal widely seen as a way for the firm to ensure its survival.

name: Billionaires
bio: Affable head of Swiss luxury group Richemont whose brands include Cartier, Chloe and Dunhill. Surging profits helped boost the stock by one-third over the past year. Completed sale of his South African telecom assets to Vodafone last year; still holds significant interests in his native country. With family owns 2 of South Africa's best-known vineyards, Rupert & Rothschild and L'Ormarins; also owns one of country's most exclusive golf clubs.

name: Billionaires
bio: Secretive brothers own 13% of retailer Metro. Also control Travel Charm chain of 11 luxury hotels and spas located along Germany’s Baltic coast and in Austria. Their Mercator Foundation supports extracurricular language and professional skills programs for immigrant children in Germany.

name: Billionaires
bio: Son of Mormon apartment managers studied at U of Utah. Operated a Wyoming hotel/gas station complex before buying 10% share in the business. Added refining as company expanded to Utah, Arizona; bought Sinclair Oil 1976. Now owns 3 refineries and more than 1,000 miles of pipeline worth more than $2 billion. Sold Barnett Shale exploration acreage to gas driller Chesapeake Energy for $300 million in the spring. Also resorts: his $300 million Sun Valley Ranch ski resort hosts Herb Allen’s (see) media mogul conference each year.

name: Billionaires
bio: Brother-in-law of Hong Kong billionaire Sir Michael Kadoorie (see), owns big stakes and sits on the board of Hongkong & Shanghai Hotels, which operates the famous Peninsula Hotel in Hong Kong, and CLP Holdings, one of Hong Kong’s power supply companies, now under fire amid reports of worsening air pollution in the city.  Member of the International Council of the Tate Gallery and of the Victoria and Albert Museum in London.

name: Billionaires
bio: Traveling salesman’s son dropped out of high school in ninth grade, pumped gas. Drafted by Army 1943, moved to Detroit after World War II. Borrowed $1,800 to buy diner, sold for modest profit. Turned to building homes in Arizona; lost out in real estate crash of 1964. Wandered to southern California, bought more property. Then leveraged buyouts: Castle & Cooke (Hawaiian real estate), Dole Food (bananas, pineapples). Prominent GOP fundraiser also owns stake in Pacific Holdings, firm that owns second-largest chassis lessor in the U.S. Bought 250-acre plot in Kannapolis, N.C. 2004; plans to turn former factory into massive scientific and economic research center.

name: Billionaires
bio: Ebay's first president and full-time employee, Skoll remains its second-largest shareholder. He is no longer involved with the company, though, and has turned his attention to movies and philanthropy. Skoll was executive producer of An Inconvenient Truth, the global-warming documentary that featured former Vice President Al Gore. The film, which was made by Skoll's Participant Productions, won two Oscars in February. Skoll pumped gas in Toronto before getting an M.B.A. from Stanford in 1995.

name: Billionaires
bio: Son of a grocer developed shopping centers in Iowa with 2 brothers beginning in 1954. Went public 1970; REIT was liquidated 15 years later for a 100% profit. Bought more malls, took General Growth Properties public 1993. Relocated to Chicago after brother Martin died 1995. Remains chairman; son, John, took reins 1999. Today company controls 200 shopping malls in 44 states, vast array of commercial properties.

name: Billionaires
bio: Chairs 110-year Godrej empire, best known for consumer products; also stakes in agrifoods, engineering, pesticides, software, chemicals. Extensive landholdings in Mumbai soaring in value along with country&#39s real estate boom. Stepping up investments in group’s property development business.

name: Billionaires
bio: The man who cracked the De Beers diamond monopoly. Leviev, the world’s largest cutter and polisher of diamonds, procured his own supply of rough diamonds to sell, thereby undercutting De Beers’ business. Now Leviev is going retail—he’s already opened an eponymous store in London, and a New York branch on tony Madison Avenue will open this spring. (Leviev diamonds made their red-carpet debut this year: Drew Barrymore dripped with them at the Golden Globe awards.) The Uzbeki-born father of 9 also controls the Africa Israel Group, an international real estate company with holdings in Israel, the U.S., the Czech Republic, Serbia and Holland.

name: Billionaires
bio: Son of a coal miner, built his Ukrainian coal and steel empire in the mid-1990s by forging ties with politician Viktor Yanukovych, who was then prime minister. After his ally lost 2004 presidential election, had his key asset, Ukraine’s largest steel company Kryvorizhstal, reprivatized. Then spent several months in hiding in Europe while criminal investigators looked into his past; no charges filed. Didn’t take long for him to recover politically: became a deputy in Ukraine’s parliament last March. With pal Victor Pinchuk (see) named person of the year by the Ukrainian Observer. At Davos this January, announced plans to list his diversified conglomerate System Capital Management.

name: Billionaires
bio: Bought his father's one-route Ontario bus company for a dollar in 1951; eventually built into Power Corp., a $23 billion (sales) financial services and communications giant. Company owns Montreal daily La Presse as well as 6 other newspapers in Quebec and Ontario. It also controls Power Financial, which includes life insurer Great-West Lifeco and Investors Group, the largest mutual fund company in Canada. In a deal worth $3.9 billion, Power Financial recently announced it was acquiring beleaguered U.S. mutual fund company Putnam Investments. Desmarais, who is still chairman of Power Corp., has left the day-to-day operations to sons Andre and Paul Jr.; Dad collects Canadian art and hunts birds at his private estate in Quebec.

name: Billionaires
bio: Bulk of fortune comes from 1998 sale of his Banco Real to Dutch bank ABN Amro for $2.1 billion. Faria kept some of Banco Real assets, around which he has since built Banco Alfa, with $4.8 billion in assets now Brazil’s 17th largest bank. Also owns Agropalma, a company reported to be Latin America’s largest palm-oil producer, which is benefiting from the growing demand for biodiesel.

name: Billionaires
bio: With mother Ingeburg, his 4 siblings Daniela, Günter, Joachim and Wolfgang (see all), inherited fortune from his late father, coffee baron Max Herz. Helped push out brother Günter and sister Daniela in a drawn-out family feud. Now holds 34% stake in $5.2 billion (sales) Tchibo Holding, makers of a well-known Germany coffee brand. Group also has 50.46 % stake in Beiersdorf AG, makers of Nivea skin care products. He and brother Wolfgang now call the shots on the key holdings.

name: Billionaires
bio: With mother Ingeburg, his 4 siblings Daniela, Günter, Joachim and Michael (see all), inherited fortune from his late father, coffee baron Max Herz. Now holds 34% stake in $5.2 billion (sales) Tchibo Holding, makers of a well-known Germany coffee brand. Group also has 50.46 % stake in Beiersdorf AG, makers of Nivea skin care products. He and brother Michael now call the shots on the key holdings.

name: Billionaires
bio: Heads $3.9 billion (sales) HCL group, which makes PCs and provides software and outsourcing services to such customers as Boeing, IBM. HCL, which celebrated 30th anniversary last August, has 43,000 employees in 17 countries. An engineer, funds private engineering school that runs courses in association with Carnegie Mellon.

name: Billionaires
bio: Sold electronics for father’s distribution company before opening car stereo store 1966. Lured older customers with appliances, VCRs; took public as Best Buy 1985. Pioneered big-box-store concept: stacked inventory on sales floor, let customers tinker with merchandise. Today $31 billion in sales, more than 940 locations. Moving into Asia: agreed to buy stake in China’s Jiangsu Five Star Appliance last May for $180 million. Donated $50 million to U of St. Thomas.

name: Billionaires
bio: Bank examiner got taste for takeover after buying Dallas drugstore in 1961 for $5,000 cash plus $95,000 loan; sold 100-store chain to Eckerd Corp. for $50 million 1973. Built Valhi, publicly traded holding company, through hostile buyouts. Schoolteacher’s son now invested in titanium (Timet, Kronos), waste management (Waste Control Specialists), computer components (CompX International). Gives to arts, medicine and children&#39s charities via Harold Simmons Foundation.

name: Billionaires
bio: Reserved hedge fund manager started career as a theoretical mathematician. MIT grad taught at Harvard. Got Ph.D. from UC, Berkeley, then broke codes for U.S. Department of Defense during Vietnam. Left to take job heading math department at SUNY at Stony Brook. Founded Renaissance Technologies investment firm 1982, generated stellar returns using computer modeling to find inefficiencies in highly liquid securities. His Medallion fund has returned 34% a year net of his stiff fees, believed to be 44% of profits, 5% of assets. Last year up 29.5% net of fees. Created Renaissance Institutional Equity Fund for institutional investors in 2005. Chairs Math for America; also supports autism research.

name: Billionaires
bio: Left his medical practice in South Africa to join identical twin brother, Thomas, in founding generic drug maker Hexal AG in 1986. Brothers eventually built Germany's second-largest generic drug maker. In February 2005 sold business as well as their 68% stake of U.S. Eon Labs to Novartis for $7.5 billion. He and his twin are now both executives at Sandoz, a generics division of Novartis. Said to love sailing, golf and skiing.

name: Billionaires
bio: With identical twin brother, Andreas, founded generic drug maker Hexal AG in 1986. Brothers eventually built Germany’s second-largest generic drugmaker. In  2005 sold business and their 68% of U.S. Eon Labs to Novartis for $7.5 billion. He and his twin are now both executives at Sandoz, a generics division of Novartis. Is said to be the more extroverted of the brothers. Reportedly collects modern art and Swiss watches.

name: Billionaires
bio: The low-key real estate and energy mogul earned international attention after he bought Manhattan’s famed Plaza Hotel in 2005 for $675 million. Via Elad Holdings (named after his son, the 26-year-old heir apparent), Tshuva also owns a real estate portfolio of residential buildings in North America and Europe. In Israel his publicly traded Delek (also listed on Nasdaq) operates 232 gas stations as well as interests in insurance, car dealerships and cable television. To this day Tshuva, who grew up penniless, never wears a watch, in honor of his parents who could not afford to buy him one as a child.

name: Billionaires
bio: Chairs family-owned conglomerate $8.5 billion (sales) Grupo Votorantim, which is active in steel, pulp and paper, chemicals and orange juice. Also owns cement plants in the Great Lakes region of the U.S. His three siblings and their heirs also have stakes in Votorantim. The company is actively managed by 8 members of the third generation; Antonio’s son Carlos Ermírio de Moraes heads the executive board. Antonio writes a weekly column in one of the leading Sao Paulo newspapers, Folha de Sao Paulo.

name: Billionaires
bio: This Monaco-based ultraprivate Romanian-born Israeli and his family control a vast global shipping empire, plus interests in banking and real estate. Through Israel Corp., Sammy controls Israel Chemicals, Zim (shipping) and Tower Semiconductor, all of which have benefited from the rise in chemical and oil prices. Sammy also shares a stake in Royal Caribbean, the world’s second-largest cruise line. In October Ofer increased his stake in South Korea’s Hanjin Shipping to 12%; rumors persist that he will pursue a takeover despite declaring that the investment is passive. In May 2006, Ofer, a renowned modern art collector, reportedly shelled out $40 million for Van Gogh&#39s “Madame Ginoux”.

name: Billionaires
bio: Youngest son of Orascom conglomerate founder, Onsi Sawiris took over construction division from his father in 1998. The company reported a record $298 million in profits last year, thanks in part to Nassef's expansion efforts in developing countries such as Algeria, Indonesia and Iraq. Also has a significant stake in Houston-headquartered construction company Texas Industries.

name: Billionaires
bio: Turned an obscure Kyoto playing-card company into Nintendo, one of the world’s best known game companies. Retired as chairman in June 2005 after 55 years at the helm. Still a large shareholder. Company is doing well, thanks to new portable gaming devices. Company’s sales are expected to reach $8 billion for the fiscal year ending in March.

name: Billionaires
bio: Chairs $3.7 billion (sales) London-listed metals and mining giant Vedanta Resources; brother Navin is No. 2. Main assets in India, Australia and Zambia. Announced $3.1 billion expansion of capacities. Plans to build Vedanta University, India's answer to Stanford, in eastern India; has pledged $1 billion.

name: Billionaires
bio: Brash entrepreneur founded Virgin 37 years ago as a mail-order record retailer. Now group revenues exceed $10 billion. Constantly making forays into new areas: this year moved into gaming and biofuels. The lucrative merger of Virgin Mobile UK with NTL and Telewest was also finalized last year; combined entity will be rebranded Virgin Media. His plans for Virgin America are still grounded awaiting approval from U.S. aviation authorities. Biggest news came in philanthropy: in September Branson pledged $3 billion over 10 years towards renewable energy research and development. In February, with former vice president Al Gore at his side, offered $25 million prize to anyone who can come up with a way to remove at least a billion tons of carbon dioxide a year from the Earth’s atmosphere.

name: Billionaires
bio: Founded Randstad Holding in 1960, now one the world’s largest temporary employment agencies. Owns 44% of the $7 billion (sales) company, which has branches in a dozen European and North American countries. Although retired, he remains vice chairman of the supervisory board. Enjoys sailing.

name: Billionaires
bio: With father, opened Rimi discount supermarket in the late 1970s. Later partnered with Swedish retailer ICA Group and supermarket giant Royal Ahold. In 2004 exercised option to sell his remaining 20% stake in the venture, forcing Ahold to pony up $1 billion. Has been boosting his stake in consumer-goods company Orkla, which named him chairman of the board in 2006. Says company will expand into Germany, France, the U.K. and Asia in the next 5 years. Also invests in real estate and local companies through his Canica group. Said to have transferred 30% of his Canica holdings to each of three children in order to start estate planning, but retains control over all shares. Reportedly owns island in the Caribbean and one of the biggest sailboats in Europe.

name: Billionaires
bio: Japan's most vocal shareholder activist. The owner of a company, Shin Nihon Kanko, that operates golf courses, last year slammed Japan Airlines, of which he was the largest stockholder, for a string of losses. The then president of Asia's largest carrier later quit. Itoyama has since moved on, selling half his JAL stock to buy a 10% stake in TV Tokyo, an affiliate of Japan's leading financial daily, the Nihon Keizai Shimbun.

name: Billionaires
bio: Vancouver magnate parlayed car dealerships, started shortly after college, into advertising, fishing and supermarket empire. Currently building stakes in Canadian small caps, including ones in Westshore Terminals Income Fund, Canfor and Sun-Rype Products. Also owns eclectic tourist attractions including Ripley's Believe It or Not. Owns a massive Palm Springs lair that once belonged to Frank Sinatra.

name: Billionaires
bio: Former butcher’s apprentice owns and runs $8.5 billion (sales) Anton Schlecker drugstore chain; group’s 13,800 locations account for 70% of Germany’s drugstores. Also expanding into Austria, Holland, Spain, France, Italy, Portugal and Eastern Europe. Wife Christa and children Lars and Meike help run the business. Football fan; enjoys sport cars, supposedly owns a Ferrari, Aston Martin, Porsche and Jaguar.

name: Billionaires
bio: Often called the Siberian hermit; rarely leaves remote town of Surgut. Avoids public attention and the trappings of wealth. A professional driller, was appointed chief executive of Surgutneftegas (which means "Surgut oil and gas") at 33. In early 1990s Bogdanov and his fellow managers privatized the company; it’s now Russia&#39s fourth-largest oil concern. Surgut invests heavily in exploration, oil field development and education. Throughout 2006 rumors raged of a possible takeover by state-run Rosneft. But the move didn’t happen and analysts say 2007 could be the year.

name: Billionaires
bio: Former intelligence officer, banker and, since 2003, a State Duma member, Lebedev is a vociferous critic of the authorities. He threatened judicial action against Russian Prime Minister Mikhail Fradkov, accusing him of procrastination on Aeroflot airplane selection (he’s a major shareholder); has frequently clashed with Moscow Mayor Yuri Luzhkov. Nevertheless, keeps a substantial part of his funds in state companies: the government may be a bad business partner, but it’s the largest in Russia.

name: Billionaires
bio: Son of a bird salesman ran father’s Hartz Mountain Pet Products. Sold 85% of company for $208 million in 2000, remaining stake to Sumitomo Corp. 4 years later. Plowed proceeds into burgeoning real estate empire: 39 million square feet of commercial space in New York and New Jersey. Owns Manhattan’s hip boutique hotels Soho Grand and Tribeca Grand; occupancy rates of hotels’ $600-a-night suites at alltime high. Ambitious redevelopment of 102-acre site of a former Ford Motor plant in Edison, N.J. slowly moving forward. Still rehabbing family’s reputation after son Edward, former head of Canary Capital hedge fund, set off 2003 mutual fund scandal with improper market-timing trading scheme. Ed paid $40 million fine. Gave $30 million to get his name on alma mater NYU’s business school 1988.

name: Billionaires
bio: Widow of Brooklyn-born Preston Tisch (d. 2005), who with brother Laurence (d. 2003) bought New Jersey hotel in 1946; leased hotels in Atlantic City. Duo graduated to New York landmarks: Drake, Belmont Plaza and Regency. Took control of Loews Theaters 1959. Company now a diverse portfolio of subsidiaries: CNA Financial (insurance), Boardwalk (natural gas pipelines), Diamond Offshore (oil drilling), Bulova (watches) and Lorillard (tobacco). Company still under family’s control; shares have tripled in the past 3 years. Preston: co-owner of pro football’s New York Giants served 2-year term as Postmaster General. Family’s contributions to NYU exceed $100 million.

name: Billionaires
bio: Creator of Japan's best-known discount clothing brand, Uniqlo, which is sometimes referred to as the Japanese version of the Gap. His company, Fast Retailing, last business year posted record sales of $3.9 billion from its sales of Chinese-made jackets, shirts and other clothing that retail for as little as $5. Yanai is taking the Uniqlo brand overseas: last year, opened a branch in New York City's swank Soho neighborhood. It was followed by an outlet in Shanghai.

name: Billionaires
bio: Grew up in Moscow, attended a well-regarded high school for the city’s elite and the prestigious Moscow State University. Later worked at the Institute for Systems Studies at the Soviet Academy of Sciences. In 1989 went to the Ministry of Foreign Affairs; worked simultaneously as a senior researcher at the Vienna International Institute for Applied Systems Analysis. Two years later was tapped to be minister of foreign economic relations. In 1994 met Alfa Group&#39s Mikhail Fridman and soon became a shareholder of Alfa-Bank, a business within the Alfa Group conglomerate; he is now its president. Owns largest private collection of Russian art in Russia.

name: Billionaires
bio: His upscale U.K. properties continue to attract high-end tenants like Hugo Boss, Cartier and Richard Ward, the fashionable hair salon where a doorman hails taxis and feeds parking meters. The Saatchi Gallery has also leased space. Cadogan is  involved with several charities and is Chairman of Leukemia Research.

name: Billionaires
bio: Head of Formula One racing still knows how to cut a deal. In 2005 sold his remaining 25% stake in Formula One to CVC Capital Partners, a leading European private equity firm, then turned around and reinvested with CVC in a new joint company called Alpha Prema. The new corporation now controls 100% of Formula One Group, and Bernie still gets to direct the empire.

name: Billionaires
bio: Star Wars mastermind completed his intergalactic double trilogy in 2005 with Revenge of the Sith; final installment grossed $850 million worldwide. Now rumored to be working on a Star Wars television series. Directed first movie while studying film at University of Southern California; futuristic police-state flick THX-1138 a cult classic. Later: directed American Graffiti, produced Indiana Jones series. Founded Industrial Light & Magic in 1975 to create the special effects shots in original Star Wars; shop handled state-of-the-art tricks in Harry Potter movies. Also owns LucasArts (videogames), Lucas Licensing (Star Wars toys and books). Next up: fourth Indiana Jones movie to be released May 2008.

name: Billionaires
bio: “Accidental entrepreneur” studied chemistry at UC, Berkeley; wanted academic career, but teaching jobs were scarce. Back to school, earned Caltech Ph.D. One of the “Gang of 8” that founded Fairchild Semiconductor in 1957. With partner Robert Noyce, founded chipmaker Intel 1968. Introduced first microprocessor 3 years later. First year sales: $3,000. Today world’s largest producer of computer chips. Served as chief exec from 1975 to 1987; chairman until 1997. Coined Moore’s Law, predicting chip power would double every 12 (later revised to 24) months. Donated half his Intel shares to Gordon and Betty Moore Foundation. Avid outdoorsman, big donor to environmental research; has a pygmy owl named after him. Spends time fishing and golfing in Hawaii.

name: Billionaires
bio: In 1978 became president of the board of his father’s Eternit, a construction materials manufacturer. Soon halted the company’s production of asbestos-containing goods. In 2003 donated $1 billion to support sustainable development programs like community organizations, educational programs, corporate social responsibility and the effective management of natural resources. Despite reputation as environmental philanthropist, is facing lawsuits in Switzerland and Italy surrounding the asbestos-related deaths of former plant workers. Much of his wealth is now held in a diversified portfolio of stocks, bonds and private equity investments and is handled by professional managers.

name: Billionaires
bio: Cofounded Bravo brewery in Russia and created popular Botchkarov beer brand. Sold to Heineken February 2002. Used proceeds to go on buying spree in native Iceland and eastern Europe. Still holds big stakes in Iceland in generic drug company Actavis and in Landsbanki, nation's oldest bank, which his father chairs. Recently sold interest in Ceske Radiokomunikace, a Czech telecom, for $1.4 billion. Now shopping around stake in Bulgarian Telecommunications Company; reportedly close to signing a deal with a US investment firm. Owns real estate in Romania, Scandinavia, Spain, Turkey and elsewhere in eastern Europe. Lives in London with longtime girlfriend, a movie producer, and their son.

name: Billionaires
bio: Became friends in early 1940s with Jay Van Andel (d. 2004) after Richard offered Jay 25 cents a week in exchange for a ride to school. After high school joined military together. Opened drive-in eatery; then founded Amway. Reorganized as Alticor in 2000. Today 3 million salespeople distribute personal care, home products in more than 80 countries. Now retired, serves on board. Heart transplant recipient owns pro basketball’s Orlando Magic. Long-practicing Christian tithes 10% of income to church; with wife, Helen, has donated $400 million to health, education, the arts.

name: Billionaires
bio: Born in Fujian Province, Hui is one of China's largest  property barons. Owns properties in Beijing, on Nanjing Road and in Fujian  Province. His Shanghai Shimao International Plaza, set along Shanghai's famed  Nanjing Road, will be completed later this year. Also plans to list Shimao's  China real estate holding company in Hong Kong in 2006. The company is  branching out into other cities, with new projects in Wuhan and  Beijing.

name: Billionaires
bio: Oldest child of Texas wildcatter H.L. Hunt (d. 1974), whose oil empire sprang from poker winnings. Inherited Hunt Oil with 3 sisters; Ray continued to mine black gold while siblings lost big in silver market. Made a fortune with oil deals in Yemen, natural gas in Peru. Today holdings include oilfields in U.S., Canada, Senegal, Oman. Leased new acreage in the Gulf for $11 million last June. Also real estate: developing luxury hotels, office parks in California and the Southwest. Sits on Halliburton board. Active in Dallas charities.

name: Billionaires
bio: Carpenter by trade, opened his own business in 1980 and developed it into one of Spain's leading property companies, $1.2 billion (sales) Fadesa Inmobiliaria. Took company public in April 2004. In September 2006 agreed to sell 55% stake in company to real estate group Martinsa for $2.8 billion. Collects art from Spanish province of Galicia; enjoys woodworking.

name: Billionaires
bio: Self-made Saudi businessman made bulk of his fortune through profitable aviation services contracts with the Saudi government. Credited with inventing the modern concept of Islamic banking, which among other things forbids interest payments. Now focuses his energy on finance and media: Albaraka Banking Group, his $1.8 billion (market capitalization) line of Islamic banks went public earlier this year, amidst the regional decline in bank stocks. Raised the ire of soccer fans across the region this summer when his subscription-only ART satellite TV channel secured the exclusive rights to broadcast the World Cup. Kamel eventually agreed to air the games in the Middle East and North Africa (terrestrial-only) more broadly for free.

name: Billionaires
bio: Son of James Kellogg III, former chairman of New York Stock Exchange; cofounded Spear, Leeds & Kellogg 1954, nation’s largest specialist on the NYSE. Peter joined as director 1973. Sold to Goldman Sachs in 2000 for $6.5 billion. Owns and operates Hudson Farm, 3000-acre hunting club in Andover, N.J.

name: Billionaires
bio: With younger brother Ronald (see), sons of beauty magnate Estée Lauder (d. 2004). Mother founded eponymous cosmetics company in 1946 peddling face cream created by chemist uncle. Company now controls almost half of U.S. premium cosmetics market. Newest “Azurée” line created by hotshot designer Tom Ford. Leonard chairman since 1995; son William now chief executive.

name: Billionaires
bio: Harvard M.B.A. started Finansbank, Turkey's fifth-largest private bank as measured by consolidated assets, which he sold in 2005 to the National Bank of Greece for $2.76 billion. That year also gave scholarships and supplied textbooks to more than 7,000 needy students. Irked Koc family when he sold his retail chain Gima to rival Sabanci Group's (see Erol Sabanci) Carrefour SA for $132 million. Plans to use his money to open a university.

name: Billionaires
bio: Attended Yale with President George W. Bush; founded ballet society to meet girls. Then Harvard M.B.A., managing director at Lehman Brothers 1978 at age 31. With partner, Peter G. Peterson, cofounded Blackstone Group, Wall Street investment house. Duo started firm in 1985 with $400,000; since then they have invested in 100 companies with a total enterprise value of $160 billion. Today 6 buyout funds with stakes in Bresnan Communications (cable television), Houghton Mifflin (publishing), Texas Genco (wholesale electricity). Currently investing $15.6 billion from fifth fund, world’s largest. Beat out Steven Roth&#39s (see) to buy Sam Zell&#39s (see) Equity Office Properties Trust last month for $39 billion; deal the largest buyout in history. Chair of Kennedy Center in Washington, D.C. threw himself a 60th birthday party at New York&#39s Park Avenue Armory last month; reported guests included billionaires Donald Trump, Leon Black, Wilbur Ross and Thomas H. Lee (see all).

name: Billionaires
bio: Father was a doctor in China; fled during WWII, moved to South Africa. Patrick graduated high school at age 16, a doctor by 23. Joined UCLA faculty, launched research leading to first human islet cell transplant; work funded by investor group led by Lee Iacocca. Role at first company, VivoRx, collapsed after feuding with investors. Founded American Pharmaceutical Partners; invented cancer treatment Abraxane, which uses particles of human protein albumin to deliver drug taxane directly to tumors. Company renamed Abraxis BioScience. Actress wife, Michele Chan, famous for roles on 1980s TV shows Danger Bay, Hotel.

name: Billionaires
bio: Founder of Austrian retail chain Billa, sold out to the German REWE group in 1996. Invested the proceeds in prime Austrian real estate and is now one of the largest, possibly the largest, private real estate owners in Austria. His assets include the five-star Hotel Radisson in Salzburg, the historic building that houses the Vienna Stock Exchange and four palaces in Vienna. The former jazz pianist, whose stage name was Charlie Walker, likes to hang out at the Cafe Central, an old coffee house he renovated in Vienna.  Recently published his memoires, "Karl Wlaschek: A Success Story".

name: Billionaires
bio: Carpenter by trade, opened his own business in 1980 and developed it into one of Spain's leading property companies, $1.2 billion (sales) Fadesa Inmobiliaria. Took company public in April 2004. In September 2006 agreed to sell  55% stake in company to real estate group Martinsa for $2.8 billion. Collects art from Spanish province of Galicia; enjoys woodworking.

name: Billionaires
bio: Apparently met Helmut Horten, founder of the eponymous German department store chain, in a hotel bar in 1959 when she was 19 years old. Despite 30-year age difference, they wed 7 years later. In 1987 he died and left her an estimated $1 billion fortune. Austria’s merry widow now divides her time between a home in Lyford Cay in the Bahamas; a residence in Tessin, Switzerland; a penthouse in Vienna and a house by the Wörthersee in Austria. Owns one of world&#39s largest yachts, the 315-foot Carinthia VII. Said to enjoy hunting and collecting art.

name: Billionaires
bio: Helped then husband Amancio Ortega make gowns and lingerie in their home. Home business became one of world most successful apparel manufacturers, Inditex, which also owns Zara retail stores. Couple divorced years ago, but Mera still holds 7% stake in the now $8.7 billion (sales) business. Also got $600 million in cash at time of Inditex's public offering. Has invested the cash in Spanish film production outfit; marine fish farming group; a company that looks for cancer treatment in compounds found in the sea; and a maker of a fingerprinting identification system for newborns. Has received various awards for her contributions to Spanish society via her Paideia Foundation, which helps people with physical and mental disabilities.
title: Investor, Philanthropist

name: Billionaires
bio: Son of a fried-mussel-pancake street vendor in Bangkok, Charoen made his fortune in whiskey and beer. His Chang Beer brand is Thailand’s top seller; brand became official sponsor of Liverpool’s Everton soccer club in 2004. Took his Thai Beverage company public in Singapore in May after attempts to list in Thailand were derailed by protests against the promotion of alcohol. Also has his hand in hotels; owns Plaza Athénées in New York City and Bangkok.

name: Billionaires
bio: Casino impresario catching up to archnemesis Sheldon Adelson (see) in Chinese gambling mecca Macau. Unveiled $1.2 billion Wynn Macau casino resort last month; complex features 600 hotel rooms, 6 restaurants. Son of bingo parlor operator studied at U. of Pennsylvania, became keno manager at Frontier Hotel in Las Vegas. Bought Golden Nugget before building Mirage, Treasure Island and Bellagio theme resorts. Sold Mirage Resorts to Kirk Kerkorian (see) for $6.4 billion in 2000. Wynn Resorts public 2002; stock up 600% since.

name: Billionaires
bio: Grandson of the founder of Danish toymaker Lego. Ran the company for 25 years before stepping down in 2004 after several years of losses; remains its sole owner.  Thanks to restructuring and the sale of assets like its four Legoland amusement parks, the world's sixth-largest toymaker by sales is finally making a profit again.

name: Billionaires
bio: Last year was a nightmare for Rybolovlev and his company Uralkali, Russia&#39s largest producer of potassium fertilizers. The company’s first-half sales and profits plunged following its suspension of exports to China during talks about a price hike. Then, in the fall was forced to close Uralkali’s oldest mine, which had accounted for 20% of the company&#39s overall production; output not expected to recover until 2011. Finally, in October 2006 unexpectedly canceled the company’s long awaited initial offering in London.

name: Billionaires
bio: Army surgical technician drove cab, sold hypodermic needles before inventing cardiovascular catheter using $1,500 blowtorch, soldering iron and plastic tubing. Started medical device company Cook 1963 in Bloomington, Ind. apartment. Added pacemakers, syringes, stents; became world’s largest privately held medical device manufacturer. Rival Guidant proposed $3 billion buyout 2003; deal fell through after new stent yielded dismal results. Gambling venture recently out of arbitration: split control of $382 million casino resort in southern Indiana with Lauth Property Group. Early riser still arrives for work at 5 a.m. each day.

name: Billionaires
bio: Fifth wife and widow of Axel Springer, founder of $3.1 billion (sales) Axel Springer Verlag, one of Germany's leading publishing groups. Now owns 50% of company, which publishes more than 150 papers in 32 countries, including leading German conservative daily Die Welt and Germany's largest daily tabloid, Bild Zeitung. Axel Springer publishes foreign language editions of Forbes in Poland and Russia. Active in various philanthropic organizations; has received numerous awards for her efforts to rebuild German-Jewish relations.

name: Billionaires
bio: Hungarian immigrant’s family fled Soviet occupation, moved to New York 1958. Became obsessed with airplanes as a child. Studied economics at UCLA, got hooked on flying; ran own plane brokerage while in college. Then with $150,000 savings, $1.7 million bank loan, started International Lease Finance with Louis and Leslie Gonda (see both). Business took off: airlines lined up for cheap, low-risk leases as industry was deregulated during 1970s. Became one of world’s largest aircraft lessors. Sold to AIG in 1990; rising shares made him billionaire. Still works for insurance giant; says he’s insulated from industry’s downward spiral with majority of business coming from overseas. Friend of actor/pilot John Travolta; reads the official Airline Guide at bedtime. “It gives me an understanding of where airlines are flying.”

name: Billionaires
bio: Ohio State law school dropout set up women’s sportswear store 1963 with $5,000 loan from aunt. Expanded, took public as Limited Brands in 1969. Today company owns Victoria’s Secret, Express, Bath & Body Works. Sales: $9.7 billion. Supports Jewish causes with wife, Abigail, and Wexner Foundation.

name: Billionaires
bio: Onetime go-between for major oil companies and state-owned oil fields in the Gulf settled in Britain in 1980 after fleeing the late Saddam Hussein’s Iraq. Started a lawsuit in early 2007 against France’s Elf, accusing its former directors of fraud and of entangling his name in their criminal acts. Daughter Luma one of 9 pharma execs facing charges of conspiracy to defraud Britain’s National Health Service out of many millions of pounds by inflating the price of some of Britain&#39s most commonly prescribed medicines. Pet charitable cause: gives money to grassroots organizations that repatriate young boys forced to race camels outside Pakistan.

name: Billionaires
bio: Powerful wife of Moscow Mayor Yuri Luzhkov started out as a factory worker, then entered the Moscow Institute of Management. Met Luzhkov in 1987 when they were both serving on the Mosgorispolcom, a Soviet-era municipal commission. In 1991 started plastic-products company Inteko, which produced furniture and crockery but has since expanded into construction and construction materials. Inteko is suing the publisher and editor of Forbes Russia over a December cover story about the company; it is seeking 106,500 rubles ($4,040) from each defendant.

name: Billionaires
bio: Former head of Seagrams empire inherited business from father, Sam (d. 1971), Russian émigré who founded Distillers Corp. in Montreal in 1924, made millions running whiskey across U.S.-Canadian border during Prohibition. Edgar Sr. took over U.S. side of business, brother Charles (see) stayed in Canada. Added premium brands (Absolut vodka), juices (Tropicana), large stake in DuPont. Son Edgar Jr. went Hollywood in 1990s: sold off juice, nylons business to finance $5.7 billion purchase of MCA/Universal. Sold rest to Vivendi for $34 billion. Family fortune soon faltered; cut losses, sold out after losing billions. Edgar Sr. now concentrating on nonprofit activities, Jewish advocacy.

name: Billionaires
bio: Built family's scrap metal business into a cascade of assets in media, utilities and oil. The resulting conglomerate, Compagnie Nationale a Portefeuille, recently sold its stake in media giant Bertelsmann. Known as a workaholic who claims he'll never retire, Baron Frere is always on the verge of a new business venture. Recently partnered with good friend and billionaire Bernard Arnault to start a joint investment group concentrating on European companies. Already owns 2 French vineyards with the LVMH mogul.

name: Billionaires
bio: Founded and runs Sun Pharmaceuticals, maker of branded generics with factories in India, Europe and U.S. Investing in drug discovery. Its antiallergy molecule undergoing U.S. clinical trials. Plans to demerge R&D arm.

name: Billionaires
bio: Hired as Esprit’s primary sourcing agent in 1971. Later bought rights to the clothing brand in Europe and Asia; listed Esprit Far East on Hong Kong stock exchange in 1993. Stepped  down as chief executive in 2003; remains chairman. Has been steadily selling off stake over the  past few years, pocketing almost $2 billion along the way; now holds less than 9% of Esprit.

name: Billionaires
bio: Met up with Austrian Dietrich Mateschitz two decades ago and decided to start an energy drink company with him. He provided the beverage formula and his partner contributed the marketing flair. Together they created Red Bull, which now has $3.4 billion in sales and in which they each own 49%. Yoovidhya also owns $170 million (sales) TC Pharmaceuticals, a producer of energy drinks in Thailand, and part of a private Thai hospital chain. Son Chalerm, who holds the remaining 2% stake in Red Bull, owns one of Asia’s leading wine producers, Siam Winery, whose labels include Monsoon Valley and Sabai, an herb-and-wine drink.

name: Billionaires
bio: Brother to mall magnate Majid Al Futtaim (see), Abdulla has independently built up his own conglomerate into an entity so large and profitable, it may make up as much as 15% of Dubai&#39s gross domestic product. Exclusive United Arab Emirates’ distributor for big-name brands such as IKEA, IBM and Toyota. Next big project: Dubai Festival City, a 1,600-acre waterfront complex.

name: Billionaires
bio: Identical twin brothers continue to make news with their vast property and retail holdings. In January, via their company Ellerman, the brothers upped their stake in Intercontinental Hotels Group, sparking speculation that they are attempting to take over the group, which owns Holiday Inn and Crowne Plaza. On the retail side, company is working on rebranding their home shopping business, which announced its merger with Great Universal Stores’ home shopping operations in 2003. Brothers&#39 main media interest is the U.K.&#39s conservative Telegraph newspaper.

name: Billionaires
bio: Father, Perry (d. 2006), inherited family fortune created by oil baron uncle Sid Richardson 1959. Passed on to eldest son, Sid (see), 1968; other brother Robert (see) split that same year. Siblings diversified oil and gas portfolio with stakes in Disney (entertainment), John Wiley & Sons (publishing) and Human Genome Sciences (pharmaceuticals). Lee avid outdoorsman.

name: Billionaires
bio: Father, Perry (d. 2006), inherited family fortune created by oil baron uncle Sid Richardson 1959. Passed on to eldest son, Sid, 1968; other brother Robert (see) split that same year. Siblings diversified oil and gas portfolio with stakes in Disney (entertainment), John Wiley & Sons (publishing) and Human Genome Sciences (pharmaceuticals). Sid still runs family investments.

name: Billionaires
bio: Ex-record-label tycoon sold his Zomba Recordings, onetime label for Britney Spears, Backstreet Boys and &#39N Sync, to BMG for $2.7 billion in 2002. Raised in a middle-class neighborhood in Johannesburg, South Africa, Calder started out playing in a local band at age 18 to support his mother and sister after his father’s death. Became a music promoter and moved to London in 1975. He now lives in the Cayman Islands, spending part of his time on a children focused charitable foundation that works in nine African countries.

name: Billionaires
bio: Owns more than 50% of Caltagirone SpA, an industrial holding company with cement, real estate and media interests. Subsidiary Caltagirone Editore controls Italy’s leading free daily newspaper, Leggo, with daily distribution of over 1 million copies. Dubbed Franco the Taciturn by media for his quiet ways. Son Francesco Jr. is president of Caltagirone’s cement subsidiary, Cementir. Also personally holds a stake in Acea SpA, Italy’s main water-and-energy provider.

name: Billionaires
bio: Highly secretive investor studied at Wharton, started trading options at Gruntal & Co. 1978; made $8,000 profit on first day. Founded SAC Capital with $20 million 1992. Today manages more than $10 billion across 9 funds based in the U.S., Cayman Islands, Anguilla. Average annual return: 36%. High performance fees: 3% of assets, 35% of profits. Avid art collector has spent more than $300 million since 2000 building collection; now refurbishing Damien Hirst’s “The Physical Impossibility of Death in the Mind of Someone Living.” Paid $8 million for the work featuring dead shark in formaldehyde; shark now shrinking, in talks with artist to replace with fresher carcass.

name: Billionaires
bio: Turned his father&#39s dust removal business into thermal engineering firm GEA. In 1999 sold his stake to MG Technologies in exchange for $1 billion in cash and 21% stake in the combined group. In March 2006 sold that stake to various institutional investors for approximately $630 million. Runs financial consulting firm, Luserve AG, from Switzerland, where he lives with his wife and 6 children. Sailed his yacht Hetairos at the Maxi Yacht Rolex Cup Races against boats owned by Hasso Plattner and Günter Herz (see).

name: Billionaires
bio: Inherited steel-and-coke fortune, turned from smokestacks to real estate and venture capital. Notable properties include Pittsburgh’s PPG Place, also luxury resorts in California. Scored hit in private equity as early backer of Kohlberg Kravis Roberts; most of fortune now in private buyout and venture capital investments. Family highly private in business matters but remains prominent in Pittsburgh philanthropy; recent gifts to cancer research, children’s hospital.

name: Billionaires
