bio: Chairman of India&#39s largest media group Bennett, Coleman & Co, run by sons Samir and Vineet Jain. Businesses include newspapers such as the Times of India, magazines, FM radio stations, music stores and, in collaboration with Reuters, an English-language news television channel. In November 2006, Indu Jain filed an action in New Delhi against FORBES and FORBES ASIA for publishing her name on our lists, on privacy grounds. Her lawyers claimed in court papers that she “is not even a shareholder of Bennett Coleman & Co., Ltd.” Yet Bennett Coleman representatives had previously written FORBES in an e-mail: “However, if you still go ahead and publish your findings in recognition of your lawful right to write on us, you should list only the name of Mrs. Indu Jain. Names of junior members of the family should not be listed as owners/co-owners.” A prospectus issued in November 2005 identifies the sons as shareholders, along with others, consisting largely of holding companies. Her lawyers also offered orally in court that Bennett Coleman was worth much more than our estimate. Case is pending.

name: Billionaires
bio: Son of a trade unionist dropped out of Harvard Ph.D. program. Drifted for 6 years: drove New York City cab, studied at Juilliard. Used $3,000 MasterCard line to trade soybeans at age 31. Made $40,000, didn’t hedge; lost $23,000 hours later. Joined Commodities Corp., learned from veteran investor Michael Marcus. Founded hedge fund group Caxton Associates 1983. Flagship Caxton Global Investments has returned roughly 30% a year since on big bets on commodities, currencies. Juilliard chairman donated 140 handwritten musical pieces by Bach, Mozart, Beethoven to the school.

name: Billionaires
bio: With older brother Leonard (see), sons of beauty magnate Estée Lauder (d. 2004). Mother founded eponymous cosmetics company in 1946 peddling face cream created by chemist uncle. Company now controls almost half of U.S. premium cosmetics market. Newest “Azurée” line created by hotshot designer Tom Ford. Ronald recently paid $135 million for 1907 Klimt portrait; believed to be the largest sum ever paid for a painting.

name: Billionaires
bio: Father Lars founded L.E. Lundbergforetagen AB in 1944 as a construction company. Fredrik took over in 1981. Today the $ 2.8 billion (sales) diversified holding company concentrates on property management and investments; owns over 150 properties and projects in Sweden. Enjoys hunting and curling; in fact, was once a junior world champion of curling.

name: Billionaires
bio: With Thai business partner Chaleo Yoovidhya (see), created Red Bull energy drink and marketed it to young people using cheeky advertising and extreme sports sponsorships. Company also owns a Formula One team, and two soccer teams: Red Bull Salzburg and the New York Red Bulls, known as MetroStars before company bought it last March. A Taurus (the zodiac sign of the bull), Mateschitz owns 49% of the $3.4 billion (sales) company. Spending less time these days on daily operations. Keeps busy with his many other interests including a new construction company and Hangar-7, the event center situated on the grounds of Salzburg airport that houses his historic aircraft collection, the Flying Bulls. Also developing a luxury resort on Laucala, an island in Fiji that he owns.

name: Billionaires
bio: Son of a construction worker created tic-tac-toe computer program in high school; unbeatable game won him scholarship to MIT. Studied neurobiology, edited college newspaper. Founded International Data Group 1964; launched weekly paper Computerworld 1967. Hedged bets with magazines PC World, Macworld. Expanded into book publishing (bestselling Dummies series), trade shows, Internet sites. Now bets on Asia: IDG’s $1.4 billion venture arm has invested $100 million in Vietnam, $150 million in India; publishes 37 magazines and newspapers in China. Created McGovern Institute for brain research at alma mater. Personally delivers holiday bonuses to all U.S. employees.

name: Billionaires
bio: A former biochemistry student and soccer player, Milchan successfully transformed his family’s fledgling fertilizer company into a $125 million chemicals business. Later began bankrolling films for U.S. directors before going on to produce such classics as Pretty Woman, The War of the Roses and Fight Club. His New Regency Productions, jointly owned by Milchan, Rupert Murdoch’s News Corp. and James Packer’s Publishing & Broadcasting, is developing a television series for ABC based on its blockbuster film, Mr. & Mrs. Smith. Milchan’s daughter Alexandra is also a film producer; son Yariv is a senior executive at Regency; daughter Elinor is a New York photographer and artist.

name: Billionaires
bio: Repulsed by smelly feet, Moretti Polegato came up with an idea in 1994 to put tiny holes in shoe soles to release sweat. Initially tried to sell the concept to Nike, which turned him down. So started his own brand, Geox. Now publicly traded, the company sold 16 million pairs of shoes last year; even the Pope is a customer. Polegato enjoys his success: owns 2 Lamborghinis, a Ferrari 360 Modena Spider, 5 Arabian horses (one named Geox) and 6 antique Moto Guzzi motorcycles; makes his own eyeglasses. Before starting his shoe business ran family’s prestigious Villa Sandi winery.

name: Billionaires
bio: UCLA grad selling nation’s leading Spanish TV network, Univision, to consortium of private equity investors, including Haim Saban (see), for $13.7 billion; deal expected to close in March. Created Embassy Communications with Norman Lear (All in the Family); sold programming interests to Coca-Cola for $485 million. With partners bought Univision 1992 from Hallmark for $550 million. Became big player in Spanish radio 2003 with $3.5 billion purchase of Hispanic Broadcasting. Largest landholder in Malibu, Calif. shuns press; gives generously to politicians and charity.

name: Billionaires
bio: Son of a racehorse breeder in Pune (formerly Poona), in western India, he branched out in 1967 and began making anti-snake venom serums that were in short supply in the country. Privately owned Serum Institute, which he founded and runs, now sells a range of affordable vaccines for rabies, measles, hepatitis B, among other diseases, in 140 countries. Considering a public listing. Son Adar heads operations. Poonawalla collects custom-built limousines; also runs family’s Poonawalla Stud Farms, which has bred several derby winners, with younger brother Zavary.

name: Billionaires
bio: Hollywood’s most celebrated director struck gold again in 2005 with War of the Worlds; Tom Cruise flick grossed $590 million worldwide. Produced Clint Eastwood war films Flags of Our Fathers, Letters from Iwo Jima. Last year with fellow billionaire David Geffen (see) and partner Jeffrey Katzenberg sold DreamWorks live-action movie studio to Paramount for $1.5 billion; personally netted $175 million. Arizona-raised movie buff rejected by top film schools, then dropped out of Cal State Long Beach. Got start in entertainment as a director for Universal. First movie, Duel, aired on TV. Third effort, Jaws, launched a litany of blockbusters: E.T., Jurassic Park, Schindler’s List, Saving Private Ryan. Now tinkering with videogames, reality television. Up next: the fourth installment of Indiana Jones franchise with pal George Lucas (see) will be released May 2008.

name: Billionaires
bio: This former bank clerk used profits from a real estate deal to open a small bank in 1966. Today, Public Bank is the third-largest banking group in Malaysia with 12,800 employees and more than 250 branches. Mindful of competition from foreign banks entering the Malaysian market following deregulation in 2007, Teh has his sights on China. In May 2006 his group acquired a Hong Kong bank and announced plans to expand its operations in Shenzhen, Shenyang and Shanghai. Enjoys photography.

name: Billionaires
bio: Founder of Fubon Group may weigh in on big decisions but his 2 U.S.-educated sons Daniel and Richard now otherwise run the show. Older son Daniel chairs Fubon Financial, which has been expanding with recent acquisition of Taipeibank. This follows the purchase of a majority stake in Bahrain-based International Bank of Asia in 2003. Richard oversees family's telecom interests as chairman of Taiwan Mobile. Brothers speak frequently, sometimes in pajama-and-slippers meetings in one of their apartments, which are located in the same building.

name: Billionaires
bio: Trained physicist, he and four former IBM colleagues founded German software company SAP in 1972. Retired in 1998 but still sits on SAP’s board. Devotes most of his time to his Klaus Tschira Foundation, dedicated to pursuing whatever scientific research and cultural projects capture his imagination; for instance, sponsored a communications and computer camp for blind and vision- impaired youth.

name: Billionaires
bio: Inherited real estate and shipping outfit Wheelock & Co. from father-in-law Sir Y.K. Pao; chairs company. Ran failed bid to become Hong Kong’s first chief executive in 1997. Recently dispelled rumors he would run again. Heads Hong Kong Trade Development Council. Has invested alongside fellow Hong Kong tycoons in some of China’s recent high-profile public offerings.

name: Billionaires
bio: Born in Kazakhstan (Tselinograd), where his Ingush family had been deported after WWII. Later returned to Chechnya-Ingushetia. Later became president of state oil company Slavneft. In 2002 was dismissed before privatization but was able to return to big oil. Over 4 years Swiss trader Glencore helped him buy a number of small Russian oil firms which he united into Russian Oil company (RussNeft).

name: Billionaires
bio: Widow of Bronson Ingram oversees Nashville-based media-distribution conglomerate he created after inheriting his father’s oil-and-barge business. Today Ingram Industries is the nation’s largest distributor of books and magazines plus retains original barge outfit. Martha became company’s director of public affairs in 1979, chairman in 1995 after husband’s death. These days books and barges run by sons John and Orrin, respectively. Son David manages spinoff Ingram Entertainment. Prominent in Nashville society.

name: Billionaires
bio: Heads Samsung Group, Korea's largest industrial conglomerate, founded by his father, Lee Byung-Chull. At its heart is Samsung Electronics, accounting for close to a fifth of the nation's exports. Group also owns the country's largest insurance companies and has interests in real estate. Wife Hong Ra-Hee is the director of Leeum, Samsung Museum of Art, which opened in Seoul in October 2004. Lee owns the most expensive home in Seoul, according to the tax authority. Avid equestrian; also likes listening to classical music.

name: Billionaires
bio: Founded online shopping mall Rakuten a decade ago with 13 tenants. Now hosts more than 18,000 virtual stores selling products ranging from organic cucumbers to BMWs. Sales total $1.1 billion.  Suing a Japanese weekly magazine, for suggesting that he might be arrested like his rival Internet entrepreneur  Livedoor's Takafumi Horie.  Mikitani's Rakuten and Livedoor operated in the same high rise; Mikitani is now moving some departments to a new location 20 minutes away.

name: Billionaires
bio: Founded Future Electronics in 1968 and built it into the world's third-largest electronics distributor (products include semiconductors and electromechanical components); sector now in cyclical slump weighed down by rising inventories and margin pressures. Spirits still high: in December threw party for 6,000 employees and friends at the Bell Centre, Montreal's equivalent to Madison Square Garden, where Peter Cetera, former lead singer of the rock band Chicago, performed. Supports the Alcor Life Extension Foundation, which promotes cryonics, the science of freezing bodies with the intent to restore life when technology becomes available.

name: Billionaires
bio: Heads Hong Leong Group Malaysia, a multinational conglomerate comprising 14 listed companies involved in a range of industries including banking, financial services, semiconductor manufacturing, ceramic tile manufacturing and motorcycle distribution. Quek’s group sold OYL Industries, an air-conditioner manufacturer it had acquired in 1990, to Japan&#39s Daikin for $2.17 billion last May. In February the group’s Hong Kong-listed Guoco Group--through its investment arm BIL International--was awarded 16 casino licenses by U.K. authorities; BIL is expected to start introducing casinos in selected Thistle Hotels, the luxury hotel chain in the U.K. that the group also owns. Has a Barrister-at-Law from Middle Temple school in the U.K. Also has interests in his cousin Kwek Leng Beng’s (see) empire.

name: Billionaires
bio: This scion of a Middle Eastern banking family cut financial ties with his younger brother Joseph (see) in mid-2006. Joseph bought Moise’s stake in Banco Safra, Brazil’s 8th-largest bank, as well as his stakes in the brothers’ banking holdings elsewhere in the world, including in Luxembourg and New York, for an undisclosed sum. Moise is reported to still own shares in Brazilian pulp and paper maker Aracruz Celulose. Joseph and Moise’s deceased brother, Edmond Safra, had a separate multibillion-dollar banking fortune, part of which he left to his wife, Lily (see).

name: Billionaires
bio: Fourth-generation banker Schroder continues as a director of his family&#39s financial services company, Schroders, which celebrated its 200th anniversary in 2004. Shares wealth with sister Charmaine whose husband George Mallinckrodt is the bank’s current president. Shares slid 30% in past 12 months; group got kicked out of the FTSE 100. Schroder flies planes and breeds "middle white" pigs at his estate in Islay, Scotland.

name: Billionaires
bio: Son of Brooklyn developer borrowed heavily, built big, lived large, became billionaire during the 1980s. Nearly lost it all after 1990 realty crash. Stayed flamboyant, smartened up and embraced reality TV. Now other builders affix “Trump” to their condos and pay The Donald a generous cut of the gross; there are 8,200 such condos in development that will bear his name. Housing slowdown? Perhaps not a problem: large-scale Trump Organization projects in Chicago (92-story hotel-and-condo complex) and Las Vegas (with casino mogul Phillip Ruffin) are almost completely sold out. Now fighting with a New York Times reporter who claimed in a book that Trump was worth just a few hundred million dollars. Sued for defamation; judge recently ruled that $5 billion lawsuit can proceed. Constantly disputes FORBES’ net worth estimate: “I’m worth $6 billion.”

name: Billionaires
bio: Founded Sodexho as catering and river-cruise company in 1966. Today the company also supplies food to U.S. Marine Corps, handles security for the Alaska natural gas pipeline, manages gold mines in Chile, operates prisons and has a majority stake in the Lido, a topless Parisian cabaret that features ice dancers and trapeze artists. A new joint venture with Magic Johnson will provide dining, catering and groundskeeping to school and corporate cafeterias. Company’s stock has doubled since 2004 when 3 top executives were forced out, including Bellon’s son. Bellon himself stepped down as chief executive the following year but remains as chairman.

name: Billionaires
bio: Together with siblings Luciano, Giuliana and Gilberto (see all), formed Benetton Group in 1965. Now deputy chairman of the $2.3 billion (sales) clothing company that sells its United Colors of Benetton, Sisley, Playlife and Killer Loop brands at 5,000 stores in 120 countries. Is also vice president of Edizione, the family holding company that owns stakes in Autostrade, which is merging with Spain’s Albertis to become the world’s largest toll road company, and Autogrill restaurants, which serve 800 million customers each year on highways and in airports in 31 countries. Formerly headed production for Benetton Group.

name: Billionaires
bio: Together with siblings Luciano, Giuliana and Carlo (see all), formed Benetton Group in 1965. The $2.3 billion (sales) clothing company sells its United Colors of Benetton, Sisley, Playlife and Killer Loop brands at 5,000 stores in 120 countries. Chairs Edizione, the family holding company that owns stakes in Autostrade, which is merging with Spain’s Albertis to become the world’s largest toll road company, and Autogrill restaurants, which serve 800 million customers each year on highways and in airports in 31 countries. A sports enthusiast, Gilberto promotes Benetton&#39s sponsorships of rugby, basketball and volleyball. Through Fondazione Benetton, he created La Ghirada, an indoor-and-outdoor sports complex with beach volleyball, golf and swimming in Treviso, Italy.

name: Billionaires
bio: Together with siblings Luciano, Carlo and Gilberto, formed Benetton Group in 1965. The $2.3 billion (sales) clothing company  sells its United Colors of Benetton, Sisley, Playlife and Killer Loop brands at 5,000 stores in 120 countries. Is also director of Edizione, the family holding company that owns stakes in Autostrade, which is merging with Spain’s Albertis to become the world’s largest toll road company, and Autogrill restaurants, which serve 800 million customers each year on highways and in airports in 31 countries.  It was actually Giuliana who started the family&#39s fashion business, knitting sweaters that brother Luciano would then peddle by bicycle. Originally sold under the Tres Jolie label, before eventually renaming it Benetton.

name: Billionaires
bio: Together with siblings Carlo, Giuliana and Gilberto (see all), formed Benetton Group in 1965. Now chairman of the $2.3 billion (sales) clothing company, which sells its United Colors of Benetton, Sisley, Playlife and Killer Loop brands at 5,000 stores in 120 countries. The family also owns Autostrade, which is merging with Spain’s Albertis to become the world’s largest toll road company, and Autogrill restaurants, which serve 800 million customers each year on highways and in airports in 31 countries. Luciano ran Benetton Group for 40 years. Son Alessandro, a former Goldman Sachs analyst, is now co-vice president and a potential heir apparent, particularly after the recent departures of Benetton’s chief executive and chief financial officer, both non-family members.

name: Billionaires
bio: Polish immigrant married Johnson & Johnson heir John Seward Johnson (d. 1983). Basia inherited 36 million J&J shares, expansive Jasna Polana mansion in New Jersey. Converted mansion into exclusive tournament-level golf club, moved to Monaco. Former art history student famously parlayed world’s most expensive piece of furniture: bought Badminton Cabinet for $15.1 million 1990, sold eighteenth-century Italian piece for $36.7 million to Prince Hans-Adam II of Liechtenstein 2004. Through her foundation funds art projects in Poland.

name: Billionaires
bio: Former Enron president wisely left firm 1996, uncomfortable with “asset-light” strategy. Bought small pipeline business from Enron with college classmate William Morgan. In 2004 spent $150 million on pipelines and terminals from ConocoPhillips, ExxonMobil, Royal Dutch Shell. Bought Canadian company Terasen for $5.6 billion in 2005. Today Kinder Morgan operates more than 43,000 miles of pipeline and more than 150 terminals. Wants more: with management and investors, announced $22 billion buyout of company last May. Poster boy for “proper” executive compensation pays himself $1 a year and flies coach on company time. Avid fly fisherman.

name: Billionaires
bio: Son-in-law of ex-president Leonid Kuchma, used his Ph.D. in pipe design to found Interpipe in 1990, now one world&#39s largest producers of steel pipes. Owned Ukraine’s largest steel company Kryvorizhstal with fellow billionaire Rinat Akhmetov until it was reprivatized in 2005. Another threat by the government to renationalize his steel mill Nikopol fizzled; a case brought by rival Ihor Kolomoyskyy (see) in U.S. courts, which accused Pinchuk of looting Nikolpol, was settled and dismissed. Now plans to invest more than $1 billion from the sale of a bank into high-end hotels in Ukraine. Sponsored lunch with George Soros at Davos, produced a documentary with Steven Spielberg on Ukraine&#39s Babi Yar massacre during World War II and held an exhibition of American and Ukrainian artists at his contemporary art center in Kiev. Named person of the year with pal Akhmetov (see) by the Ukrainian Observer.

name: Billionaires
bio: With brother Steven (see), left father’s real estate firm 1979, founded Equity Group Holdings. Bought up small manufacturing companies: Chicago Pneumatic Tool, Western Pacific Industries. Purchased 25% stake in near-bankrupt REIT, combined with manufacturing units to create Danaher Corp. Acquired, revamped more than 3 dozen companies in 25 years. Mitchell: built museum to house personal art collection; open by appointment only.

name: Billionaires
bio: First fortune came from popular kids show Mighty Morphin Power Rangers. Sold to Disney 2001 with Fox Family Channel, joint venture with Rupert Murdoch’s Fox television; personally reaped $1.7 billion. Attempted to sell large stake in German broadcaster ProSiebenSat.1 Media to publisher Axel Springer last year; deal shot down by regulators. Now selling company to private equity giant KKR and Permira. Bought A. Jerrold Perenchio’s (see) Spanish-language broadcaster Univision for $13.7 billion with partners last year.

name: Billionaires
bio: Three decades ago, founded sensor manufacturer Keyence Corp in a seedy town in Western Japan.  Sales have doubled and profits nearly tripled in the past 5 years to $1.3 billion (sales). Remains chairman.

name: Billionaires
bio: High school grad and self-made industrialist worked in construction in Alaska before borrowing a bulldozer on credit and founding his own company in Montana. Grew with federal highway contracts. Rescued bankrupt Morrison Knudsen in 1996. Reorganized, renamed Washington Group International in 1998, lost in bankruptcy after dispute over later acquisition from Raytheon. Today investments include Montana regional railroad; largest tug and barge fleet in British Columbia; Butte copper mine, where he lowered costs by sidestepping union in favor of sharing profits with miners. Also seeded investment in Seaspan, fleet of 36 container ships on long-term contracts with China; took public 2005. Avid yachtsman spends time cruising in his 226-foot yacht, Attessa.

name: Billionaires
bio: Son of Montreal tobacco and candy wholesaler studied at Harvard. Cofounded Boston Properties 1970. Today real estate holdings include 120 commercial units including offices, hotels, retail. Also media: U.S. News & World Report, New York's Daily News.

name: Billionaires
bio: Onetime pharmacist sold family pharmaceutical business 1985; invested proceeds in several industries, from banking to textiles. Accumulated 10% stake of construction giant Sacyr Vallehermoso, of which he is a vice president. Often appears in tabloids alongside well-known politicians and members of Spanish artistic and cultural circles. Known for his valuable art collection; last June acquired Edgar Degas' "La sortie du bain," once owned by Penthouse founder Bob Guccione, for $12.8 million. Enthusiastic hunter; enjoys bullfights, soccer.

name: Billionaires
bio: With father Stephen (see), third- and fourth-generation heads of engineering juggernaut that built the Hoover Dam, Trans-Alaska Pipeline and Channel Tunnel. Revenues now exceed $18 billion; rapid growth recently with large rebuilding contracts in Iraq. Father and son believed to own 20% of company each. Recent high-profile projects include Washington State's Tacoma Narrows Bridge, building emergency housing in Louisiana after Katrina. Also erected China's largest petrochemical plant, natural gas facilities in Australia and Africa. Riley now chairman, CEO.

name: Billionaires
bio: With son Riley (see), third- and fourth-generation heads of engineering juggernaut that built the Hoover Dam, Trans-Alaska Pipeline and Channel Tunnel. Revenues now exceed $18 billion; rapid growth recently with large rebuilding contracts in Iraq. Father and son believed to own 20% of company each. Recent high-profile projects include Washington State's Tacoma Narrows Bridge, building emergency housing in Louisiana after Katrina. Also erected China's largest petrochemical plant, natural gas facilities in Australia and Africa. Riley now chairman, CEO.

name: Billionaires
bio: Cable guy founded network that became Home Box Office; traded stake with the old Time Inc. for a cable company with 1,500 Long Island customers in 1973. Bet became Cablevision. Took public 1986, stock up 400% since 1992 despite tough times following tech bubble. Sales now top $5 billion. Issued $10 special dividend last April; personally netted $580 million. Recently trying to take Cablevision private; board rejected $8.9 billion offer in January. Son James runs pro basketball’s New York Knicks, hockey’s Rangers.

name: Billionaires
bio: Harvard business school grad struck up friendship with Warren Buffett (see) in 1962. Early investor in Berkshire Hathaway; today owns 19,000 shares worth $2 billion. Founded investment advisory firm First Manhattan 1964; assets believed to exceed $10 billion. Joined Berkshire board of directors in 2003. Sits on board of American Museum of Natural History in New York.

name: Billionaires
bio: Once drove a tow truck. Now known for astute debt-financed purchases. Last year his Rank Group bought out and privatized Burns Philp foods and Carter Holt Harvey paper products for $3.3 billion. Soon after, sold pieces of each, like Uncle Tobys snacks and New Zealand forests. Recently agreed to pay $500 million for International Paper's beverage-packaging unit and bid $2 billion for SIG, a Swiss packaging company. Enjoys boating and water sports, particularly diving. Made headlines in January when he reportedly rescued 3 people and a dog from a burning boat off New Zealand's Waiheke Island.

name: Billionaires
bio: Amherst grad founded Continental Cablevision 1963 with former frat brother. Sold to the former U S West 1996 for $11 billion; Hostetter kept large stake. Renamed MediaOne, sold a second time to AT&T for $58 billion 1999. Also owns large chunk of publicly traded gas storage and transportation outfit Energy Transfer Equity. Large portion of fortune held in personal investment vehicle Pilot House Associates.

name: Billionaires
bio: Ann inherited big Wal-Mart stake from father James (Bud) Walton (d. 1995), who cofounded retail giant with brother Sam. Husband Stanley (see) made fortune as a real estate developer; built shopping centers anchored by Wal-Mart stores. Also owns 1 million acres of ranch land across the Midwest and Canada. Sports junkie owns stakes in pro football’s St. Louis Rams, basketball’s Denver Nuggets, hockey’s Colorado Avalanche, soccer’s Colorado Rapids. Last year bought Napa Valley winery Screaming Eagle; cult cab limits production to 600 cases a year. Bottles of first vintage (1992): $3,000.

name: Billionaires
bio: His tour outfit Globus & Cosmos was founded in 1928 by father, Antonio, with a single boat that ferried tourists around Lake Lugano where Sergio also owns a portfolio of lakeside property. Today Globus tours escort travelers seeking adventure in Europe, Africa and Asia. Real wealth comes from family's investments, largely in the bond market. Loves expensive toys: has a helicopter, a yacht (Lady Marina) and a $600,000 Mercedes Maybach.

name: Billionaires
bio: After father’s death 2 years ago became sole owner of candy company Storck GmbH, makers of Werther&#39s Original, Merci, Riesen, Toffifee and nimm2, among other well-known candies. Fourth generation of his family to run the $1.7 billion (sales) group. Company established the Stork Foundation in 1992 to preserve Germany’s endangered stork population.

name: Billionaires
bio: With brother Mitchell (see), left father’s real estate firm 1979, founded Equity Group Holdings. Bought up small manufacturing companies: Chicago Pneumatic Tool, Western Pacific Industries. Purchased 25% stake in near-bankrupt REIT, combined with manufacturing units to create Danaher Corp. Acquired, revamped more than 3 dozen companies in 25 years.

name: Billionaires
bio: Dyslexic fisherman reportedly told by schoolteacher he’d never amount to anything. Went to Seattle, where he sold fish off one boat and started what would become his fortune. Returned to Norway and built up fleet—and reputation as a ruthless corporate raider. Lived large with a giant yacht and own Boeing jet, but had nearly driven his shipping empire into the ground by 2003. Sold yacht, paid off debt and has turned around his businesses. Back on our list thanks to huge gains from holdings of his Aker conglomerate, which owns and operates shipyards, offshore drilling, seafood and shipping.

name: Billionaires
bio: Owns major stake in Saudi Islamic banking giant Al Rajhi bank. Three brothers (see) also hold substantial shares. Stock is down significantly to $30 from an astronomical high in 2006 of $70, but the bank continues to turn a solid profit thanks to increasing interest in Islamic finance. Other lines of business include building materials and agriculture.

name: Billionaires
bio: Third generation to run Verlagsgruppe Bauer, mass-media company founded by his grandfather 1875. The $2.2 billion (sales) group publishes everything from TV guides to special interest publications like Auto Zeitung (cars) and Kochen & Geniessen (cooking), to magazines like Neue Post and Das Neue Blatt. U.S. titles include First for Women, Woman's World and InTouch. Sells in 13 countries including Mexico, Russia and China.

name: Billionaires
bio: Secretive Chen delisted his Nan Fung Textiles 1989; invested in real estate. Later bought real estate including luxury properties, residential buildings, plus stake in Singapore billionaire Ng Teng Fong’s (see) Sino Land. Committed Buddhist.

name: Billionaires
bio: Gave up his orthopedic practice in 1956 to take over family's shoe business. Turned it into Europe's largest shoe retailer Deichmann-Schuhe GmbH. Also owns U.S. retail chains Rack Room Shoes and Off Broadway. Son Heinrich runs daily operations. Committed philanthropist, Deichmann regularly donates large sums to missionary and humanitarian organizations, including a program to help leprosy victims in India, which he visits annually.

name: Billionaires
bio: Heir to the Campbell Soup fortune once tried unsuccessfully to pressure Wyoming legislators to legalize game ranching for native and exotic life. Not much has been heard from him since he moved to Ireland in 1994, reportedly to avoid U.S. taxes. Sold his Campbell stake in 1996.

name: Billionaires
bio: Opened his first hotel 50 years ago at the age of 21 in Palma de Majorca. His Sol Meliá now has $1.5 billion in sales, with more than 350 hotels and resorts in 30 countries; has 20 in Cuba, also many locations in Latin America and Caribbean. Still runs the group with help from his 2 sons. Has received numerous awards in his career such as Tourism Personality of the Century. Avid golfer.

name: Billionaires
bio: Took over his family&#39s clothing shop in a ramshackle Tokyo neighborhood 5 decades ago. His Seven & I group is now Japan’s largest store operator with $33 billion in sales. It controls 7-Eleven convenience stores worldwide and an extensive network of retail chains at home. In a bid to tap China&#39s new, affluent consumers the retailer last year opened 20 stores in the world&#39s most populous nation. Retired, Ito remains the group’s honorary chairman.

name: Billionaires
bio: With first cousin George Roberts (see) partnered with fellow Bear Stearns mentor Jerome Kohlberg (see) founded buyout behemoth KKR 1976. Bought undervalued companies using debt, cleaned up balance sheets, sold for profits. Kohlberg retired 1987; averse to hostile takeovers. “Barbarians at the Gate” famous for 1989 $31 billion buyout of RJR Nabisco. More recently: Primedia, Toys “R” Us, SunGard Data Systems. Last year took Thomas Frist’s (see) HCA Corp. private with Bain Capital and Merrill Lynch Global Private Equity for $33 billion. Then last month completed $45 billion buyout of energy outfit TXU with Texas Pacific; deal believed to be the largest buyout in history. Bottom line: 11 funds have reaped $51 billion in profits for investors. Raised $5 billion on Amsterdam Stock Exchange for publicly traded limited partnership investing in western Europe. Kravis contributes to New York City Ballet.

name: Billionaires
bio: Started out as a field supervisor in the plantation industry. Now heads IOI Group, one of the world’s leading operators of palm oil plantations, refineries and related manufacturing activities. His Rotterdam refinery is the largest palm oil refinery in Europe. His plants produce specialty oils, metallic stearates and fats that are used in soaps, detergents, cosmetics and food additives. Is also a leading real estate developer in Malaysia: projects include townships, shopping malls and resorts. Provides scholarships and educations grants to needy students.

name: Billionaires
bio: One of only three winners of coveted Macau gaming license. Backdoor listing in 2005 transformed his sleepy construction materials supplier into the first gaming outfit traded on the Hong Kong stock exchange. Opened his $400 million Starworld Hotel & Casino in October 2006; now investing $800 million on Galaxy Mega Resort on desirable Cotai strip, set to open in 2008. Born in China, moved to Hong Kong at age 4. With only an elementary school education, started helping his grandmother run a store that sold food staples. By 1950 was buying construction equipment from Japan and reselling it to Southeast Asia. Owns hotels in the U.S.; real estate in China. His K. Wah Center in Shanghai has attracted such tenants as J.P. Morgan Partners, J.C. Penney.

name: Billionaires
bio: Politician&#39s son dabbled in family&#39s modest publishing business before launching Sun TV when India’s satellite television market opened up in the 1990s. Sun now owns 20  channels, 7 radio stations, newspapers and magazines. Company&#39s April listing made Maran, who owns 90%, a billionaire. Recently merged two broadcasters that he co-owns, into Sun. Brother Dayanidhi is minister for communications and IT.

name: Billionaires
bio: Forced out of McCain Foods&#39 day-to-day operations in the 1990s after a family feud; remains vice chairman and still has a one-third stake in the world’s largest producer of frozen french fries. Took over meat processor Maple Leaf Foods in 1995, where son Michael is chief. Stock off this year on the news of a meat recall and the shuttering of a Nova Scotia poultry plant. Donates to philanthropic causes like National Ballet School of Canada and National Gallery of Canada.

name: Billionaires
bio: Son of Greek immigrants studied petroleum engineering at Texas A&M, founded Mitchell Energy & Development 1946. Wildcatter struck big in north Texas gas fields, sold to Devon Energy 2001 for $3.5 billion. Proceeds invested in real estate: owns Bald Head Island in North Carolina, hotels in Galveston. Nature enthusiast donated $35 million to alma mater last year.

name: Billionaires
bio: Former jute trader, split from family and moved into banking, later infrastructure. Shot into limelight last year after winning hotly contested bid to modernize New Delhi airport and taking flagship GMR Infrastructure public. His 2 sons and son-in-law work in the group.

name: Billionaires
bio: With first cousin Henry Kravis (see), partnered with fellow Bear Stearns mentor Jerome Kohlberg (see) founded buyout behemoth KKR 1976. Bought undervalued companies using debt, cleaned up balance sheets, sold for profits. Kohlberg retired 1987; averse to hostile takeovers. “Barbarians at the Gate” famous for 1989 $31 billion buyout of RJR Nabisco. More recently: Primedia, Toys “R” Us, SunGard Data Systems. Last year took Thomas Frist’s (see) HCA Corp. private with Bain Capital and Merrill Lynch Global Private Equity for $33 billion. Then last month completed $45 billion buyout of energy outfit TXU with Texas Pacific; deal believed to be the largest buyout in history. Bottom line: 11 funds have reaped $51 billion in profits for investors. Raised $5 billion on Amsterdam Stock Exchange for publicly traded limited partnership investing in western Europe.

name: Billionaires
bio: Grandson of visionary oil baron John D. Rockefeller now working to give away his fortune. Last June pledged living endowment to Rockefeller University: $100 million after death and 5% of earnings on gift annually while alive. Chief concerns: education, genetics research. Grandfather turned $4,000 in oil refining into Standard Oil, oil and gas giant that fueled American industrial revolution. Company broken up in landmark antitrust case 1911. Father invested in real estate. David: banker, diplomat, philanthropist. Insect enthusiast has one of largest beetle collections in world: 160,000 specimens, 9,000 species.

name: Billionaires
bio: Studied at U of North Carolina, then Harvard Business School. Later salvaged father’s business, Bank of North Carolina, before it merged with NCNB in 1982 (now Bank of America). Today owns 32 million shares of BofA. Became a construction maven: bought drywallmaker National Gypsum 1995. Prefers to keep company private: “A family business has the luxury of thinking in 10-year cycles.” Former UNC president enjoys repairing grandfather clocks.

name: Billionaires
bio: Opened a small shoe store in Manila 60 years ago. Today controls a retail empire that includes 31 malls across Asia, including the 4.1-million-square-foot Mall of Asia, which boasts an Olympic-size skating rink. Still visits the mall every other day, often in his trademark Hawaiian shirts. Last year raised $525 million in the nation’s largest public offering for his conglomerate SM Investments. Has also been increasing his stake in banking and slowly opening malls in China. Aging entrepreneur still sits at the head of bi-weekly family board meetings but is largely handing over daily operations to his 6 kids.

name: Billionaires
bio: Patriarch of Ayala Corp., the oldest and largest conglomerate in the Philippines, founded in 1834. Interests in real estate, water and telecom, among other industries. Zobel de Ayala retired in April; son Jaime Augusto took over as chairman; other son Fernando became president. In addition to a career in which he headed a number of Philippine businesses--including Bank of the Philippine Islands--Zobel de Ayala’s public service record includes a stint as Philippine Ambassador to the Court of St. James and the Scandinavian countries from 1970 to 1975. Holds an architecture degree from Harvard.

name: Billionaires
bio: Mall developer famous for bringing snow skiing to the Dubai desert is expanding his preeminent retail brand, MAF Holding, across the region, from Egypt to Oman. Company's joint venture with French hypermarket chain Carrefour has created the fastest-growing grocery chain in the Gulf and brought in nearly $1.5 billion in sales last year alone. Next up: introducing his retail-centered lifestyle to Syria. Plans for a $2 billion shopping and residential complex outside Damascus were announced in December.

name: Billionaires
bio: Father, Perry (d. 2006), inherited family fortune created by oil baron uncle Sid Richardson 1959. Passed on to eldest son, Sid (see), 1968; other brother Robert (see) split that same year. Siblings diversified oil and gas portfolio with stakes in Disney (entertainment), John Wiley & Sons (publishing) and Human Genome Sciences (pharmaceuticals). Oil business flourished last year. Ed develops real estate.

name: Billionaires
bio: Private leveraged buyout titan forced into public eye last year after New York Post gossip columnist Jared Paul Stern allegedly tried to shake him down for $100,000 (plus $10,000 a month) in exchange for favorable coverage. Burkle worked with FBI to tape Stern soliciting the bribe; U.S. Attorney’s office now says it will not press charges. Stern threatening to sue. Son of a grocery store manager founded investment company Yucaipa 1986; made fortune buying and selling supermarket chains Fred Meyer, Jurgensen’s, Ralph’s. Internal rate of return from 1985 to 2003: 43% a year. Today owns stakes in Sean (P. Diddy) Combs’ Sean John clothing line; Pathmark grocery stores. Now bidding for Tribune newspaper company with fellow Los Angeles billionaire Eli Broad (see). Democratic fundraiser a close friend of Bill Clinton; former President calls Burkle’s 757 private jet “Ron Air.”

name: Billionaires
bio: Born in Oregon, raised in San Francisco Bay Area. Played clarinet as child; became fascinated by reed vibrations. Began working at Ampex Corp. while high school sophomore; played integral role in developing company&#39s early videotape recording system.  Earned Cambridge Ph.D. in electrical engineering before taking fellowships with British Atomic Energy Commission, Unesco. Founded Dolby Laboratories in London 1965, relocated to San Francisco 1976. Made fortune with audio-processing systems that eliminate hiss and other background noise. Dolby sound technology now the industry standard for movies, stereo equipment. First integration: Dolby A-type noise reduction used on premixes and masters to 1971 cult classic A Clockwork Orange; first movie to make use of Dolby Stereo’s surround sound was 1976 musical A Star is Born; first blockbusters to use Dolby Stereo were Close Encounters of the Third Kind and Star Wars 1977. Took public 2005; shares up 85% since January 2006. With wife donated $16 million for a new stem cell research center at UCSF.

name: Billionaires
bio: Longtime ally of Silvio Berlusconi (see), cofounded financial services group Mediolanum SpA with Berlusconi’s Fininvest Group in 1982. Still runs the group, whose companies provide investment advice, online banking, life insurance and real estate loans. Has also invested alongside Berlusconi in MolMed, a medical biotech company that is developing cancer therapies; has a stake in Caffaro Biofuel. Enjoys bicycling.

name: Billionaires
bio: Met partner Jerry Yang (see) at Stanford grad school, turned Internet directory project into popular Web portal Yahoo. Put Ph.D. on hold to work full-time. Took public 1996. Filo: involved in technical operations. Both billionaires said to still wear sneakers, fly coach. Former Warner Bros. boss Terry Semel lords over day-to-day operations.

name: Billionaires
bio: Memphis-born hedge fund manager studied economics at U. of Virginia. Made a fortune trading cotton on Wall Street. Founded Tudor Investment 1980. Predicted 1987 market crash; returned 126% net of fees that year. “You adapt, evolve, compete or die.” Now bullish on Asia, especially Japan. Avid pheasant hunter, bass fisherman owns property in Florida Keys, Zimbabwe. Founded New York City’s poverty-fighting Robin Hood Foundation.

name: Billionaires
bio: Met partner Gary Burrell (see) as an engineer at AlliedSignal; struck out on own to make products based on newfangled Global Positioning System. Founded navigation device maker Garmin 1989; U.S. Army first customer, during Gulf war. Expanded to devices for boats, planes, hikers. Now focused on R&D; developing 60 new products a year. Kao donated $17.5 million to alma mater, U. of Tennessee for science and engineering.

name: Billionaires
bio: Born in London's East End, Lewis made initial wealth expanding family's catering business. Gradually moved into currency trading late 1970s; still an active trader today. Also main investor in Tavistock Group, which has interests in more than 100 companies including Simply Self Storage, which claims to be largest privately held storage company in U.S. Has homes all over the world including one at Lyford Cay and another at Isleworth, an Orlando golf community he bought out of receivership 1990s. Developing 6,700-acre community, Lake Nona, near Orlando, and resort in the Bahamas, Albany Golf & Beach, with friends Tiger Woods and Ernie Els.

name: Billionaires
bio: Oklahoma native riding high on rising price of oil: personally netted more than $1 billion in 2005 on big gains in oil and gas. Fortune faltering slightly as oil prices fall. Studied geology at Oklahoma State; graduated 1951. Worked for Phillips Petroleum for 3 years before striking out on own. Founded Mesa Petroleum 1956 with $2,500. Produced plenty of oil and gas, lots of debt. Sold to Richard Rainwater (see), then made name with hostile takeovers of Gulf, Phillips, Unocal. These days runs investment firm BP Capital: bets on crude oil, natural gas, Canadian tar sands. Also trying to capitalize on lucrative water rights in Texas panhandle. Staple on Republican giving circuit; horse lover. Recently donated $165 million to alma mater’s athletics program; offered to invest the gift for free.

name: Billionaires
bio: Cheerful Stanford business grad got start managing Bass family’s $50 million portfolio in 1970; lost money first 2 years. Acquired large stake in Disney 1984; went solo 2 years later. Cofounded Columbia Hospital 1987, merged with Hospital Corporation of America 1994. Made fortune on oil bets: ConocoPhillips, Chevron, EnCana. Now worried global warming will have dire impact on environment, world economy. “I just think that we’re in the world of expensive energy for years to come.” Wife, Darla Moore, self-made millionaire. “We’ve been married 16 years and our net worth is up six- or sevenfold. It’s not a coincidence.”

name: Billionaires
bio: Nephew of late Forbes 400 member Max Fisher (d. 2005) started out as tax lawyer. Founded developer Related 1972; initially focused on building, financing low-income housing. Branched into riskier luxury buildings; nearly went bankrupt early 1990s. Recovered. Has developed more than $15 billion worth of property across the country including NYC’s Time Warner Center; Ross lives, works in the building, takes elevator from his penthouse to his corner office. Latest project: with Vornado’s Steven Roth (see), $7 billion reconstruction of New York’s Madison Square Garden and Penn Station. Recently purchased Equinox Fitness Clubs, integrating workout centers into new developments. “This is a great time to be in real estate. This is the 15 seconds of sun.” Still finances affordable housing via publicly traded Charter Mac. Donated $100 million to alma mater University of Michigan business school in 2004.

name: Billionaires
bio: Minority partner in Russian oil tycoon Roman Abramovich’s (see) Millhouse Capital. Company sold stake in oil giant Sibneft to Russian state-owned gas monopoly Gazprom for $13.1 billion last October. Duo founded oil trading outfit Runicom early 1990s. Took control of Sibneft 1995; this summer agreed to buy 41% of Evraz, Russia’s largest steelmaker. Other investments: Russian meat processor, Moscow real estate. Abramovich recently gave Shvidler his yacht; Le Grand Bleu (The Big Blue) came complete with 65-man crew, helicopter, aquarium, speedboat.

name: Billionaires
bio: Grandchild of Homer Stryker (d. 1980), surgeon who invented mobile hospital bed, founded medical supply company Stryker Corp. When son, Lee, died in plane crash 1976, hired John Brown (see) to run firm; deployed new sales force, cut costs. Public 1979. Third generation controls 30% of company. Ronda: only family member to sit on board.

name: Billionaires
bio: Took his Peel Holdings private in 2004. In 2005 led the group's $1.3 billion takeover of Mersey Docks & Harbour Co. in a bid to revitalize the Liverpool waterfront. This year Deutsche Bank's property arm paid $600 million for 49% stake. Group's other holdings include Manchester's Trafford Centre (UK's largest shopping center), investment properties, airports and ports. Also owns stake in Britain's largest coal mining company, UK Coal. An environmentalist, Whittaker won government approval to set up a wind farm near Rochdale in the Greater Manchester area. Owns Billown Mansion on the Isle of Man.

name: Billionaires
bio: Husband and wife founded Mediterranean Shipping Co. in 1970 as a small ship operator. Today MSC is the world's second-largest container shipper with 310 container vessels. The company's cruise ship arm, MSC Cruises, boasts authentic Italian cuisine, an Italian crew and ship christenings by cinema legend Sophia Loren.

name: Billionaires
bio: Along with brother, Edgar Sr., inherited the Seagram spirits empire that was built up by their father, Sam, and sold to Vivendi in 2000. Lately Charles is focusing on Jewish charities. Helped found Birthright Israel, which sends Jewish youths from North America on educational tours of Israel. Through his foundation underwrites New York Jewish Music & Heritage Festival. Last year started the Andy Prize in memory of his late wife, Andrea, who was killed by a taxi while walking their dog near their Manhattan apartment. The prize will be awarded annually to an Israeli decorative artist for excellence in ceramics, jewelry, textile or glass.

name: Billionaires
bio: Youngest of four brothers, Dhanin was just 25 when he took over the family's small seed shop. Transformed it into one of the world's largest suppliers of animal feed. Then successfully branched into retail, telecom and other businesses. The group uses a lotus flower as its Buddhist symbol of commitment, effort and accomplishment. In spare time, enjoys breeding Thai chickens; bankrolls a cockfighting arena but only with chickens wearing small gloves to prevent serious injuries.

name: Billionaires
bio: Daughter of a Guangdong Province army officer and eldest of eight children. A finance job at a foreign paper-products trading company gave her the idea to start her own business. In 1985 she moved to Hong Kong and, with $4,000 in savings, set up a company importing waste paper. Five years later she and her husband, a Taiwan-born Brazilian national, trained as a dentist, traveled to California to open a paper recycler that would ship its output to China. In 1995 she returned to China and, with her husband and brother, started paper manufacturer Nine Dragons (whose name implies ?highest fortune?), of which she is chairman. It went public in March 2006; now all three are billionaires. Hopes the business will stay in the family for ?100 years.

name: Billionaires
bio: Became publicly known only in 2005 when steel giant Evraz Group listed on the London Stock Exchange; Frolov, who is responsible for all of Evraz's operations, turned out to own the second-largest stake. In 2006 sold a part of his holdings to Roman Abramovich, now the largest shareholder of Evraz. Prior to joining Evraz, worked as a research fellow at the I.V. Kurchatov Institute of Atomic Energy. Graduated from the Moscow Institute of Physics & Technology.

name: Billionaires
bio: With brother William, heads Li & Fung, $6 billion (sales) global outsourcing giant that supplies clothes and accessories to such retailers as Disney and Bed, Bath & Beyond. Links American and European consumers to factories in 40 countries. Grandfather Fung Pakliu started company a century ago in Guangzhou with partner Li To-ming; duo sold porcelain, antiques. Father Fung Hon-chu ran companies while brothers studied business in America; they returned to take helm 1970s. Victor now chairman.

name: Billionaires
bio: With brother Victor (see), heads Li & Fung, the $7.2 billion (sales) global outsourcing giant that supplies clothes and accessories to such retailers as Disney and Bed Bath & Beyond. Now has license to run Toys “R” Us stores in Hong Kong. Links American and European consumers to factories in 40 countries. Grandfather Fung Pakliu started the company a century ago with partner Li To-ming; duo sold porcelain, antiques. Father Fung Hon-chu ran it while brothers studied business in U.S.; they returned to take helm 1970s.  William is managing director, Victor chairman. To commemorate the company’s centenary anniversary, set up a scholarship program via the Li & Fung Foundation.

name: Billionaires
bio: In the 1990s created Russia&#39s largest coal-trading company, Rosuglesbyt. Later invested in cement, purchasing the Stern Cement plants and the cement business of Elena Baturina’s Inteko. Now his Eurocement Group, with 16 plants, is the country&#39s largest producer, with 40% of the market (up to 80% in some regions). After the purchase of the Inteko plants was able to nearly double cement prices, dramatically improving profits. Russia’s antimonopoly authority tried to sue Eurocement but failed to prove that the price hike was illegal.

name: Billionaires
bio: Widow of steel baron Om Prakash Jindal, who died in a helicopter crash two years ago. Each of her 4 sons runs parts of the family's $4 billion (sales) Jindal group, which also has interests in power, industrial gases and ports. She remains chairperson of several group companies.

name: Billionaires
bio: Chairman of Turkcell mobile phone company. Fell off the billionaires list in 2003 due to enormous debt load at 2 of his banks, Pamukbank and Yapi Kredi. He returned to the list in 2006 after paying off more than $3 billion of the debt. In November 2006 sold his Yapi Kredi Bank to Koc Group. His Genel Energy recently found an oil reserve in Northern Iraq.

name: Billionaires
bio: Born in Taiwan; got a degree in dental surgery from the University of Santa Amaro in Brazil in 1983.  Met his wife Yan Cheung in Hong Kong. Moved with her to the U.S. in 1990 where they set up a paper recycling business. Later returned to China and started paper manufacturer Nine Dragons with his wife and brother-in-law. Company went public March 2006. Flags from China, the United States and Brazil hang outside their corporate headquarters.

name: Billionaires
bio: Portland, Ore. native sold magazines, lemonade during Depression. Studied physics at UCLA. Founded and sold aerospace companies Spectrolab and Heliotek 1960s; outfits made solar cells, spotlights. Funded some of world’s most innovative biomedical companies: Pacesetter Systems (rechargeable pacemakers), MiniMed (insulin pumps), Advanced Bionics (neural stimulation). Sold parts to Medtronic for $4.2 billion in 2001. Up next: inhaled insulin, prosthetic retinas. Octogenarian plans to endow $100 million to biomedical institutes at a dozen universities.

name: Billionaires
bio: Yale economics student wrote senior thesis on improving overnight delivery services using integrated network of planes and trucks. Stint in Vietnam, then worked as crop-dusting pilot. Bought small stake in Arkansas aviation firm. With venture capital, small inheritance, launched Federal Express 1973. FedEx the world’s biggest overnight freight service; delivers more than 6 million shipments a day to 220 countries and territories. Company owns Kinko’s. New cargo hub in Guangzhou, China under construction.

name: Billionaires
bio: Former Palo Alto residential broker developed Silicon Valley commercial real estate 1960s with partner Carl Berg (see). Later built up portfolio erecting campuses for tech titans Apple and Yahoo. Today owns 9.5 million square feet of commercial space, 8,000 residential units; another 340 acres ready for development. Selling off San Jose properties, reinvesting in apartments in Washington State, Oregon, other parts of California.

name: Billionaires
bio: Founded and runs Essel group, with interests in media, packaging, amusement parks, online lottery and cable networks. Restructured television empire into 3 companies, now separately listed. Launched Dishtv, a direct-to-home service, which competes with Tata Sky, Tata group’s joint venture with Star TV. Plans to list Dishtv.

name: Billionaires
bio: Dot-com impresario turned basketball bad boy now creating a small entertainment empire. Pittsburgh native bartended in Dallas before creating systems-integration firm MicroSolutions; sold in 1990 for $6 million. Started Broadcast.com with Indiana University pal Todd Wagner (see) 1995. Sold to Yahoo 5 years later for $5.7 billion in stock, sold out before Internet bust. Used windfall to buy pro basketball’s Dallas Mavericks. Team lost last year’s NBA finals to Micky Arison’s (see) Miami Heat. With Wagner owns stakes in HDNet, Magnolia Pictures, 2929 Entertainment. Duo sold syndicator Rysher Entertainment (Hogan’s Heroes, Nash Bridges) to Qualia Capital last year.

name: Billionaires
bio: Son of a carpenter. Founded Sonae GSPS, maker of decorative laminates, in 1959. Later diversified into supermarkets, eventually becoming Portugal’s biggest retailer through his Modelo Continente superstores and supermarket. Holds 53% stake in the now $8.4 billion (sales) company, which today has interests in tourism, car parks, real estate, shopping centers, a radio station, a newspaper and a maker of wood panels. Sons Nuno and Paulo and daughter Claudia work at the company.

name: Billionaires
bio: Profits at Fukuda's consumer finance company, Aiful, slumped after financial regulators capped interest rates at 20% down from 29% in 2006. Net income last business year slipped 15% to $570 million. The government action against Aiful and rival consumer loan companies came after incidents in which lenders harassed debtors. Regulators also ordered Aiful to suspend lending at some branches for up to 25 days as punishment.

name: Billionaires
bio: With sisters, inherited Getty Oil from oil baron father, J. Paul Getty Sr. (d. 1976). Spent 4 years in business, then sold to Texaco in 1986 for $10 billion. Now renaissance man: spends days composing music; choral works have been performed by San Francisco Symphony. Invests in finance, wine. Founded ReFlow; outfit buys, holds illiquid shares from mutual funds until they find new buyers. Financed wine, restaurant business under PlumpJack label. Preserves $180-a-bottle wine with screw-top caps; insists science says they’re better than cork.

name: Billionaires
bio: The Saudi-born Lebanese parliamentary majority leader is pressing for a peace deal in Beirut and for an international tribunal on the slaying of his father, prime minister Rafik Hariri. Also general manager of Saudi Oger, the family’s $8 billion holding company. In early 2007 paid visits to pal Jacques Chirac, president of France, who pledged political and economic support for Lebanon, and to Russian Security Council Secretary Igor Ivanov. When the family’s leading pol and Georgetown grad isn’t working, he likes to scuba dive and draw on Cuban cigars.

name: Billionaires
bio: With mother Ingeburg, 3 brothers (Joachim, Michael and Wolfgang) and sister Daniela (see all), inherited a fortune from his father, coffee magnate Max Herz. A nasty family feud led him and his sister Daniela to sell their combined 40% stake in German consumer goods group Tchibo Holding to their mother and 3 brothers for an estimated $5 billion in August 2003. Now he and his sister own private equity firm Mayfair GmbH, through which they hold 25% stake in German sportswear manufacturer, Puma AG. Raises horses at his stud farm; races his yacht, All Smoke.

name: Billionaires
bio: Father, James (Bud) Walton, and his brother, Sam, ran a handful of small five-and-dime stores in Arkansas and Missouri. Brothers built first Wal-Mart in Rogers, Ark. 1962. Nancy inherited large stake after Bud’s death 1995. Sold pro hockey’s St. Louis Blues in June. Founder New York City’s Cedar Lake Ensemble: contemporary ballet troupe envy of starving artists; offers 52-week contracts, vacation pay. In 2005 U. of Missouri dropped daughter Paige’s name from new basketball arena; she was said to have paid her USC roommate $20,000 to do her homework.

name: Billionaires
bio: Grandfather John T. Dorrance, inventor of condensed-soup process, bought out his uncle’s Campbell Preserve Company in 1914. Passed company on to son, 3 daughters. Third generation still owns about half the company; Dorrance (see), Malone, Weber (see) sit on board but not actively involved day to day. Interests include raising, riding horses.

name: Billionaires
bio: Former Lebanese Prime Minister founded telecom company Investcom with brother (see) at height of Lebanon&#39s civil war in 1982. Sold company in June 2006 to South Africa&#39s MTN Group for $5.5 billion. A popular and moderate figure in Lebanese politics, Mikati served as Lebanon’s minister of public works before his brief stint as prime minister in 2005. Lives in Beirut with his wife, a professor of English at American University of Beirut.

name: Billionaires
bio: Founded telecom company Investcom with brother (see) at height of the Lebanese civil war in 1982. Company profited from tapping underpenetrated cellular markets in the Middle East and sub-Saharan Africa. Made his fortune when South Africa's MTN Group bought Investcom in early 2006 for a record $5.5 billion. Started career in construction industry in the United Arab Emirates in the late 1960s. Used his training as a civil engineer to help found Arabian Construction Company in Abu Dhabi. Sold company in 1992 to focus on growing telecom sector.

name: Billionaires
bio: Nuclear engineer turned his family&#39s ailing Naples drug wholesaler into Alliance UniChem, second-largest drug wholesaler in Europe. The group was bought by U.K. pharmacy chain Boots last year for $12 billion. Pessina chairs the new entity, Alliance Boots, which has 3,000 stores and is Europe’s biggest buyer of generic medicines. Known to own a yacht and collect art.

name: Billionaires
bio: Grandchild of A.N. Pritzker (d. 1986), who with sons Jay (d. 1999) and Robert created industrial conglomerate Marmon (2005 sales: $7 billion) and hotel giant Hyatt (215 hotels worldwide). In 2001 plans collapsed to pass control of empire to Jay&#39s son Thomas, cousin Nicholas and niece Penny; family agreed to split pot 11 ways. Deal enraged Robert’s youngest kids, Liesel and Matthew; duo filed suit, settled for $500 million each. Dynastic carve-up to include Hyatt public offering or sale by 2011. Tentative so far. Just one windfall: tobacco outfit Conwood sold for $3.5 billion to R.J. Reynolds April. Thomas: chief executive of Pritzker Organization holding company. Family oversight role waning.

name: Billionaires
bio: Newspaper entrepreneur bought shares in chemical company Dwory; funded expansion with debt, taking advantage of low interest rates. Diversified into ceramic tiles, wood floors and real estate. Gave up any management roles 2 years ago but is still an active investor on Warsaw Stock Exchange. Pulled out of launching a newspaper last year because of intense competition. Avid race car driver, races 20 days a year.

name: Billionaires
bio: Ethnic Chinese entrepreneur has amassed a mostly private fortune that includes international carrier Philippine Airlines as well as the nation's largest cigarette company, Fortune Tobacco. Also owns a portfolio of real estate in Hong Kong. Among his many posts, he is the Philippines' Honorary Consul to Romania. Hobbies include flying helicopters and learning Chinese history; paid a professor from China to move to Manila to be his private tutor.

name: Billionaires
bio: Minnesota farm boy turned 6-figure investment into $1.75 billion (sales) printing empire. Worked way though college at print shop; persuaded retiring owner to sell for $2 million over 10 years. Paid off debt early, built Taylor Corp. into printing monster: invitations, stationery, magazines. Retired CEO owns 99%; still chairman. Says he’s on the lookout for acquisitions in the coming year. Also developing small agribusiness on his Iowa, Minnesota farmland: chickens, liquefied eggs. “The chicken business is an old business. I’m bringing new technology to it.” Former Republican state senator also owns pro basketball’s Minnesota Timberwolves.

name: Billionaires
bio: Norwegian real estate magnate bought his first building in 1951 and opened his first restaurant in 1966. Now his $740 million (sales) Olav Thon Gruppen owns 360 properties in Norway and 18 abroad. The portfolio includes shopping malls (60 of them), office buildings, retail stores, hotels (6,150 rooms) and several Oslo restaurants and pubs. Even makes raw ingredients for soap and cosmetics.

name: Billionaires
bio: Chief of Meriton Apartments made his fortune building low-cost housing. In recent years boosted his rental business. Born in China to Russian parents who fled the country during the Bolshevik Revolution. Learned about real estate development as a child visiting his father, a builder, at work sites in Tianjin, China; immigrated to Australia at age 28. Owns 3 Bentleys; on alternate days his license plates read HOT1 and HOT2 (for his initials) and OSCAR1 (his middle name).

name: Billionaires
bio: Fourth-generation banker became head of Banco Santander 1986. Built it into Santander Central Hispano, world&#39s tenth-largest bank by assets. Bought Philadelphia’s Sovereign Bank in 2006 . Pesky legal problems appear over for Botín, who was acquitted in 2005 of charges of criminal misappropriation of bank funds to pay off 2 departed bank officials. In December 2006 courts dropped tax fraud case against him and several former bank executives connected to the bank&#39s 1994 purchase of Banesto,  its retail branch now run by daughter and heir apparent, Ana Botín. Enjoys golf, hunting and fishing.

name: Billionaires
bio: Third-generation grocer caters to yuppie tastes. High-end Central Market stores shun big brands like Coca-Cola and General Mills in favor of organic foods, wine and cheese, in-store cafes. Founded in 1905 by grandmother originally to support sick husband, 3 children in Kerrville, Tex. Today sales from more than 300 stores in Texas and Mexico top $11.5 billion. Expanding: new HEB Plus stores sell a higher mix of nonfood products to take on Wal-Mart Supercenters. Two nephews now in charge: Howard III leads Mexican operation, Stephen Dallas. Older brother, Howard, runs Butt Foundation; used to preach with Billy Graham.

name: Billionaires
bio: Former auto repair shop owner and Michelin engineer entered cell phone business in 1987. Sold just 26 phones in his first 8 months from his store in hardscrabble Stoke-on-Trent. Caudwell Group sales reached $3.6 billion in 2005. In September 2006 Caudwell sold his 85% stake in the group for $2.3 billion. Avid sportsman used to bike 14 miles to work; now plans to sail the world and concentrate on his charity for disadvantaged and sick children.

name: Billionaires
bio: "Little Chung," as he is nicknamed, took reins of Hyundai Motor from late father, Hyundai founder Chung Ju-Yung, in 1999 and helped transform it into a respected automaker. Now he and the company are embroiled in scandal: Chung was sentenced in February to 3 years in prison for embezzling corporate funds. Remains chairman while his case is appealed. He was first arrested in April 2006 and spent 2 months in jail before being released on bail. In the meantime, Hyundai is struggling with labor unrest at home.

name: Billionaires
bio: After selling TV-production giant Endemol, the brain behind global hit Big Brother returned in full creative force in 2005. Launched a new television channel, Talpa TV, to stunning success in the Netherlands. In its first months Talpa claimed 10% of coveted youth market and secured rights to screen the Dutch premier soccer league. But viewership has fallen off since then, and the business is burning cash. After reality-TV pioneer’s investment firm bought back small stake in Endemol early this year, rumors started flying he wanted it all.

name: Billionaires
bio: Grandfather John T. Dorrance, inventor of condensed-soup process, bought out his uncle’s Campbell Preserve Company in 1914. Passed company on to son, 3 daughters. Third generation still owns about half the company. Dorrance recently purchased $18 million plot of land in Hawaii.

name: Billionaires
bio: Merged his staffing company, French Ecco, with Klaus Jacobs’ Swiss Adia in 1996 to create Adecco. Now one of the world’s largest employment agencies with $24 billion in sales. Per Swiss law, stepped down as cochairman of Adecco in 2005 at age 70 and is now honorary president. Foriel-Destezet remains busy on the boards of holding company Akila Finance and security systems provider Securitas. Lives as a tax-exile in London.

name: Billionaires
bio: Following footsteps of father, the slain Lebanese prime minister Rafik Hariri, into Middle East real estate development, from his Geneva base. Bahaa’s Horizon Development is planning a $5 billion minicity for mixed use in the Jordanian port of Aqaba on the Red Sea. Also personally adopted 6 bridges to reconstruct in Lebanon following last summer’s Israel-Hezbollah conflict. Deferred to relatives’ wishes in late 2006 to delay the initial public offering of Oger Telecom, which last year bought Turk Telekom for $6.5 billion. Chairs two soccer clubs in Lebanon.

name: Billionaires
bio: With mother, Ingeburg, and 4 brothers, Günter, Joachim, Michael and Wolfgang (see all), inherited a fortune from her father, coffee magnate Max Herz. A nasty family feud led her and her older brother Günter to sell their combined 40% stake in German consumer goods group Tchibo Holding to their mother and other 3 brothers and mother for estimated $5 billion in August 2003. Now she and her brother own private equity firm Mayfair GmbH, through which they hold 25% stake in German sportswear manufacturer Puma AG.

name: Billionaires
bio: Raised during Depression: became farmer, then land-use lawyer. Planted vines north of San Francisco 1970s, released first Kendall-Jackson wine 1982. Today Jackson Family Wines produces more than 5 million high-end cases a year from 14,000 acres. Thought about retiring 2000; put K-J up for sale, changed his mind. Big coup this August: won auction to buy 3 California wineries out of bankruptcy for $96 million. Now getting into horse racing. Over past 3 years has spent $200 million on Thoroughbred breeding; operation includes nearly 200 horses (12 already racing) and 4 farms. Generous: blew $155,000 for a 2006 Maserati at recent charity auction. “I didn’t set out to buy it. But it’s all for a good cause.”

name: Billionaires
bio: Runs Kotak Mahindra Bank, which he cofounded along with tractor tycoon Anand Mahindra as finance firm in 1985. Secured much-prized banking license and converted into bank in 2003. Last year ended 14-year partnership with Goldman Sachs by acquiring the American firm’s 25% stake in 2 subsidiaries for $72 million.

name: Billionaires
bio: Chief executive of Fimalac, parent of Fitch Ratings, which operates in 50 countries. Founded the company in 1991 after a varied career. Started a teen magazine in 1961 at age 21. Sold it off a few years later. Attended elite Ecole Nationale d’Administration, then moved into banking and finance. Eventually landed at L’Oréal, where he spent 15 years, rising up to group executive vice president of finance. Now a board member at L’Oréal and Renault. A theater buff, he has helped fund renovations for the Theatre du Rond Point in Paris. Is also on the board of the American Friends of the Louvre.

name: Billionaires
bio: Cofounded do-it-yourself home improvement giant Home Depot with partner, Arthur Blank (see), in 1978 after being fired from now defunct Handy Dan Home Improvement Center. Took public 3 years later. Revolutionized hardware store concept with inventory stacked to ceilings; caters to both professional contractors and regular Joes. Via Marcus Foundation, funded $250 million aquarium in hometown Atlanta.

name: Billionaires
bio: With brother J.W. Jr. (see), sons of J.W. Marriott Sr. (d. 1985). Dad started empire with root beer stand in Washington, D.C. in 1927; Hot Shoppes later became regional chain. Opened first hotel 1957. J.W. Jr. appointed president 1964; exited restaurant business 25 years later. Brothers split company amid bondholder protest 1993. Richard controls hotel ownership operation (newly named Host Hotels & Resorts); J.W. heads franchise and property management outfit (Marriott International). Active Mormons fund education, also Bridges From School to Work Program.

name: Billionaires
bio: Met partner Henry Samueli (see) at TRW. Designed high-speed telecom chips in Nicholas’ spare bedroom. Founded Broadcom in 1991; took public 7 years later. Nicholas: former workaholic chief exec unexpectedly quit in 2003 to spend time with family. Supports performing arts, education, science via Nicholas Foundation.

name: Billionaires
bio: Founder of Aruze, a maker of pachinko and slot machines. Business has been faltering for past three years, with no new hits and customers switching to rivals. To raise money, company sold its stake in American billionaire Steve Wynn’s Macau casino for $900 million.

name: Billionaires
bio: Star stock car driver retired from racing 1965 at age 28. Worked for Alcoa; left, bought Chevy dealership. Started Penske Corp. 1969: truck leasing, truck parts manufacturer, diesel engine maker. Also controls more than 280 dealerships in U.S. and Europe as chairman of United Auto Group, nation’s second-largest auto dealer. Owns Indy, Nascar and American Le Mans racecar teams; part-owner of Deer Valley ski resort in Utah. Inked deal to sell Smart cars in U.S. for DaimlerChrysler.

name: Billionaires
bio: After 10 years as Minister for Science & Innovation, Lord Sainsbury resigned in November 2006. The former politician owes his wealth to his stake in his family's iconic Sainsbury's grocery business. His fortune, which had been held in a blind trust while he was in government, was just released. The company has lately been the subject of increased takeover speculation from buyout groups as investors and rivals hope Sainsbury may now cash out his remaining holdings.

name: Billionaires
bio: Cofounder of SAS, world’s largest privately held software company. First met partner James Goodnight (see) at North Carolina State. Founded SAS 1976; company develops business intelligence programs and platforms. Goodnight: sits on World Economic Forum’s International Business Council. Supports education causes. Avid rock collector has more than 100 fossils, meteorites. Sall: quiet techie spends his time heading JMP, statistical software maker that creates graphs from raw data. Partners believe happy employees are more productive: workers enjoy on-site  day care, 35-hour workweek, swimming pool, free M&Ms.

name: Billionaires
bio: One of a trio of Brazilian billionaire beer barons. With former investment banking partners, Jorge Paulo Lemann and Carlos Alberto Sicupira (see both), Telles built Brazilian brewer AmBev. In 2004 merged with Interbrew of Belgium to form InBev, world’s largest brewer by volume. InBev shares have surged over the past two years as company expands into emerging markets like China while cutting costs. The trio also controls Brazilian retailer Lojas Americanas, which had a stock rise of 67% in 2006. In January Lojas Americanas announced it was buying the Blockbuster movie rental stores in Brazil. Telles is reportedly a keen spearfisher and likes to spend time in Monaco.

name: Billionaires
bio: Met partner David Filo (see) at Stanford grad school, turned Internet directory project into popular Web portal Yahoo. Put Ph.D. on hold to work full-time. Took public 1996. Both billionaires said to still wear sneakers, fly coach. Former Warner Bros. boss Terry Semel lords over day-to-day operations. Yang: Taiwanese immigrant, participates in corporate strategy. Last month donated $75 million to Stanford; most of the money will go to a new environmental studies center.

name: Billionaires
bio: A descendent of one of most celebrated business families in modern Chinese history, in November symbolically cemented a deepening relationship between China and Africa when he bought into mining giant Anglo-American; bought the shares from South African billionaire Nicky Oppenheimer (see). Yung's main business interest is CITIC Pacific, a Hong Kong-listed conglomerate whose prominent investments include Cathay Pacific Airways.

name: Billionaires
bio: Thirty-nine-year-old billionaire took reins of Grupo Televisa when his father died in 1997. He now owns almost 15% of the company’s outstanding shares. Televisa operates radio, satellite, Internet and publishing businesses, and in recent years has diversified into off-track betting and a discount airline. Sitting on $1 billion in cash, the company sees the U.S. as its most important prospect for growth. Last year made an unsuccessful bid for Univision, the United States’ largest Spanish-language media company. The Azcárraga family helped found Univision in 1961 but was forced to reduce its stake because of U.S. limits on foreign ownership.

name: Billionaires
bio: Corporate raider known for snapping up large stakes in distressed companies. Got start as a bank trainee at Edmond de Rothschild. Has lately been targeting advertising companies: built up a stake in French agency Havas, demanded board seats, gutted management and made himself chairman; now buying up Aegis Group, the British media and market research concern. Eclectic portfolio also includes plastics, African shipping, Asian palm-oil plantations, newspapers and a television channel. Avid comics aficionado has a collection of 1,000 comic books by the likes of Pieds Nickles and Spirou.

name: Billionaires
bio:
Grandchild of publishing legend William Randolph Hearst, who assumed control of San Francisco Examiner from his father. Built what once was one of nation’s largest newspaper chains via sensational “yellow” journalism. Hearst Corp. still controlled by grandchildren; nonfamily member Victor Ganzi runs day-to-day business. Today empire comprises newspapers (San Francisco Chronicle), magazines (Cosmopolitan, Good Housekeeping), cable channels (stakes in ESPN, 
Lifetime, A&E), TV and radio stations. William III a partner at venture capital shop Kleiner Perkins; investing in online search engine Sphere, sportscentric stock market site Protrade.com. Also real estate; owns prime parcel along California coast.

name: Billionaires
bio: College dropout bought used garbage truck in 1962; turned small trash-hauling operation into waste-management titan WMX. Resigned 1984, shifted to movies. Bought 19-store video rental chain Blockbuster 1987; expanded, sold to Viacom 7 years later for $8.4 billion. Invested some of the proceeds in resorts; sold stake in Extended Stay America to Stephen Schwarzman’s (see) Blackstone Group 2004 for $185 million. Owner of pro football’s Miami Dolphins hosted Super Bowl XLI in February.

name: Billionaires
bio: Engineer runs family’s Kalyani group, world’s second-largest forgings manufacturer. Customers include DaimlerChrysler, Ford, General Motors and Toyota. His Bharat Forge, founded by father Neelkanth in 1966, has joint venture with First Auto Works, China’s biggest automotive company. Grooming son Amit, an engineer from Bucknell University. Considers 7 his lucky number.

name: Billionaires
bio: Wife Ann (see) inherited big Wal-Mart stake from father James (Bud) Walton (d. 1995), who cofounded retail giant with brother Sam. Stanley made fortune as a real estate developer; built shopping centers anchored by Wal-Mart stores. Also owns 1 million acres of ranch land across the Midwest and Canada. Sports junkie owns stakes in pro football’s St. Louis Rams, basketball’s Denver Nuggets, hockey’s Colorado Avalanche, soccer’s Colorado Rapids. Last year bought Napa Valley winery Screaming Eagle; cult cab limits production to 600 cases a year. Bottles of first vintage (1992): $3,000.

name: Billionaires
