bio: Son-in-law of Kazakhstan’s President Nursultan Nazarbaev hit the jackpot this fall when Halyk, Kazakhstan’s third-largest bank in which he owns a large stake, went public; wife, Dinara Kulibaeva (see), also owns shares. Last year was named chairman of the board of national oil and gas company KazMunaiGaz; its exploration division raised $2.3 billion in an initial public offering in London last fall.

name: Billionaires
bio: Second daughter of Kazakhstan President Nursultan Nazarbaev. With husband Timur Kulibaev (see) owns shares in Halyk, Kazakhstan’s third-largest bank, which went public last fall. Executive director of education foundation named after her father.

name: Billionaires
bio: Born in Shanghai and raised in Hong Kong, Lam studied engineering at National Taiwan University and went on to found one of the island's largest laptop computer makers, Quanta Computer. Still not a household name, the Taiwan contract manufacturer is the world's no. 1 maker of notebook computers. The company continues to quash rumors of a merger with Taiwan's largest PC parts maker, Terry Gou's (see) Hon Hai Precision Industry.

name: Billionaires
bio: Flamboyant socialite owns 47% of Hong Kong property developer, Chinese Estates Holdings. Succeeded brother Thomas as chairman in December after Hong Kong’s Insider Dealer Tribunal ruled Thomas had engaged in insider dealing and barred him from sitting on board for a year. Joseph’s son Lau Ming-wai will replace him as company executive director. He and Thomas also own a stake in Lifestyle International, the outfit that owns SOGO Department Stores. Avid art collector, recently paid $17.5 million for Andy Warhol’s “Mao,” a record for a Warhol. Also said to be one of largest collectors of red wine, with at least 10,000 bottles.

name: Billionaires
bio: Math major from Chinese University of Hong Kong; partnered with Chinese entrepreneur Zhang Li. Together built fortune (both billionaires) through Guangzhou R&F Properties by providing housing to increasingly well-off mainlanders. Li and Zhang are co-chairs of the company.

name: Billionaires
bio: Dropped out of high school at age 14 to help run family’s dairy business during Depression. Opened ice cream store with siblings 1940; turned $1,200 investment into 200-store United Dairy Farmers chain. Diversified into finance with small S&Ls. Today American Financial Group: big stakes in insurance, banking; assets up 25% in past 12 months. Also betting on energy: owns Indiana ethanol producer New Energy Corp; profits have doubled since 2005. Longtime co-owner of pro baseball’s Cincinnati Reds sold half the team to fruit-and-vegetable scion Robert Castellini last year.

name: Billionaires
bio: With brother Richard (see), sons of J.W. Marriott Sr. (d. 1985). Dad started empire with root beer stand in Washington, D.C. in 1927; Hot Shoppes later became regional chain. Opened first hotel 1957. J.W. Jr. appointed president 1964; exited restaurant business 25 years later. Brothers split company amid bondholder protest 1993. Richard controls hotel ownership operation (newly named Host Hotels & Resorts); J.W. heads franchise and property management outfit (Marriott International). Active Mormons fund education, also Bridges From School to Work Program.

name: Billionaires
bio: Son of cable investor John Elroy McCaw. With brothers Bruce, Keith and John Jr., inherited company after father’s death in 1969, made big bet on cellular; sold to AT&T in 1993 for $11.5 billion. Reinvested proceeds in Nextel and satellite network, wiped out in telecom crash. Now chief executive of Clearwire; broadband outfit offers wireless access across massive areas using Wi-Max.

name: Billionaires
bio: Son of Marcel Mérieux, a former laboratory aide to Louis Pasteur. Founded BioMérieux in 1974, a company that had roots in his father’s first laboratory, Institut Merieux, and an interest by Becton Dickinson. Is still chief executive of the biotech outfit, which specializes in the diagnosis of bacteria in the human body and infectious diseases like HIV and tuberculosis. The company is working with German biotech firm Profos to develop food-borne-pathogen testing and enhance food safety. Eldest son Rodolphe was killed in 1996 at the age of 27 when TWA Flight 800 crashed over Long Island. Second son, Christophe, who was expected to take over from his father this year, died of cardiac failure in July 2006 at age 39. Son Alexandre, 32, is a board member.

name: Billionaires
bio: Financial genius joined what became Drexel Burnham Lambert in 1969. Conceived market for high-yield junk bonds, fueled 1980s leveraged-buyout boom. Helped fund famous financiers of The Forbes 400: Ted Turner, Carl Icahn, Ronald Perelman (see all). Salary, bonus $550 million in 1986. Pleaded guilty to 6 counts of securities fraud 1990. Paid $900 million settlement to government, litigators, creditors; served 22 months in prison. Big medical-research backer started funding cancer research in 1970s after father diagnosed. Survived own battle with prostate cancer 1990s. Still investing, but spends bulk of his time on philanthropy. Supports groups trying to accelerate the development of cures for serious diseases: Prostate Cancer Foundation, Milken Family Foundation, FasterCures.

name: Billionaires
bio: Grandchild of A.N. Pritzker (d. 1986), who with sons Jay (d. 1999) and Robert created industrial conglomerate Marmon (2005 sales: $7 billion) and hotel giant Hyatt (215 hotels worldwide). In 2001 plans collapsed to pass control of empire to Jay’s son Thomas, cousin Nicholas and niece Penny; family agreed to split pot 11 ways. Deal enraged Robert’s youngest kids, Liesel and Matthew; duo filed suit, settled for $500 million each. Dynastic carve-up to include Hyatt public offering or sale by 2011. Tentative so far. Just one windfall: tobacco outfit Conwood sold for $3.5 billion to R.J. Reynolds April. Penny: heads family realty investments, Hyatt senior housing division. Family oversight role waning.

name: Billionaires
bio: Board member of Turkey's powerful Sabanci Group serves as face of family empire in Europe. Spends as much time in London as he does in Istanbul. Watched as fellow billionaire Bahaa Hariri (see) and family outbid Sabanci-led consortium for Turk Telecom privatization in late 2005. Also started another large Turkish conglomerate, Esas Holding, in 2000. Had library named for him at Harran University in Turkey. Past charitable projects include an archeological site in Turkey first excavated in the 1960s and a refurbished park in Bodrum, Turkey. Brother of Erol Sabanci (see).

name: Billionaires
bio: Met partner Henry Nicholas at TRW. Designed high-speed telecom chips in Nicholas’ spare bedroom. Founded Broadcom in 1991; took public 7 years later. Samueli: serves as Broadcom chairman, chief technical officer; working on expansion to India, China. UCLA grad funded alma mater’s School of Engineering & Applied Sciences; recently bought pro hockey’s Anaheim Ducks.

name: Billionaires
bio: Grandchild of Homer Stryker (d. 1980), surgeon who invented mobile hospital bed, founded medical supply company Stryker Corp. When son, Lee, died in plane crash 1976, hired John Brown (see) to run firm; deployed new sales force, cut costs. Public 1979. Third generation controls 30% of company. Jon: architect; funds gay and lesbian causes, great-ape sanctuaries.

name: Billionaires
bio: Widow of Brooklyn-born Laurence Tisch (d. 2003), who with brother Preston (d. 2005) bought New Jersey hotel in 1946; leased hotels in Atlantic City. Duo graduated to New York landmarks: Drake, Belmont Plaza and Regency. Took control of Loews Theaters 1959. Now company a diverse portfolio of subsidiaries: CNA Financial (insurance), Boardwalk (natural gas pipelines), Diamond Offshore (oil drilling), Bulova (watches) and Lorillard (tobacco). Company still under family’s control; shares have tripled in 3 years. Larry: long known for bearish pessimism, informal but tightfisted management style. Family’s contributions to NYU exceed $100 million.

name: Billionaires
bio: Founded a property company in Hong Kong with partner, Li Sze Lim (see) in 1994 after starting his career as a hotel industry executive. The two took their company Guangzhou R&F Properties public. Issued more shares this year to expand their land bank. Company made recent purchases in Guangdong province and Chongqing. Zhang is co-chairman and chief executive.

name: Billionaires
bio: In 2001 his Yuzhny Kuzbass bought a controlling stake in Glencore’s Chelyabinsk Metallurgical Plant. Out of these assets he created steel and mining Mechel Group, which went public in 2004 on the NYSE. Last year became Mechel’s largest investor, buying out shares of partner Vladimir Iorikh. Today rumors suggest Mechel may be broken up into separate mining and steel businesses.

name: Billionaires
bio: Coca-Cola director increased stake in soda giant last May; now owns 6.3 million shares worth $300 million. Bulk of fortune housed in investment boutique Allen & Company; helped take Google public. Low profile, stellar returns: claims to have earned more than 40% a year for investors since mid-1980s. Famous host of annual media retreat in Sun Valley, Idaho. Guest list often includes some from The Forbes 400: Henry Kravis, Barry Diller, Rupert Murdoch.

name: Billionaires
bio: This metals magnate is experiencing a re-birth of sorts. In the 1990s was one of the best-known Russian businessmen, co-owner of aluminum plants and the bank Rossiyskiy Kredit. In 2000 sold all his holdings in Russia and was quiet for 4 years. Then in 2004 made a triumphant comeback as co-owner, with Alisher Usmanov, of the Metalloinvest holding company, one of Russia&#39s largest ore mining and processing firms. His daughter Anna Anisimova has made her mark on New York’s real estate and social scenes. A member of her father’s real estate firm, Coalco, the former model helped broker a deal to buy designer Diane von Furstenberg’s Manhattan headquarters. She also spent $600,000 to rent a house in the Hamptons last summer and dropped $15 million on a 4,000-square-foot pad in the Time Warner Center.

name: Billionaires
bio: Mexico’s richest woman and granddaughter of Spanish immigrant who founded Grupo Modelo, maker of Corona and other beers. Asunción still has an undisclosed stake in Modelo, now 50%-owned by Anheuser-Busch, and has a joint venture with global player Constellation Brands. Wife of U.S. Ambassador to Mexico Tony Garza, she also has a stake in Emilio Azcárraga Jean’s Grupo Televisa.

name: Billionaires
bio: Reclusive retailing billionaire has been called the U.K.&#39s Howard Hughes for his extreme secrecy. In the spotlight recently as his Sports World International gets ready to list on the London Stock Exchange. The sports retailer has 370 stores and owns brands like Lillywhites and Lonsdale among others. In 2000 blew whistle on his competitors JJB Sports and Allsports when they called him to a meeting to fix the price of soccer jerseys. Didn’t stop Sports World from buying a 10% stake in JJB as well as shares in other rival chains Blacks Leisure and JD Sports.

name: Billionaires
bio: Press-shy founding partner of private  equity giant Apollo Advisors studied philosophy, history at Dartmouth. Harvard M.B.A. Took job at Drexel Burnham Lambert, famed Wall Street bank that made a name selling junk bonds during 1980s; became head of M&A. Michael Milken (see) convicted of securities fraud 1989; firm in bankruptcy a year later. Then Apollo: since 1990 firm has invested $15 billion from 5 private equity funds. Average annual return: 41%. Last year raised $12 billion for sixth fund; first investments include stakes in Jacuzzi, Realogy, Rexnord. Art lover owns one of country’s most renowned collections: impressionist, modern, contemporary, old masters. Friend of financier Carl Icahn (see).

name: Billionaires
bio: Pittsburgh native studied economics at Bucknell; graduate studies at San Diego State. Became a disciple of legendary investor Benjamin Graham. Founded Brandes Investment Partners money management firm in 1974. Stickler for due diligence: believes in painstaking financial analysis; invests in high-intrinsic-value companies at low stock price, waits for market to adjust. “Compelling bargains are often overlooked in equity markets.” Serves on boards of Salk Institute for Biological Studies, Whittier Institute for Diabetes. Paid Elton John to perform at wedding to wife, Tanya, last April; ceremony held at couple’s $60 million, 54,000-square-foot ranch in Rancho Santa Fe.

name: Billionaires
bio: The younger Chandler took half the assets of Sovereign Global when he and brother Richard parted ways, “completely amicably,” in December. His newly formed Legatum, which means “legacy” in Latin, retains significant stakes in banks in India and Japan. Raised on a New Zealand farm; father was once a beekeeper. Croatian mother lent upbringing an international bent. Section of Legatum Web site dedicated to global development and humanitarian activities.

name: Billionaires
bio: Split with his brother Christopher (see) after running investment portfolio Sovereign Global together for 20 years. Says he plans to pursue a different strategy through his newly anointed Orient Global, which has stakes in financial services in India. Secretive Sovereign had made fortune investing in such countries as Brazil, Japan and Russia and in such industries as telecom, banking and oil. Brothers made news over the years when they bought up major stakes in Korean conglomerates SK Corp., LG Electronics and LG Corp. Sold those all in 2005. Raised on a New Zealand farm; father was once a beekeeper before eventually founding a department store. Brothers sold store and used the money to begin their investing careers.

name: Billionaires
bio: Grandchild of publishing legend William Randolph Hearst, who assumed control of San Francisco Examiner from his father. Built what once was one of nation’s largest newspaper chains via sensational “yellow” journalism. Hearst Corp. still controlled by grandchildren; nonfamily member Victor Ganzi runs day-to-day business. Today empire comprises newspapers (San Francisco Chronicle), magazines (Cosmopolitan, Good Housekeeping), cable channels (stakes in ESPN, Lifetime, A&E), TV and radio stations.

name: Billionaires
bio: Chairman of Ashmore Group, a London fund manager specializing in emerging markets with $10 billion assets under management. Took company public in October, raising $2 billion. Started career at Australia & New Zealand Banking Group and rose through the ranks of the emerging market division. Started what is now Ashmore in 1992 with other ANZ Group alumni; officially became independent in 1999. Holds law degree from Cambridge University.

name: Billionaires
bio: Started Poland&#39s largest leasing business, Europejski Fundusz Leasingowy, in 1991. Sold his stake 10 years later to French bank Crédit Agricole for $280 million. Since then has concentrated on building a banking, insurance and leasing conglomerate. His publicly listed bank Getin Holding is expanding into Russia and Ukraine buying local banks. Last year founded private banking group, Noble Bank, to target high-net-worth Poles; plans to go public mid-2007. Continues to develop property arm. Recently stated: "In the past year I&#39ve earned more money than ever before in my life, and next year I&#39ll make still more."

name: Billionaires
bio: New Balance Arch Co. founded in 1906 with goal of correcting orthopedic foot problems. Davis saw opportunity in the rise of athletic shoe popularity; bought company on day of Boston Marathon 1972. Built brand bucking fashion trends. “Endorsed by no one” philosophy focused on selling comfort, support. Jim serves as chief exec; wife, Anne, is executive vice president. Company now holds No. 2 spot on the U.S. sneaker scene; sales exceed $1.5 billion. Expanding in Asia.

name: Billionaires
bio: Former owner of pro football’s San Francisco 49ers severed ties to team 1999 following heated dispute with sister Denise over family assets. Sister forced to pay him $70 million, give up large stake in Simon Property Group. Today owns 15.5 million SPG shares. Also owns shares in DeBartolo Holdings REIT inherited from mall-developer father. Now buying up land in Florida; developing shopping centers that feature medical offices, condos and bars.

name: Billionaires
bio: Former money man for George Soros (see) famous for orchestrating his boss’ billion-dollar raid on the British pound in 1992 with timely short position. Believed to help generate string of 30% returns for Soros’ Quantum Fund. Duo parted ways in 2000. Now runs Duquesne Capital Management in Pittsburgh. Chairs Harlem Children’s Zone; nonprofit provides educational services to more than 12,600 children and adults.

name: Billionaires
bio: Daughter of Curtis Carlson, who borrowed $55 in 1938 to produce trading stamps for grocery store promotions. Diversified into hotels (Regent, Radisson, Country Inns & Suites), restaurants (T.G.I. Friday’s), travel. With sister Marilyn Carlson Nelson(see), inherited Carlson Cos. after Curtis’ death in 1999. Marilyn: leads expanding travel-hospitality conglomerate Carlson Wagonlit. Acquired rival Navigant in August; combined operation sells more than $25 billion worth of corporate travel services. Going global: Beijing now hosts ritzy Regent Hotel; city already has two Friday&#39s and a Radisson. Son Curtis is president. Barbara heads family&#39s foundation.

name: Billionaires
bio: Sports magnate handing family business to second generation after suffering 2 strokes earlier this year. Best assets: pro football’s Tampa Bay Buccaneers and U.K. soccer behemoth Manchester United. Disgruntled U.K. fans still griping about Glazer. Bought majority stake in team last May, took club private; delisted from London Stock Exchange. Borrowed hundreds of millions of dollars with preferred stock to buy total control. Refinanced to reduce interest, but debt to sign star players will deplete team’s war chest. Family denies tight strings; plans to generate more media revenues. Healthy real estate portfolio includes 67 shopping centers.

name: Billionaires
bio: Israeli immigrant spent his 20s learning the buyout business alongside older brother Alec (see) at Gores Technology Group. Split in 1995: Tom now runs Platinum Equity; conglomerate manages 20 companies, with $8 billion in sales. Rebuilds distressed companies before selling them at a profit. Sold ACR Logistics to Kuehne & Nagel International for $510 million in January. Also invested in film-production shops Crescent Drive Pictures, 360 Pictures. Last year bought 8-acre property in Beverly Hills between homes of David Geffen and Ronald Burkle (see both).

name: Billionaires
bio: Grandchild of publishing legend William Randolph Hearst, who assumed control of San Francisco Examiner from his father. Built what once was one of nation’s largest newspaper chains via sensational “yellow” journalism. Hearst Corp. still controlled by grandchildren; nonfamily member Victor Ganzi runs day-to-day business. Today empire comprises newspapers (San Francisco Chronicle), magazines (Cosmopolitan, Good Housekeeping), cable channels (stakes in ESPN, Lifetime, A&E), TV and radio stations.

name: Billionaires
bio: Grandchild of publishing legend William Randolph Hearst, who assumed control of San Francisco Examiner from his father. Built what once was one of nation’s largest newspaper chains via sensational “yellow” journalism. Hearst Corp. still controlled by grandchildren; nonfamily member Victor Ganzi runs day-to-day business. Today empire comprises newspapers (San Francisco Chronicle), magazines (Cosmopolitan, Good Housekeeping), cable channels (stakes in ESPN, Lifetime, A&E), TV and radio stations.

name: Billionaires
bio: Grandchild of publishing legend William Randolph Hearst, who assumed control of San Francisco Examiner from his father. Built what once was one of nation’s largest newspaper chains via sensational “yellow” journalism. Hearst Corp. still controlled by grandchildren; nonfamily member Victor Ganzi runs day-to-day business. Today empire comprises newspapers (San Francisco Chronicle), magazines (Cosmopolitan, Good Housekeeping), cable channels (stakes in ESPN, Lifetime, A&E), TV and radio stations.

name: Billionaires
bio: Former chief executive of Banamex bank made almost $2 billion in 2001, when he sold the bank to Citigroup. Today owns more than 14 million Citigroup shares, valued at $780 million. In August gave away 4.8 million shares in “charitable gift” to family, a decrease that was offset by a rise in the Citigroup stock price. Five years after the Banamex sale Citigroup is still taking care of Hernández, who is a director there. Last year Citigroup gave Hernández and his family more than $2 million worth of “office, secretarial and related services, and airplane and helicopter usage.”

name: Billionaires
bio: Son of H.S. Kim, founder of Korean chipmaker Anam Semiconductor. Emigrated to U.S. 1955. Created Amkor Electronics 1968 as U.S. sales arm for father’s chip packaging business. Took public 30 years later.  Made a second fortune in gaming. With wife, Agnes, started Electronics Boutique retail chain 1977; first mall kiosk sold calculators, digital watches. Shifted to videogame consoles and accessories. Sold in 2005 to GameStop for $1.4 billion; netted $375 million.

name: Billionaires
bio: Nicknamed Mr. Shanghai for his evangelism on behalf of that business hub. Succeeded in China while other siblings in storied Hong Kong business family stayed at home. Listed China property investment vehicle, Shui On Land, in Hong Kong last year; company skirted scandal by repaying loan to a troubled Shanghai pension fund. Cement interests thriving amid China building boom. Part of investor group that owns Bank of America tower in San Francisco.

name: Billionaires
bio: Former engineer became right-hand man to TCI cable founder Bob Magness (d. 1996), sold TCI to AT&T in 1999 for $54 billion; investing the proceeds ever since. Today his publicly traded holding company Liberty Media owns stakes in electronic retailing (IAC/InterActiveCorp), media (Time Warner), cable (QVC, Encore, Starz).

name: Billionaires
bio: Former Campbell Soup accountant joined animal nutritionist Paul Iams’ pet food firm 1970; focused on high-end breeders and vets. Succeeded Iams 1975, bought him out 1982. Expanded with specialized food products for sensitive stomachs, weight loss. Sold company to Procter & Gamble 1999 for $2.3 billion. Keeps busy feeding Mathile Family Foundation.

name: Billionaires
bio: Daughter of Curtis Carlson, who borrowed $55 in 1938 to produce trading stamps for grocery store promotions. Diversified into hotels (Regent, Radisson, Country Inns & Suites), restaurants (T.G.I. Friday&#39s), travel. With sister Barbara Carlson Gage (see) inherited Carlson Cos. after Curtis’ death in 1999. Marilyn: leads expanding travel-hospitality conglomerate Carlson Wagonlit. Acquired rival Navigant in August; combined operation sells more than $25 billion worth of corporate travel services. Going global: Beijing now hosts ritzy Regent Hotel; city already has two Friday&#39s and a Radisson. Son Curtis is president. Barbara heads family&#39s foundation.

name: Billionaires
bio: The world’s first ethanol billionaire. With family, Ometto controls Cosan S.A., the world’s largest grower and processor of sugarcane, and second largest producer of ethanol. Cosan listed its shares on Brazilian stock exchange in 2005. The company&#39s origins date back to 1936, when the Ometto family established a sugarcane mill. Cosan has grown since 2000 through acquisitions and partnerships. It lost $31 million on revenues of $1.2 billion in fiscal 2006. Malaysian billionaire Robert Kuok’s (see) group is an investor in Cosan.

name: Billionaires
bio: Known to her friends as Lottie, she is the second-largest shareholder of Hennes & Mauritz, the successful Swedish clothing retail chain founded by her father, Erling, in 1947 and now run by her brother Stefan (see).

name: Billionaires
bio: Grandchild of A.N. Pritzker (d. 1986), who with sons Jay (d. 1999) and Robert created industrial conglomerate Marmon (2005 sales: $7 billion) and hotel giant Hyatt (215 hotels worldwide). In 2001 plans collapsed to pass control of empire to Jay’s son Thomas, cousin Nicholas and niece Penny; family agreed to split pot 11 ways. Deal enraged Robert’s youngest kids, Liesel and Matthew; duo filed suit, settled for $500 million each. Dynastic carve-up to include Hyatt public offering or sale by 2011. Tentative so far. Just one windfall: tobacco outfit Conwood sold for $3.5 billion to R.J. Reynolds April. Anthony: with brother, J.B (see), runs venture capital fund, invests in technology, manufacturing.

name: Billionaires
bio: Grandchild of A.N. Pritzker (d. 1986), who with sons Jay (d. 1999) and Robert created industrial conglomerate Marmon (2005 sales: $7 billion) and hotel giant Hyatt (215 hotels worldwide). In 2001 plans collapsed to pass control of empire to Jay’s son Thomas, cousin Nicholas and niece Penny; family agreed to split pot 11 ways. Deal enraged Robert’s youngest kids, Liesel and Matthew; duo filed suit, settled for $500 million each. Dynastic carve-up to include Hyatt public offering or sale by 2011. Tentative so far. Just one windfall: tobacco outfit Conwood sold for $3.5 billion to R.J. Reynolds April. Daniel: songwriter.

name: Billionaires
bio: Grandchild of A.N. Pritzker (d. 1986), who with sons Jay (d. 1999) and Robert created industrial conglomerate Marmon (2005 sales: $7 billion) and hotel giant Hyatt (215 hotels worldwide). In 2001 plans collapsed to pass control of empire to Jay’s son Thomas, cousin Nicholas and niece Penny; family agreed to split pot 11 ways. Deal enraged Robert’s youngest kids, Liesel and Matthew; duo filed suit, settled for $500 million each. Dynastic carve-up to include Hyatt public offering or sale by 2011. Tentative so far. Just one windfall: tobacco outfit Conwood sold for $3.5 billion to R.J. Reynolds April. James: retired U.S. Army colonel, founder of Pritzker Military Museum.

name: Billionaires
bio: Grandchild of A.N. Pritzker (d. 1986), who with sons Jay (d. 1999) and Robert created industrial conglomerate Marmon (2005 sales: $7 billion) and hotel giant Hyatt (215 hotels worldwide). In 2001 plans collapsed to pass control of empire to Jay’s son Thomas, cousin Nicholas and niece Penny; family agreed to split pot 11 ways. Deal enraged Robert’s youngest kids, Liesel and Matthew; duo filed suit, settled for $500 million each. Dynastic carve-up to include Hyatt public offering or sale by 2011. Tentative so far. Just one windfall: tobacco outfit Conwood sold for $3.5 billion to R.J. Reynolds April. J.B.: with brother, Anthony (see), runs venture capital fund, invests in technology, manufacturing.

name: Billionaires
bio: Grandchild of A.N. Pritzker (d. 1986), who with sons Jay (d. 1999) and Robert created industrial conglomerate Marmon (2005 sales: $7 billion) and hotel giant Hyatt (215 hotels worldwide). In 2001 plans collapsed to pass control of empire to Jay’s son Thomas, cousin Nicholas and niece Penny; family agreed to split pot 11 ways. Deal enraged Robert’s youngest kids, Liesel and Matthew; duo filed suit, settled for $500 million each. Dynastic carve-up to include Hyatt public offering or sale by 2011. Tentative so far. Just one windfall: tobacco outfit Conwood sold for $3.5 billion to R.J. Reynolds April. Gigi: filmmaker.

name: Billionaires
bio: Grandchild of A.N. Pritzker (d. 1986), who with sons Jay (d. 1999) and Robert created industrial conglomerate Marmon (2005 sales: $7 billion) and hotel giant Hyatt (215 hotels worldwide). In 2001 plans collapsed to pass control of empire to Jay’s son Thomas, cousin Nicholas and niece Penny; family agreed to split pot 11 ways. Deal enraged Robert’s youngest kids, Liesel and Matthew; duo filed suit, settled for $500 million each. Dynastic carve-up to include Hyatt public offering or sale by 2011. Tentative so far. Just one windfall: tobacco outfit Conwood sold for $3.5 billion to R.J. Reynolds April. John: runs private equity fund, invests in retailing, hospitality, entertainment, resorts.

name: Billionaires
bio: Grandchild of A.N. Pritzker (d. 1986), who with sons Jay (d. 1999) and Robert created industrial conglomerate Marmon (2005 sales: $7 billion) and hotel giant Hyatt (215 hotels worldwide). In 2001 plans collapsed to pass control of empire to Jay’s son Thomas, cousin Nicholas and niece Penny; family agreed to split pot 11 ways. Deal enraged Robert’s youngest kids, Liesel and Matthew; duo filed suit, settled for $500 million each. Dynastic carve-up to include Hyatt public offering or sale by 2011. Tentative so far. Just one windfall: tobacco outfit Conwood sold for $3.5 billion to R.J. Reynolds April. Karen: runs educational Web site Myhero.com.

name: Billionaires
bio: Grandchild of A.N. Pritzker (d. 1986), who with sons Jay (d. 1999) and Robert created industrial conglomerate Marmon (2005 sales: $7 billion) and hotel giant Hyatt (215 hotels worldwide). In 2001 plans collapsed to pass control of empire to Jay’s son Thomas, cousin Nicholas and niece Penny; family agreed to split pot 11 ways. Deal enraged Robert’s youngest kids, Liesel and Matthew; duo filed suit, settled for $500 million each. Dynastic carve-up to include Hyatt public offering or sale by 2011. Tentative so far. Just one windfall: tobacco outfit Conwood sold for $3.5 billion to R.J. Reynolds April. Linda: psychoanalyst, political activist.

name: Billionaires
bio: Buoyed by beer. With investing partners and fellow billionaires Jorge Paulo Lemann and Marcel Telles (see both), turned around AmBev, a lagging Brazilian beermaker, and in 2004 merged  it with Interbrew of Belgium to form InBev, now the world&#39s largest brewer by volume. The Brazilian trio is one of InBev’s controlling shareholders. The three men also control Brazilian retailer Lojas Americanas—a kind of Wal-Mart without groceries. For fun Sicupira is said to enjoy underwater spearfishing.

name: Billionaires
bio: Brothers are largest shareholders in Ranbaxy Laboratories, a leading pharmaceutical firm founded by their late grandfather Bhai Mohan Singh. Malvinder now chief executive, company on acquisition binge. Paid $324 million for Romanian pharma firm Terapia and is reportedly, preparing to bid for Merck's global generics business. Stock hit after recent FDA raid on company's U.S. headquarters in Princeton, N.J. Younger brother Shivinder heads Fortis Healthcare, a chain of hospitals, which he is readying to take public.

name: Billionaires
bio: Founder of Turkey's largest construction company, $6 billion (market capitalization) Enka. In addition to Turkey, Enka is especially active in Russia, where it partnered with Koc Holding to build the supermarket chain RamStore in Russian cities Moscow and St. Petersburg. Born in Skopje, Macedonia, established Enka with brother-in-law Sadi Gulcelik in 1957 in Istanbul at the age of 27.

name: Billionaires
bio: Shopping mall developer and former Sotheby’s chairman spent 9 months in jail on price-fixing charges 2004. Now writing no-holds-barred account of prison experience: Threshold Resistance in stores in April. Sold off controlling stake in art auctioneer 2005. U. of Michigan dropout built shopping center empire, took public via REIT 1992. Today Taubman Centers owns 22 malls in 11 states. Recently helped raise $45 million for Detroit Institute of Arts.

name: Billionaires
bio: Patriarch of cable news remains one of Time Warner’s largest individual shareholders despite dumping nearly 100 million shares in 4 years; has 30 million shares worth $650 million left. Stepped down as Time Warner vice chairman in 2003; retired from the board last May. “Mouth of the South” getting richer with real estate, food. Nation’s largest individual landowner: 2 million acres in 11 states. Restaurant chain, Ted’s Montana Grill, serves bison burgers at 45 locations. Newest venture: renewable energy. Pumping millions DT Solar. Last year donated 30 million Time Warner shares to his favorite charities, including Turner Foundation and United Nations, where Turner&#39s gifts now exceed $600 million.

name: Billionaires
bio: Youngest billionaire. Prince Albert von Thurn und Taxis appeared briefly in Forbes ranks at age 8 but officially inherited fortune on his 18th birthday in June 2001. Went to high school in Rome; studied economics and theology in Scotland. But doesn’t have to ever work. Assets include real estate, art and a tech company. His 30,000 hectares of woodland in Germany is considered one of the largest forest holdings in Europe. Lives in a family castle, Schloss Emmeram, with his mother, Gloria, and older sisters Maria Theresia and Elisabeth. Racecar driver tours with an Italian auto-racing league.

name: Billionaires
bio: Graduated from college with a degree in Chinese literature. Known to sprinkle his conversations with colorful Chinese phrases. Worked as a manager in a state-owned company. Then opened up a store that sold air-conditioners in his native city of Nanjing. Nowadays his Sunning Appliance has 400 retail stores, making it China's second-biggest electrical appliance chain. Has announced plans to open another 600 more by 2010. Listed his company on the Shenzhen stock exchange in 2004.

name: Billionaires
bio: World War II infantryman joined Army at 18; fought in Italy, France and Germany. Then sold topical ointments for uncle’s medical supplies company. Pharmaceutical entrepreneur stayed with family business, made fat fortune helping others get slim. Introduced Slim-Fast nutritional supplements 1976. Sold to Unilever in 2000 for $2.3 billion; all employees received year’s salary as parting gift. Octogenarian giving away fortune: donates to Mayo Clinic, cofounded Center for Middle East Peace & Economic Cooperation. Vital: sired sixth child after 80th birthday.

name: Billionaires
bio: Son of a barber got start selling popcorn. Played hockey for UCLA, then Harvard M.B.A. and Loyola law degree. Founded Ace Beverage 1956 with exclusive rights to distribute Budweiser in Los Angeles. Today controls suds distribution in LA, Hawaii (5 islands) and the Caribbean. Added insurance, auto dealerships, real estate. Portfolio now includes 4 million square feet of commercial property and 4,500 residential units. Big supporter of YMCA.

name: Billionaires
bio: Former banker has managed to largely keep out of the news since he sold Banco Bozano Simonsen to Spain’s Banco Santander Central Hispano 2000. Last year reportedly sold stakes in coffee plantation and Rio de Janeiro shopping center to new Brazilian investment fund. His 11% stake in Brazilian jetmaker Embraer worth $825 million. Said to love racing horses; lives in Greenwich, Conn.

name: Billionaires
bio: With partners and longtime friends Alijan Ibragimov and Alexander Machkevich (see both) built a metals and mining empire in Kazakhstan; in December Eurasian Natural Resources Corporation registered as a U.K. holding company in preparation for a public offering later this year. Reportedly forced to sell 25% stake in ENRC to fellow Kazakh billionaire Vladimir Kim (see) after government demanded management changes. A native of Uzbekistan, Chodiev studied international law and Japanese, and lived in Japan before teaming up with his pals. Travelled to Kazakhstan when the group decided to pursue business interests there.

name: Billionaires
bio: Fitness buff Diniz chairs $6.5 billion (sales) Companhia Brasileira de Distribuiçao, Brazil’s largest retailer, which sells everything from food and clothing to TVs and appliances. His stake in the retailer increased last year when his father, Valentim Diniz—who founded the company in 1948—divided his shares among his children. Abílio Diniz controls company with French food retailer Groupe Casino.

name: Billionaires
bio: A count who has a lock on his wealth. Holds stakes in Assa Abloy, world's largest producer of locks; Securitas AB, one of the largest publicly traded security companies; Fagerhult AB, a Swedish maker of light fixtures; and Attendo Senior Care, a private company that provides alarms and care communication systems for senior citizens. Received an M.B.A. from Harvard Business School in 1964.

name: Billionaires
bio: Trained mathematician; former IBM software engineer. Cofounded German software firm SAP with four former IBM colleagues. Successfully built up the North American market for SAP, then left the firm in 1997 after a falling-out with his partners. Holds an honorary professorship of mathematics from the University of Karlsruhe for his support of talented students in the math, natural sciences and technology fields. His charitable foundation supports cancer and AIDS research, art and historical preservation.

name: Billionaires
bio: With partners and longtime friends Alexander Machkevich and Patokh Chodiev (see both) built a metals and mining empire in Kazakhstan. In December Eurasian Natural Resources Corporation was registered as a U.K. holding company in preparation for a public offering there later this year. Reportedly forced to sell 25% stake in ENRC to fellow Kazakh billionaire, Vladimir Kim (see) after government demanded management changes. Native of Kyrgyzstan moved to Kazakhstan when the group decided to pursue business interests there. Devout Muslim with six sons, shuns the limelight.

name: Billionaires
bio: Born in Berlin, Jarislowsky moved to Canada in 1949 after receiving his M.B.A. at Harvard. Six years later founded Jarislowsky Fraser, an asset manager that today manages $50 billion on behalf of institutional clients and high-net-worth individuals. Outspoken critic of excessive executive pay. In addition to an eclectic art collection, which includes jade, Chinese furniture and Eskimo artifacts, owns a private island in British Columbia with 16 miles of shoreline. Inducted into the Canadian Business Hall of Fame last year.

name: Billionaires
bio: The son of a pharmacist cobbled together 2,000 pharmacies to create one of the biggest pharmacy chains in North America. The Edmonton, Alta.-based Katz (pronounced “Cates”) Group is also one of Canada’s largest private companies. Starting in the 1990s Katz bought up distressed pharmacy chains with the help of drug distributor McKesson, then hired capable execs to turn the chains around. Katz is now using the Rexall name to rebrand his stores; plans to open 100 new ones in Canada using existing cash flow to fund them.

name: Billionaires
bio: With partners and longtime friends Alijan Ibragimov and Patokh Chodiev (see both) built a metals and mining empire in Kazakhstan; in December Eurasian Natural Resources Corporation registered as a U.K. holding company in preparation for a public offering later this year. Reportedly forced to sell 25% stake in ENRC to fellow Kazakh billionaire Vladimir Kim (see) after government demanded management changes. Native of Kyrgyzstan studied literature and was one of the youngest deans of a university in Kyrgyzstan at the age of 26. Moved to Moscow to start a trading business with Chodiev and Ibragimov. Early on obtained Israeli citizenship and has been very active in Jewish causes.

name: Billionaires
bio: Warren Buffett&#39s (see) overlooked yet indispensable consigliere; Oracle of Omaha claims duo often “tap-dance to work.” Vice chairman of Berkshire Hathaway since 1979; owns 16,000 shares worth $1.7 billion. Due-diligence-obsessed investor published Poor Charlie’s Almanac in 2005; tome full of “Mungerisms,” such as: “If you buy a few great companies, you can sit on your ass.”

name: Billionaires
bio: Holds 9% of Spain&#39s largest construction company, $15.6 billion (2005 sales) A.C.S. (Actividades de Connstrucción y Servicios S.A.), which he has headed since 1993.  Well known as onetime president of popular Real Madrid soccer club, once the team of stars like David Beckham and Zinedine Zidane; ran the club from 2000 to 2006. Resigned in February 2006 after string of defeats, despite initial successes and once-stellar players

name: Billionaires
bio: Son and grandson of Washington, D.C.-area mortgage lenders set up Chevy Chase Bank in trailer 1969. Now largest local bank in area; worth at least $1 billion. Started real estate investment trust Saul Centers 1993 to own retail properties, strip malls; today holds just under 50%. U of Virginia grad a trustee of National Gallery of Art, Johns Hopkins School of Medicine.
title: Chairman and CEO
employment: {'name': 'Saul Centers Inc.', 'title': 'Chairman and CEO', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Great-granddaughter of Franz Ströher, wigmaker who founded Wella AG, one of world&#39s biggest professional hair care groups. Pocketed $1 billion in March 2003 sale of Wella to Procter & Gamble. Sylvia and her husband, a former male nurse, are known for their collection of contemporary German art which includes works by Baselitz, Immendorff and Kiefer.

name: Billionaires
bio: Cofounder of Sun Microsystems; an inventor of Cisco Systems’s switching business. Co-founded and ran Kealia, a computer design system, sold to Sun in 2004.  Now back at Sun Microsystems as senior vice president and chief architect.  Early backer of Google: his initial $100,000 investment is now worth US$1.5 billion. Also has stake in chip-designing-software maker Magma Design Automation. Reportedly lives alone in a small Palo Alto, Calif. apartment.

name: Billionaires
bio: Made headlines last summer for backing Lakshmi Mittal in his successful attempt to merge pan-European steel group Arcelor with Mittal Steel to form Arcelor Mittal, world's largest steel company, with $78 billion in sales. Now holds 2.6% of new entity, which makes him third-biggest shareholder after Mittal and Romain Zaleski (see both). Reportedly never goes out in public without a bodyguard to safeguard him and his family from kidnapping and assassination attempts by Basque separatists. Owns cattle ranch Ganaderias Aguadulce, in south of Spain, on which he raises bulls for bullfighting.

name: Billionaires
bio: Founded NCB stockbrokers in Dublin in 1981. Sold the company in 1994 for $39 million and started his own private equity firm, International Investment & Underwriting. This year sold his best-known asset, the London City Airport, to a consortium of investors including Credit Suisse, GE and AIG. Still owns stakes in a variety of entities, from Scotland’s Celtic Football Club to Latvia’s Rietumu Banka; also a piece of Barbados&#39 swank Sandy Lane Hotel. Passionate golfer.

name: Billionaires
bio: HCA founder took nation’s largest hospital operator private with Bain Capital, KKR and Merrill Lynch last July for $33 billion. Served as a flight surgeon in Air Force. With father, founded Hospital Corp. of America 1968. Public 1969. Merged with Columbia Hospital Corp. of Richard Rainwater (see) 1994. Came out of retirement to revive company during a lengthy Medicare-fraud investigation. Predicts big buyout will inspire other large family-owned public companies to go private: “We&#39re breaking new ground. This will play a big role in showing people you can do it.” Funds Joe C. Davis YMCA Outdoor Center in Nashville; often flies in on his Lake Amphibian airplane to visit.

name: Billionaires
bio: Inherited retailer from Polish-immigrant parents; sold it to his brother-in-law in 1985. Built own fortune in shopping centers; still owns 50% of Chadstone and Northland malls. Last year divested his stakes in the companies that manage his properties and recently sold 4 retirement villages for $80 million. Also invests in irrigation companies in Israel. With his wife collects Japanese art.

name: Billionaires
bio: Payroll rep saw niche handling red tape for small businesses. Launched payroll and HR services firm Paychex 1971 with $3,000 and a credit card; expanded through franchise agreements, joint ventures. Took public 1983. Today more than 100 offices nationwide. Stepped down from day-to-day operations in 2004; remains chairman. Cofounder of New York State Independence Party, spent $90 million of his own money on three failed gubernatorial campaigns. Decided against 2006 run. Owns pro hockey’s Buffalo Sabres; gives to education, health care causes.

name: Billionaires
bio: With her 5 children, Günter, Joachim, Michael, Wolfgang, and Daniela (see all), inherited a fortune from her late husband, coffee magnate Max Herz. Personally owns 15% of Tchibo Holding, the German consumer goods group her husband ran. Sons Michael, Wolfgang and Joachim own the rest. Daughter Daniela and son Günter cashed out in 2003 after a nasty family feud.

name: Billionaires
bio: South Korea's richest woman is the younger sister of the nation's richest man, Samsung head Lee Kun-Hee (see). Chairs fast-growing retailer Shinsegae, once part of the mighty Samsung Group; name means "new world." Company bought Wal-Mart's stores in South Korea last year; should complement its successful discount chain E-Mart, which already accounts for 80% of its sales. Lee's husband was one of thousands competing last year to become the first Korean astronaut; he didn't win. Son Chung Yong-Jin is Shinsegae's vice president; her daughter is involved in the family hotel business.

name: Billionaires
bio: Former Honeywell exec became chief of networking firm Cisco in 1988. Went public 1990, stepped down 5 years later as stock turned into Internet bellwether; briefly, in 2000, the world's most valuable company. With wife, Tashia, gave $50 million to U of Wisconsin to fund biosciences research in April. Avid cyclist and hiker chairs the Nature Conservancy, which uses private funds to buy up privately held land to protect it from development. New board age limit had him stepping down as Cisco chairman this past November.

name: Billionaires
bio: Much venerated cofounder of $2 billion (revenue) software services firm Infosys Technologies, which celebrated silver jubilee in 2006. Stepped down as executive chairman last August upon turning 60 but is still chief mentor and nonexecutive chairman. Set to join Unilever’s board in May.

name: Billionaires
bio: Lawyer turned money man got start at Thacher Proffitt & Wood, then stints at BlackRock Financial and UBS. Cofounded asset manager Fortress Investment Group in 1998. Today serves as chief operating officer, oversees structured finance and legal matters. Became a billionaire with partners Peter Briger, Michael Novogratz, Robert Kauffman and Wesley Edens (see all) with public offering last month. Owns 53 million shares worth $1.6 billion. Group sold minority interest to Japanese investment firm Nomura for $890 million last December; Nardone has earned an additional $100 million in net cash payouts since 2005.

name: Billionaires
bio: Argentinean-born son of Cuban parents wanted to be an academic; became urban planner instead. Then condos. With partner, Stephen Ross (see), cofounded Related Group of Florida 1979; built affordable housing for low- and middle-income customers 1980s. Switched to high-end condo construction because “you make 20 times more.” Has built 55,000 apartments in Florida over the past 25 years. Now tapping new markets: Atlanta, Tampa, Orlando, Park City, Denver. In 2005 announced plans to build $3 billion Las Ramblas condo-and-casino complex in Las Vegas; project fell through, sold land to W Hotel Group for $100 million profit. Despite faltering Florida condo market, announced $200 million luxury high-rise development in West Palm Beach with partner Donald Trump (see) in January. Milking Latin American ties to start condo projects in Mexico, Argentina.

name: Billionaires
bio: Raised in gold mining town in central Australia. Quit school at 14 to sell hand-carved handkerchief boxes. Dabbled in plumbing, construction, a small airline and ice skating ventures. His best cash business came as a going-away gift in 1962 when he stepped down from his job as a manager for an earthmoving outfit. The company chairman gave Perron Toyota franchise rights, allowing Perron to set up dealerships in Western Australia. Perron says he tried to give it away, but “nobody wanted it.”

name: Billionaires
bio: Vietnam vet’s Majestic Realty rapidly expanding. Owns, operates 70 million square feet of commercial property in Los Angeles, Denver, Las Vegas, Dallas. Biggest boom: rising demand for LA distribution centers as Asian trade increases. Built Staples Center with Philip Anschutz (see); duo owns stakes in pro basketball’s LA Lakers, hockey’s LA Kings. Donated $23 million to alma mater USC&#39s fine arts school last year.

name: Billionaires
bio: Canada's cheese mogul started Saputo in Montreal in 1954 with parents Giuseppe and Maria. Delivered mozzarella by bicycle in the early days. Snapped up U.S. and Canadian dairies in the 1980s as pizza's growing popularity boosted demand for his products. Still serves as chairman; son Lino Jr. is chief. Through his private investment company Jolina Capital, recently took Canadian lumber company Arbec Forest Products private and also owns a stake in Tembec, another forest products company. Owns 80% of the 47-story Place Victoria, home of the Montreal Stock Exchange.

name: Billionaires
bio: Vice chairman of Lotte Group, a conglomerate with interests in retail, candy and construction. Group was founded by his father and chairman Shin Kyuk-Ho, 84, who transferred much of his wealth to Shin and his older brother Shin Dong-Joo (see).  Group now trying to build the world's tallest tower in Seoul. Heads professional baseball team Lotte Giants in Japan.

name: Billionaires
bio: With her three children and her brother-in-law, this widow controls Brazil’s second-largest steelmaker, Companhia Siderúrgica Nacional (CSN). In 1993 son Benjamin used money from the family’s textile business to purchase stake in steel company. He now serves as CSN’s chairman and chief executive. In early 2007 CSN lost a bid to acquire Anglo-Dutch steelmaker Corus Group to India’s Tata Steel. Dorothéa isn’t involved in running the steel company. The family also owns Banco Fibra, which has nearly $3 billion in assets.

name: Billionaires
bio: Grandchild of Homer Stryker (d. 1980), surgeon who invented mobile hospital bed, founded medical supply company Stryker Corp. When son, Lee, died in plane crash 1976, hired John Brown (see) to run firm; deployed new sales force, cut costs. Public 1979. Third generation controls 30% of company. Pat: founder of Bohemian Foundation, donates to quirky causes like making Colorado the best place in the U.S. to raise children.

name: Billionaires
bio: Seventh child of Kentucky dairy farmers fell in love with airplanes listening to broadcast of Lindbergh’s transatlantic flight. Paid for flying lessons by opening hamburger stand near school. University of Kentucky dropout flew Pan Am airplanes for 10 years. Launched corporate pilot training outfit FlightSafety International 1951. Took public 1968, sold shares to Warren Buffett’s Berkshire Hathaway 1996. Now chairs Orbis International: nonprofit group uses airplanes as mobile ophthalmological labs for doctors in developing countries.

name: Billionaires
bio: Great-grandfather peddled baking powder and soap; used chewing gum as incentive. Gum more popular; introduced spearmint chewables 1893. Bought Altoids, Life Savers brands as part of $1.5 billion Kraft Foods candy division acquisition 2004. Opened candy factory in Shanghai; looking for acquisitions in Asia. World’s largest gum producer launched 72 new products last year to go with 2 most recognizable brands: Wrigley’s Extra and Orbit. Fourth-generation gummaker named ex-Nike executive William Perez as new chief; remains chairman.

name: Billionaires
bio: Morphed a bed-linen manufacturer into Turkey's largest exporter. His Zorlu holding company encompasses 65 businesses in consumer electronics, financial services and energy. Once bankrupt, his private-label TV-maker and distributor Vestel today commands 26% of the European market. In 2006 sold his private bank, Denizbank, to Belgian Dexia for $2.4 billion; now searching for new investments. High school dropout shuttles around Europe in custom-designed helicopter. Also owns Vestel Manisaspor soccer club, which plays in Turkey's Premier Super League.

name: Billionaires
bio: Started out, with brother Dmitry (see), importing computers to Russia. Brothers then set up a bank and recently have been active in real estate and mass media. Alexei heads up their IT business and general strategy. Despite their wealth, felt a lack of education and completed executive M.B.A.s at the University of Chicago in 2005. Both brothers are very religious. Uses free time to assist clergymen at Moscow’s Church of the Trinity.

name: Billionaires
bio: Brought into the business by older brother Alexei (see); they are now equal partners. Started out importing computers to Russia, then set up a bank, and recently have been active in real estate and mass media. Despite their wealth, the brothers felt a lack of education and completed executive M.B.A.s at the University of Chicago in 2005. Alexei is in charge of the brothers’ IT business and the general strategy; Dmitry was recently appointed to a seat on the Federation Council of the gas-rich Arctic region of Yamal and is more involved in their bank, Promsvyazbank.

name: Billionaires
bio: Son of Greek immigrants; born in Detroit, raised in Pasadena, Calif. Got real estate license 1962, bought corner lots at busy intersections and sold to gas stations. Started renting apartments 1968, realized real money was in owning. Today privately held Arnel & Affiliates owns, manages 5,200 apartments plus more than 2 million square feet of commercial space. Former ambassador to Spain invests in pet products (Doskocil), coolers (Igloo) through Westar Capital.

name: Billionaires
bio: Former government bureaucrat has turned Hopson Development Holdings into a national real estate brand, with successful projects in Beijing, Shanghai and Tianjin.

name: Billionaires
bio: Son of Texas farmer bought first bank in 1975 for $1.2 million, later sold for $80 million. Biggest score: With Ronald Perelman (see), sold California’s Golden State Bancorp to Citigroup for $6 billion in stock 2002. When in New York, visits Perelman to stake out new banking deals. Other investments include auto-finance outfits AmeriCredit and Triad Financial, oil and gas firm McMoRan Exploration. Southern Methodist U alum donated $20 million in 1997 to build new football venue; SMU Mustangs now play at Ford Stadium. Owns 140,000-acre cattle ranch in New Mexico, compound in the Hamptons.

name: Billionaires
bio: Opened a wholesale business which sold perfume and beauty supplies in 1994 in his hometown of Krasnodar. In 1998 established Magnit, a chain of grocery stores with the slogan “Always Low Prices.” Took the company public in April 2006; Magnit’s 1870 stores generate $2.5 billion in annual sales. Loves Ferraris and extremely expensive watches.

name: Billionaires
bio: Inherited Gerling Konzern, one of the world's largest reinsurers, from his father. The company, in which he had 94% stake, was sold to Germany's Talanx Group in November 2005 for estimated $1.6 billion. Now focuses on his Gerling Academy for Risk Research, a think tank that studies the industrial world's impact on the environment.

name: Billionaires
bio: Started small investment portfolio from Harvard dorm room in 1986 after reading article on Home Shopping Network in FORBES; managed $1 million by senior year. Started Citadel Investment Group with $1 million investment from trader Frank Meyer 1990. Today manages at least $12 billion in assets. No longer active in trading. Wife, Anne Dias, manages hedge fund Aragon Global Management. Duo donates to education, arts causes.

name: Billionaires
bio: Digital-dish lovers will be forever indebted to Hubbard for their satellite television service. Father Stanley Eugene (d. 1992) founded what may have been first U.S. commercial airline, went bankruptcy; built radio station 1923, added TV 1948. “Stub” seized control 1981, pioneered satellite-TV business with U.S. Satellite Broadcasting. Took public 1996; sold to Hughes/DirecTV for $1.3 billion 3 year later. Latest endeavor: movie information and trivia channel Reelz. Grandfather of 13 now chief cheerleader: “It’s more fun that way.”

name: Billionaires
bio: Left teaching job at MIT in 1966 to help start engineering school at UC, San Diego. Developed knack for negotiation working on projects for U.S. Department of Defense. Cofounded Qualcomm 1985. Patented CDMA (code division multiple access) design, now running in more than a quarter of the world’s cell phones. Flourishing in U.S. and Asia; fighting to win over carriers and phonemakers in Europe, where company now faces charges of antitrust violations from competitors.

name: Billionaires
bio:
Korean War vet earned law degree at night from DePaul U Partnered with Phillip Frost (see) early 1970s, acquired Key Pharmaceuticals. Turned company around with revamped asthma drug; sold to Schering-Plough for $836 million in 1986. Launched Kos Pharmaceuticals 2 years later. Public 1997; dominated cholesterol market with 
Niaspan, which raises good cholesterol. Sold company to Abbott Laboratories in November for $3.7 billion. Donates to New York’s Metropolitan Museum of Art, Tufts University.

name: Billionaires
bio: Media-shy shades tycoon sold motorcycle grips from his car trunk 1975. Founded Oakley; added sunglasses, goggles. Boosted sales with savvy marketing, avoiding star-endorsement deals. Now invading Nike’s turf with push into sportswear, shoes. Also personal electronics: developed RazrWire, Thump sunglasses with built-in MP3 player. Optics products account for 70% of business. Handed over reins to former Nike exec Scott Olivet in 2005; self-proclaimed “mad scientist” still serves as chairman.

name: Billionaires
bio: Heir to America’s largest private company and the world’s biggest agriculture and commodity-trading concern. Founder William W. Cargill started with grain elevator in Iowa after Civil War, son-in-law John MacMillan took over after patriarch’s death. Fifth generation now on the board. Family owns nearly 90% of company, employees the rest. Sales now $75 billion. Expanding into agricultural consulting and other service industries. All known for keeping it private in daily life as well as business matters. Cousins James Cargill and Margaret Cargill both died last year.

name: Billionaires
bio: Son of auto dealer quit job to sell used computers after placing $3 ad in Chicago Tribune to sell old PC. Reaped $300 profit on second sale. Saw potential in discount computer sales, started Computer Discount Warehouse 1984. Skilled negotiator brought car-selling traits to computer industry; offered salespeople high incentives. Today CDW sells $6 billion of computer gear, mostly to businesses, government. Spends time managing personal portfolio that consists mostly of low-risk stocks and bonds.

name: Billionaires
bio: Founded BlackBerry maker Research in Motion while a student at the University of Waterloo. Debuts this year among the World’s wealthiest along with his cochief executive James Balsillie (see), thanks to the strength of RIM’s stock, up 95% in the last year after the company settled a patent dispute that threatened to shut down the popular e-mail service. Lazaridis drives the company’s technology and research. Noted donor: gave $50 million to his alma mater; gave another $100 million to establish the Perimeter Institute for Theoretical Physics.

name: Billionaires
bio: Only son of Samsung Chairman Lee Kun-Hee (see). Studied Asian history at Seoul National University in Korea and majored in business at Keio University in Japan. His thesis was about deindustrialization in Japan's manufacturing industry. Also attended a doctoral program at Harvard Business School, majoring in e-commerce. Joined Samsung after graduation; recently headed up its successful S-LCD joint venture with Sony. Heir apparent acquired a 25% stake in Samsung Everland through convertible bonds with low conversion prices raising some concerns among civic groups.

name: Billionaires
bio: An orphan, Lee learned the art of trading from an uncle in Hong Kong. Started exporting handbags from the mainland. Set up Lee & Man Paper in 1994 to tap China's need for packaging paper for its burgeoning exports. More recently profits coming from packaging paper for goods snapped up by China's increasingly affluent consumers. Lee & Man Paper operates a pulp mill in California and plans to invest in Vietnam,

name: Billionaires
bio: Heir to America’s largest private company and the world’s biggest agriculture and commodity-trading concern. Founder William W. Cargill started with grain elevator in Iowa after Civil War, son-in-law John MacMillan took over after patriarch’s death. Fifth generation now on the board. Family owns nearly 90% of company, employees the rest. Sales now $75 billion. Expanding into agricultural consulting and other service industries. All known for keeping it private in daily life as well as business matters. Cousins James Cargill and Margaret Cargill both died last year.

name: Billionaires
bio: Heir to America’s largest private company and the world’s biggest agriculture and commodity-trading concern. Founder William W. Cargill started with grain elevator in Iowa after Civil War, son-in-law John MacMillan took over after patriarch’s death. Fifth generation now on the board. Family owns nearly 90% of company, employees the rest. Sales now $75 billion. Expanding into agricultural consulting and other service industries. All known for keeping it private in daily life as well as business matters. Cousins James Cargill and Margaret Cargill both died last year.

name: Billionaires
bio: Built energy conglomerate Perez Companc and sold it to energy giant Petrobras for $1 billion in 2002. Now focuses on the type of oil that comes from vegetables. Food and farming concern Molinos Rio de la Plata, in which he owns a controlling stake, recently spent $110 million to expand its soybean-crushing factory in San Lorenzo. Argentina’s answer to Kraft also deals in pasta, flour and frozen foods. Side project: with wife, Maria Carmen, raises dairy cows and churns ice cream for Munchi’s, a small chain of ice cream parlors.

name: Billionaires
bio: Heir to America’s largest private company and the world’s biggest agriculture and commodity-trading concern. Founder William W. Cargill started with grain elevator in Iowa after Civil War, son-in-law John MacMillan took over after patriarch’s death. Fifth generation now on the board. Family owns nearly 90% of company, employees the rest. Sales exceed $75 billion. Expanding into agricultural consulting and other service industries. All known for keeping it private in daily life as well as business matters. Cousins James Cargill and Margaret Cargill both died last year.

name: Billionaires
bio: Eldest son of Lotte Group founder and chairman, Shin Kyuk-Ho, who transferred much of his wealth to Shin and his younger brother Shin Dong-Bin (see). Vice president of Japan Lotte. Sits on the boards of Lotte Chilsung Beverage, Hotel Lotte and Lotte Aluminum.

name: Billionaires
bio: Born, schooled in Madras, India. Created shop bot Junglee; sold to Amazon in 1998. Worked for Netscape, Amazon before launching Sherpalo in 2000. Learned to adapt during the tech bust: “Living in a world where everything is changing constantly, you learn to change.” Early investor, board member of Google. Sold off more than half his shares since public offering 2004. Other investments: Zazzle (custom-designed T shirts, mugs, stamps), PodShow (online radio), 247Customer.com (Indian call centers).

name: Billionaires
bio: Like former business partner Lev Kvetnoi (see) was born in a small settlement near Moscow and studied at the same school of athletics, the Institute of Physical Culture, but later got a degree in teaching. In early 1990s, worked for MontazhSpetsBank. With Kvetnoi joined Alisher Usmanov’s metallurgical business; Kvetnoi was sent to Oskol Metal Works, while Skoch went to Lebedinsky Mining. In April Usmanov joined the 2 firms with a third to create the Metalloinvest conglomerate. Kvetnoi sold out, but Skoch remains a partner. Became a member of the State Duma in 1999.

name: Billionaires
bio: New York City developer bet everything on one skyscraper: built iconic 9 West 57th 1972; “the best building in the city” now worth estimated $1.5 billion. Also owns luxury apartments on Upper East Side. Latest project: turning undeveloped parcel on Manhattan’s East River into 4 million square feet of residential, commercial and retail space. Proposed buildings will be taller than 505-foot-high United Nations building.

name: Billionaires
bio: Chairman of the Geneva-headquartered Steinmetz Diamond Group, the largest customer of De Beers. Like most diamond dealers, Steinmetz is moving upstream to insure a reliable supply of rough diamonds. Last year he won 11 diamond-manufacturing licenses in Botswana; he also boasts mining licenses in the Congo, Sierra Leone and Zambia (all of which pit him directly against his iconic supplier). Steinmetz also has a 37% stake in Nikanor, a holding company with copper and cobalt mining assets located in Congo, which raised $400 million in an initial public offering on London’s Alternative Investment Market in July 2006.

name: Billionaires
bio: Patriarch of the Yeoh family founded YTL Corp., one of Malaysia&#39s largest conglomerates with interests in construction, utilities, hotels, property development and technology. He and his family profited from the late 1990s financial downturn, using it as an opportunity to start buying up land and companies that were selling at cut-rate prices. In 2002 bought English utility company Wessex Water for $1.7 billion from Enron. Son Francis runs YTL’s daily operations.

name: Billionaires
bio: China-born Zhong joined the ranks of the world's richest following the successful initial offering of his property development arm Yanlord in Singapore in 2006. Zhong also has businesses in trading, manufacturing, retail and financial services in China, Singapore, Hong Kong, Indonesia, Malaysia and Australia. Yanlord's land bank includes sites in Shanghai, Chengdu, Nanjing, Zhuhai, Suzhou and Tianjin.

name: Billionaires
bio: Followed in footsteps of older brother Kutayba (see); got undergraduate degree at UC, Berkeley before joining family’s multibillion-dollar trading business. Also forged own success as head of Gulf Bank, with more than $13.8 billion in assets Kuwait&#39s second-largest commercial bank. In December the Kuwaiti  bourse reportedly barrred the Alghanim family from selling any of their shares in Gulf Bank as consequence for failing to fully disclose their stake in the public company.

name: Billionaires
bio: Older brother of Bassam (see), Kutayba started at father's conglomerate, Alghanim Industries, 1970s, after graduating from UC, Berkeley. As chairman, oversees group operations in consumer goods, auto trading, shipping and financial services spanning 4 continents. Reportedly owns Samar, one of the largest and most expensive private yachts ever built with an onboard helicopter, 2 swimming pools and space for a staff of 20, plus guests.

name: Billionaires
bio: Cochief executive of BlackBerry maker Research in Motion. Debuts this year among the world’s wealthiest along with company founder Michael Lazaridis (see) thanks to the strength of RIM’s stock, up 95% in the last year after the company settled a patent dispute that threatened to shut down the popular e-mail service. Balsillie offered to buy the Pittsburgh Penguins hockey team last year for an estimated $175 million, but the deal fell through. Helped establish the Waterloo Regional Children&#39s Museum and donates to other causes like Lazaridis&#39 Perimeter Institute for Theoretical Physics. Competes in men&#39s long course triathlons.

name: Billionaires
bio: Cofounded commercial real estate investment firm, JMB Realty, with Judd Malkin 1968. Today diverse portfolio includes office buildings in Los Angeles, shopping mall in Chicago, luxury hotels. Partner in private equity Walton Street Capital; raised a $1.6 billion fund last June. Doubling down: won coveted Philadelphia casino license in December. Developed $890 million Niagara Falls casino with Pritzker family (see). Also seeking Illinois gaming license. Big supporter of Northwestern U. and Northwestern Memorial Hospital’s heart program.

name: Billionaires
bio: Met partner Min Kao (see) as an engineer at AlliedSignal; struck out on own to make products based on newfangled Global Positioning System. Founded navigation device maker Garmin 1989; U.S. Army first customer, during Gulf war. Expanded to devices for boats, planes, hikers. Now focused on R&D; developing 60 new products a year. Burrell: retired as cochair 2004, now chairman emeritus.
title: Chairman Emeritus

name: Billionaires
bio: LA builder owns 209,000 square feet of office space and 3,100 luxury apartment units in southern California. “I like to think I’m in the affordable housing business.” Onetime accountant now focused on condo and retail development. Partners with Blackacre Capital Management, real estate arm of hedge fund Cerberus Capital Management, and apartment operator AIMCO in other LA-area projects. Also venturing into Israel. Last June acquired 50% stake in Israel’s EMD Real Estate Development & Investment; plans to build 40-story luxury tower with panoramic views of Tel Aviv and 5-minute walk from beach. “It’s going to be a home run.”

name: Billionaires
bio: Opened his first drugstore in 1969. Now the Jean Coutu Group is one of North America’s largest pharmacy chains. Bought into the Eckerd brand in 2004 when it purchased the chain’s stores in the Northeast and mid-Atlantic states for $2.4 billion. Just two years later announced it was selling its U.S. operations, including the Eckerd and Brooks brands, to Rite Aid, in a deal worth $3.4 billion in stock and cash. When the deal closes later this year, Jean Coutu Group will become Rite Aid&#39s top shareholder. Coutu’s son Michel will also became cochairman of the board at Rite Aid.

name: Billionaires
bio: Runs $3 billion (sales) Videocon group, consumer electronics and home appliances manufacturer with factories in India, Poland, Italy, Mexico and China. Is world&#39s third-largest maker of color picture tubes. In October announced $700 million deal for South Korea’s Daewoo Electronics; still pending. Plays the flute.

name: Billionaires
bio: Former car dealer now runs a media empire holding the largest newspapers and TV networks in Turkey, commanding a whopping 40% of the advertising market. In recent years acquired for scraps—$300 million—various media assets previously owned by nemesis and rival Uzan family, who fell off FORBES billionaires list in 2005. Also owns a large gasoline company, Petrol Ofisi. Charitable foundation supports literacy programs, but when it comes to speaking English, Dogan relies on help from his 4 daughters, 2 of whom have master’s degrees from Columbia Business School and are expected to take over the family business.

name: Billionaires
bio: Mastermind behind the superfashionable and functional Dyson vacuum. Grew up studying English and playing the bassoon. Then went to art school to study design and engineering. Ran through 5,127 prototypes until he perfected G-Force in an upright vacuum that uses spinning technology to maintain constant suction. Introduced his vacuum in U.K. in 1993 and was immediate hit. This year Dyson's DC12 became Japan's top-selling vacuum, besting competitors Sharp and Sanyo. Announced plans to open the Dyson School of Design & Innovation in 2008 to offer 14-to-18 year-olds programs in engineering, design and enterprise.

name: Billionaires
bio: Father, Curly, operated small lumber mill; Red joined family business 1940s. Took Sierra Pacific public 1969; private again 5 years later. Borrowed $460 million to buy 522,000 acres in 1988. Today company is one of the largest forest landowners in the U.S. with 1.7 million acres. Constantly battling preservationists; shrinking supply of timber resources pushing values higher. Also forcing prices up: institutional investors, which place timber bets to hedge against inflation. Recently bought 147,000-acre Hamilton Tree Farm in Washington State out of bankruptcy. Also building fourteenth sawmill in Burlington, Washington. Two sons active in the business.

name: Billionaires
bio: Competition is sapping demand for Funai's low-cost DVD players and televisions. His company Funai Electric's sales fell 6% last fiscal year to $3 billion, with net profit slipping 20%. To reverse the drop in revenue Funai, which sells through discounters including Wal-Mart, is shifting production to digital cameras and flat-panel LCD television as falling prices for those products open up new markets for discount makers.

name: Billionaires
bio: Youngest child of Joyce Hall (d. 1982), preacher’s son who started selling greeting cards at Kansas City YMCA at age 18. Took reins 1966 with expansions into crayons (Crayola), TV (Hallmark Channel), real estate (Crown Center Shopping Complex). Now world’s largest greeting-card firm.

name: Billionaires
bio: Qualifies for the billionaire ranks as a son of slain Lebanese prime minister Rafik , who left behind a $16.7 billion estate last year. Now based in Riyadh, helps watch over family holding company Saudi Oger for older brother Saad Hariri, Lebanese parliamentary majority leader. Also has hands in U.S. government contracting: cofounded and chairs identity management software firm Epok, based outside Washington, D.C., which aims to sell to federal and state customers.

name: Billionaires
bio: Youngest brother of Saad Hariri, the Lebanese parliamentary majority leader; older brothers Bahaa and Ayman and mother Nazek are all also billionaires. Family looking to sell 15-year-old Beirut's Future Television Network, a terrestrial and satellite TV network of which he is a board member. Less interested in politics than brothers Bahaa and Saad, he runs a fledgling design studio for furnishings and other wares in Paris, where sister Hind and mother also live.

name: Billionaires
bio: The Viscount Rothermere, as he is known, assumed leadership of the Daily Mail & General Trust (DMGT) newspaper conglomerate from his late father when he was just 30 years old. Now 39, he's proven adept at guiding DMGT in a shrinking U.K. newspaper market. Under his leadership the group has been diversifying its holdings and been making significant moves online. He and Claudia, his Oxford-educated wife, recently built a Palladian home, Ferne Park is a large estate in the Dorset countryside

name: Billionaires
bio: Like fellow Mexican billionaire Roberto Hernández Ramirez, Harp hit payday in 2001, when Citigroup bought Banamex bank. A baseball fanatic, owns the Red Devils, a minor-league team that will play in a new 12,000-seat stadium Harp that built at Mexico City’s National Autonomous University. Wealth runs in family: Harp’s cousin is Mexico’s richest man, Carlos Slim Helú.

name: Billionaires
bio: Continued economic boom in Brazil helped boost the fortune of this luxury apartment developer. Horn founded Cyrela Brazil Realty 1978; built it into largest developer of high-end residential buildings in Sao Paulo and Rio de Janeiro. Over past year Cyrela actively expanded its footprint by inking development deals with partners in various regions of Brazil. Horn also owns slice of agricultural investor BrasilAgro. A low-profile man known for giving 20% of his earnings to charity.

name: Billionaires
bio: Chemical maker still committed to his 2005 promise to give away entire fortune after he finds buyer for Huntsman Corp. Wharton grad making plastic egg cartons in 1960s before buying a styrene plant 1970. Turned Huntsman into nation’s largest private chemical company with huge acquisition spree. Rising oil prices put big squeeze on profits; forced to give up 49% of firm to settle debts with creditors. Turned company around. Took public 2004; personally netted $275 million. Used some of the proceeds to purchase more land in Idaho; now has 7,500 acres. Gave more than $100 million of remainder to charity. Committed philanthropist funds cancer research with Huntsman Cancer Institute and Hospital.

name: Billionaires
bio: Child of Samuel Curtis Johnson (d. 2004), great-grandson of salesman who founded floor wax company 1886. Sam joined 1954, expanded to cleaning supplies (Pledge, Windex), insect repellents (Off, Raid). Passed company to fifth generation in 2000. Today S.C. Johnson employs 12,000 people worldwide, sells products in 100 countries. Estimated sales: $6.5 billion. Children sent to Sam’s alma mater, Cornell, before joining family business. All still active. Fisk CEO of S.C. Johnson. Curt runs industrial cleaning products spinoff JohnsonDiversey, Helen camping-and-water-sports manufacturer Johnson Outdoors and banking-centric Johnson Financial, Winnie family foundation. Family known for social responsibility, environmentalism; big backers of Smithsonian, Mayo Clinic. Several members took diving trip to Indonesia looking for wrecked plane their grandfather used while scouring globe for wax ingredients.

name: Billionaires
bio: Widow of Samuel Curtis Johnson (d. 2004), great-grandson of salesman who founded floor wax company 1886. Sam joined 1954, expanded to cleaning supplies (Pledge, Windex), insect repellents (Off, Raid). Passed company to fifth generation in 2000. Today S.C. Johnson employs 12,000 people worldwide, sells products in 100 countries. Estimated sales: $6.5 billion. Children sent to Sam’s alma mater, Cornell, before joining family business. All still active. Fisk CEO of S.C. Johnson. Curt runs industrial cleaning products spinoff JohnsonDiversey, Helen camping-and-water-sports manufacturer Johnson Outdoors and banking-centric Johnson Financial, Winnie family foundation. Family known for social responsibility, environmentalism; big backers of Smithsonian, Mayo Clinic. Several members took diving trip to Indonesia looking for wrecked plane their grandfather used while scouring globe for wax ingredients.

name: Billionaires
bio: Child of Samuel Curtis Johnson (d. 2004), great-grandson of salesman who founded floor wax company 1886. Sam joined 1954, expanded to cleaning supplies (Pledge, Windex), insect repellents (Off, Raid). Passed company to fifth generation in 2000. Today S.C. Johnson employs 12,000 people worldwide, sells products in 100 countries. Estimated sales: $6.5 billion. Children sent to Sam’s alma mater, Cornell, before joining family business. All still active. Fisk CEO of S.C. Johnson. Curt runs industrial cleaning products spinoff JohnsonDiversey, Helen camping-and-water-sports manufacturer Johnson Outdoors and banking-centric Johnson Financial, Winnie family foundation. Family known for social responsibility, environmentalism; big backers of Smithsonian, Mayo Clinic. Several members took diving trip to Indonesia looking for wrecked plane their grandfather used while scouring globe for wax ingredients.

Johnson employs 12,000 people worldwide, sells products in 100 countries. Estimated sales: $6.5 billion. Children sent to Sam’s alma mater, Cornell, before joining family business. All still active. Fisk CEO of S.C. Johnson.
