Curt runs industrial cleaning products spinoff JohnsonDiversey, Helen camping-and-water-sports manufacturer Johnson Outdoors and banking-centric Johnson Financial, Winnie family foundation. Family known for social responsibility, environmentalism; big backers of Smithsonian, Mayo Clinic. Several members took diving trip to Indonesia looking for wrecked plane their grandfather used while scouring globe for wax ingredients.

name: Billionaires
bio: Child of Samuel Curtis Johnson (d. 2004), great-grandson of salesman who founded floor wax company 1886. Sam joined 1954, expanded to cleaning supplies (Pledge, Windex), insect repellents (Off, Raid). Passed company to fifth generation in 2000. Today S.C. Johnson employs 12,000 people worldwide, sells products in 100 countries. Estimated sales: $6.5 billion. Children sent to Sam’s alma mater, Cornell, before joining family business. All still active. Fisk CEO of S.C. Johnson. Curt runs industrial cleaning products spinoff JohnsonDiversey, Helen camping-and-water-sports manufacturer Johnson Outdoors and banking-centric Johnson Financial, Winnie family foundation. Family known for social responsibility, environmentalism; big backers of Smithsonian, Mayo Clinic. Several members took diving trip to Indonesia looking for wrecked plane their grandfather used while scouring globe for wax ingredients.

name: Billionaires
bio: Daughter of Al Lerner (d. 2002), who brought professional football back to Cleveland after making billions in credit cards through MBNA. Heirs now out of that business; sold company to Bank of America in 2005 for $35 billion in cash and stock. Family netted $300 million cash; today their shares of BofA worth $2.8 billion. Known for Cleveland-area medical philanthropy.

name: Billionaires
bio: Widow of Al Lerner (d. 2002), who brought professional football back to Cleveland after making billions in credit cards through MBNA. Heirs now out of that business; sold company to Bank of America in 2005 for $35 billion in cash and stock. Family netted $300 million cash; today their shares of BofA worth $2.8 billion. Known for Cleveland-area medical philanthropy.

name: Billionaires
bio: Son of Al Lerner (d. 2002), who brought professional football back to Cleveland after making billions in credit cards through MBNA. Heirs now out of that business; sold company to Bank of America in 2005 for $35 billion in cash and stock. Family netted $300 million cash; today their shares of BofA worth $2.8 billion. Randy is active as Browns owner. Known for Cleveland-area medical philanthropy.

name: Billionaires
bio: Manhattan-born Wharton grad worked in father’s cosmetics and hair care products company. Made first fortune selling contact-lens-design company to Cooper Labs for $60 million in 1971. Acquired New Jersey cable licenses; sold Vision Cable for $220 million in 1982. Later built cell phone business Metro Mobile, sold to Bell Atlantic for $2.6 billion 1992. With family now holds 28% stake in natural gas distributor Southern Union worth $525 million. Also owns large piece of Verizon Communications.

name: Billionaires
bio:
Took over William Morrison Supermarkets, which is named for his father, in 1952; became chairman in 1956. Since then, built the chain into the 4th largest 
grocer in Britain with sales of $24 billion in 2005. In 2004, after a protracted six-way bidding war, emerged victorious in takeover bid for rival Safeway supermarkets, paying $5 billion in stock and cash. Consequent to the troubled integration, Morrisons’stock suffered a 30% loss in the six months following the buyout; is now recovering. Knighted in 2000 for service to food retailing industry.

name: Billionaires
bio: Family escaped Soviet Union after the revolution, settled in Iran. Immigrated to U.S. at age 15 with 4 suitcases and $800. Studied at USC, worked as exec at Motown Records before going into real estate 1973. Today Olen owns 6.25 million square feet of commercial space and 11,000 residential units in Los Angeles, Las Vegas and south Florida. Entire portfolio owned via Copenhagen-registered holding company Landmark, which he claims is owned by other entities. Last May bought 42-story skyscraper in Chicago for $362 million. Mulling international expansion: acquaintance of former Russian president Boris Yeltsin owns land in Moscow. Has been fighting IRS over claim he owes $77 million in back taxes and penalties. Son and heir apparent, Andrei, died in car crash in 2005; daughter, Natalia, taking more active role in operation.

name: Billionaires
bio: Nephew of A.N. Pritzker (d. 1986), who with sons Jay (d. 1999) and Robert created industrial conglomerate Marmon (2005 sales: $7 billion) and hotel giant Hyatt (215 hotels worldwide). In 2001 plans collapsed to pass control of empire to Jay’s son Thomas, cousin Nicholas and niece Penny; family agreed to split pot 11 ways. Deal enraged Robert’s youngest kids, Liesel and Matthew; duo filed suit, settled for $500 million each. Dynastic carve-up to include Hyatt public offering or sale by 2011. Tentative so far. Just one windfall: tobacco outfit Conwood sold for $3.5 billion to R.J. Reynolds April. Nicholas: head of development, Hyatt Hotels.

name: Billionaires
bio: Founded Interstate Partners 1968. Today chief executive, large shareholder in Vornado Realty Trust, nation’s second-largest real estate investment trust. Took control of Vornado 1980; boosted $100 million market cap to $18 billion with shrewd buyouts of Manhattan skyscrapers, purchase of Kennedy family&#39s Merchandise Mart in Chicago. Now bullish on big New York developments. With Related Companies’ Stephen Ross (see), overseeing $7 billion reconstruction of Madison Square Garden and Penn Station. Recently lost out to Stephen Schwarzman&#39s (see) Blackstone Group in bid for Sam Zell&#39s (see) Equity Office Properties; Blackstone paid $39 billion cash.

name: Billionaires
bio: Owns 40% of $6 billion (sales) Helm A.G., which has interests in trading, chemicals and pharmaceuticals. Became chairman of executive board in 1984 when father, Hermann, the company’s founder, retired. Dad still owns other 60%.

name: Billionaires
bio: Billions for beauty. Luiz Seabra founded Natura Cosméticos, Brazilian version of Avon, 1969. Today its more than half a million “consultants” peddle creams and makeup across Brazil and four other Latin American countries. Stock has nearly quadrupled in value since going public on Brazilian stock exchange May 2004. Seabra cochairs the company with fellow billionaire Guilherme Peirao Leal (see).

name: Billionaires
bio: Stock car maven attended first auto race at age 8; promoted events on dirt track in Midland, N.C. as teen. Opened Charlotte Motor Speedway 1960; bankrupt 2 years later. Founded Speedway Motorsports. Public 1995. Now controls 6 tracks; commands highest average number of seats per track in the industry. Increasingly threatened by competitors William and James France (see both), owners of Nascar and International Speedway Corp. Despite rumor, says no plans to race in Mexico: “I thought Taco Bell was a phone company.” Donates money to child-related causes via Speedway Children’s Charities.

name: Billionaires
bio: Harvard graduate and cofounder of Royal Caribbean Cruises, which remains the tent pole of the family business. Cruise line came under congressional spotlight after the mysterious disappearance of a Greenwich, Conn. honeymooner in 2005. Wilhelmsen family has been busy expanding its maritime empire through oil driller Awilco Offshore. Chairs family investment company, with stakes in oil tankers, Russian hotels and shopping centers in the Baltic States. Son Alexander took his spot on Royal Caribbean’s board in 2003.

name: Billionaires
bio: The younger brother of Yan Cheung (he spells his name differently in English) who founded paper manufacturing company Nine Dragons in 1995. Executive director and deputy chief executive of Nine Dragons, he is responsible for much of the day-to-day operations, including marketing, distribution, finance, procurement and IT departments.

name: Billionaires
bio: Owns hefty stake in Al Rajhi Bank, Saudi&#39s Islamic banking behemoth. His 3 brothers (see) also own significant shares. Although Saudi&#39s stock market isn&#39t nearly as strong as it was last year- Al Rajhi&#39s shares were down more than 60% from last year&#39s peak in April— Mohammed is still comfortably wealthy thanks to his side investments in agriculture and gypsum production. His steel company is in the midst of building a massive plant in Jeddah.

name: Billionaires
bio: New Jersey-raised money man studied at NYU. Then Wall Street. Started in options group at Lawrence Kotkin Associates, graduated to corporate bonds. Went to Western State Law (now Thomas Jefferson Law) at night, started managing own money via Alexander Group 1980. Invested in for-profit student-loan provider First Marblehead 1991. Today owns 20% of the company. Bought pro basketball’s Houston Rockets in 1993. Animal rights advocate.

name: Billionaires
bio: Sultan of sound repaired radios in high school to keep his family afloat after WWII depressed his father’s import business. Fulbright scholar earned Ph.D. in electrical engineering from MIT, stayed on faculty. Began research program in hi-fi sound reproduction; founded Bose Corp. 1964. First contracts with NASA, U.S. military, improving audio communications. Built brand on groundbreaking loudspeaker design. Introduced first factory-installed car stereo system 1982; today major supplier for high-end automobiles (Porsche, Mercedes). New iPod speaker systems pumping up revenues. Plans to give fortune to educational causes.

name: Billionaires
bio: Father, Sam (d. 1993), came to Vegas 1941 with $80; got start spinning roulette wheels. Saved $6,000, borrowed another $10,000, bought Sahara hotel 1952; eventually became Mint hotel general manager. Father and son cofounded Boyd Gaming 1974. Took public 19 years later; today company owns casinos in Mississippi, Louisiana, Illinois, Indiana, New Jersey. Jump-started 2004 gaming industry consolidation craze with $1.3 billion acquisition of Coast Casinos. Agreed to buy Dania Jai Alai slots outfit in Fort Lauderdale for $152.5 million last May. Bigger vision for Sin City: destroying Stardust casino to make way for Echelon Place, a $4 billion hotel-casino-condo complex on Las Vegas Strip. Also owns Atlantic City’s Borgata casino with MGM Mirage.

name: Billionaires
bio: Armed with a degree in radio electronics, in the 1990s was the first in Moscow to open stores with bar code readers. Diversified company later traded food and electronics, imported bananas, managed banks and an airline; group eventually collapsed. Now focuses on the gambling business and is opening slots parlors and casinos in Russia, the Baltics, Ukraine, Kazakhstan, Romania, Macedonia, the U.S. and Latin America. Injured in a mysterious accident in Monte Carlo 10 years ago, appears frequently at Moscow parties in a wheelchair. Heads the Russian Committee for the Development of the Paralympics Movement.

name: Billionaires
bio: Former scientist fronted family friend Fred DeLuca (see) $1,000 to open sandwich shop to help pay for college 1965. Shop floundered; DeLuca opened second outlet to create aura of success. Created healthy buzz with infamous Jared commercials claiming formerly obese airline worker lost 245 pounds eating only Subway sandwiches. Today there are 27,235 Subway shops in 85 countries. Last summer a group of Subway operators sued DeLuca over control of ad dollars; suit alleges he uses marketing budget to drive up total sales at expense of franchisee profits.

name: Billionaires
bio: Majority owner of electric power plants and copper, aluminum and soda ash mines in Turkey. Also smaller interests in gasoline and aviation services. Building a new media center in desirable Taksim neighborhood of Istanbul. His media company Merkez has a licensing agreement with FORBES to publish FORBES TURKEY. Also owns apple farms on the outskirts of Istanbul. Personally pays for school construction throughout Turkey.

name: Billionaires
bio: Family friend Peter Buck (see) fronted family friend DeLuca $1,000 to open sandwich shop to help pay for college 1965. Shop floundered; DeLuca opened second outlet to create aura of success. Created healthy buzz with infamous Jared commercials claiming formerly obese airline worker lost 245 pounds eating only Subway sandwiches. Today there are 27,235 Subway shops in 85 countries. Last summer a group of Subway operators sued DeLuca over control of ad dollars; suit alleges he uses marketing budget to drive up total sales at expense of franchisee profits.

name: Billionaires
bio: Born in a small town near Moscow, studied economics in Moscow State University, where he got a doctorate. Headed several investment firms before joining Alfa Group in 1995. Worked in the firm’s food-and-commodities-trading subsidiary, Alfa Eco, then led the group’s takeover of an aluminum plant in Siberia. Later became a lobbyist and member of the Federation Council, the upper house of parliament. Since then his relations with other Alfa shareholders have become strained. However, maintains a large stake in Altimo, a company that inherited Alfa Eco’s assets and now has major holdings in Russia’s telecom industry.

name: Billionaires
bio: Parents Donald and Doris developed real estate, then founded music-and-jeans store the Gap in San Francisco 1969. Public 1976; expanded with Banana Republic (1983), Old Navy (1994), Forth & Towne (2005). Now 3,100 stores worldwide. Parents handed control of company—and nearly half of their stock—to second generation 2004. Brother Robert (see) serves as chairman; William (see) ran company’s international stores until 1998; John co-owner of pro baseball’s Oakland A’s.

name: Billionaires
bio: Arts-and-crafts aficionado opened first store in Oklahoma City selling handmade wooden picture frames with $600 loan 1970. Today Hobby Lobby operates 390 stores; recent expansion into Arizona, Utah. Devout Christian spreads The Word with full-page newspaper ads. Unconcerned about backlash: “The greater concern of ours is to say what we believe.”

name: Billionaires
bio: With three friends, founded Fosun Group and turned it into one of China's largest nongovernment-owned conglomerates, with interests in steel, property, retailing and real estate. Guo owns the biggest stake. Profits have climbed at Forte, its Shanghai-listed group's real estate arm.

name: Billionaires
bio: Owns privately held kretekmaker Djarum. Started in 1951 in Kudus, Central Java as small hand-rolling operation and continues to operate there to this day. First to sell light or flavored version, which comes in cherry and vanilla. The kretekmaker is the leader in foreign markets, with a dominant 70% market share in the U.S.; their menthol cigarettes have also gained popularity among Malaysian youth who view it as trendy. Also has Bank Central Asia stake.

name: Billionaires
bio: Transformed Far Eastern Group, founded by father as a textile manufacturer in 1945, into one of Taiwan's largest conglomerates, with interests in textiles, building materials, retailing, transportation and financial services. Has $39 billion in assets and 40,000 employees. Remains chief executive. Charged with forgery and breach of trust last fall but denies any wrongdoing.

name: Billionaires
bio: Son of Macedonian immigrants played shortstop for pro baseball’s Detroit Tigers farm team. Bought the franchise in 1992; team on verge of reaching playoffs for first time since 1987. Opened first Little Caesars pizza joint in 1959 after injury ended career; 40 stores by 1967. Modeled franchise on Ray Kroc’s McDonald’s: cheap ingredients, fast service, drive-up windows. Business lagged 1990s; ditched frozen cheese, refurbished stores. Sales: $1.4 billion. Also owns pro hockey’s Detroit Red Wings.

name: Billionaires
bio: Son of farmers founded Commonwealth Brands tobacco company 1990; manufactured discounted cigarettes USA Gold, Bull Durham, Malibu. Undersold top names with low advertising costs. Sold for $1 billion 2001. Now a rancher; owns 1.5 million acres in Texas, Florida, New Mexico. Also has small stakes in Kentucky Downs and Churchill Downs racetracks; the latter is home to the Kentucky Derby. Investing in energy sciences through Radix Energy Technologies (photovoltaic and organic polymers). Wildlife conservationist also runs program to help zoos breed rare species.

name: Billionaires
bio: Took control of Kohl’s department-store chain in management buyout with partners 1986. Expanded family-operated 40-store chain into 740-branch empire. Took public 1992. Kellogg started as store manager, climbed to chief executive. Retired 2001. Sales now exceed $13 billion. Also owns stake in used-car chain CarMax.

name: Billionaires
bio: Grew up in the Ural-region town of Verkhnaya Pyshma and went to a mining-and-metallurgy high school in Sverdlovsk and then to a metallurgy institute. In 1979 went to work as a mechanic at Uralelectromed, now the main factory at the Ural Mining-and-Metallurgy Co. Served as general director for 7 years starting in 1995. Now Iskander Makhmoudov's (see) closest partner, helping him build up holdings in Urals mining and metallurgy companies.

name: Billionaires
bio: Accordion-playing fire-breather founded Cirque du Soleil in 1984 with a gang of street performing friends. Initially funded by the Canadian government, the Montreal-based circus, which has no animals, no speaking and no star performers, became a for-profit group in 1985. Eventually bought out majority partner in 2000; today owns 95% of company. Hit jackpot when Steve Wynn brought Cirque to Las Vegas in 1991. Today group has five permanent shows in Sin City, including Beatles-themed "Love," which opened in June 2006; replaced Siegfried & Roy at the Mirage. Throws lavish parties, dreams of one day traveling into space.

name: Billionaires
bio: Leal helped fellow Brazilian billionaire Luiz Seabra (see) build Natura Cosméticos into the biggest Avon-like cosmetics company in Brazil. He cochairs Natura and has promoted a product line that uses renewable ingredients from Brazilian rain forest. He is also an active board member of nonprofit groups, including the World Wildlife Fund in Brazil.

name: Billionaires
bio: Father, Mike Sr., arrived in America 1914; made ricotta and mozzarella cheese for local customers 1950s. Jim joined company at 18, developed Leprino Foods into world’s largest producer of mozzarella. Estimated sales: $1.7 billion. Nine U.S. manufacturing plants process 1 million to 6 million pounds of milk each day, 5% of nation’s milk supply. Biggest customers: Domino’s, Papa John’s, Pizza Hut. Company also sells to Nestlé for Hot Pockets, Stouffer’s microwave pizzas. Big GOP contributor not limited to pies: excess whey sold as protein concentrate and lactose for baby formula, nutritional supplements, animal feed. Now catering to health-conscious parents; provides Lite Mozzarella for school lunches.

name: Billionaires
bio: Former lawyer founded real estate developer Lerner Enterprises in 1952. Built massive Washington, D.C.-area malls Tysons Corner Center, Tysons II and White Flint. Today owns 20 million square feet of commercial, retail space and 6,000 apartments. Has sold 22,000 private homes; currently building new subdivisions in Washington suburbs. Also owns stake in NYC's Chelsea Piers. Last spring with 14 other investors bought pro baseball's Washington Nationals for $450 million; Lerner's son and 2 sons-in-law will run franchise. City broke ground on a $610 million stadium last May.

name: Billionaires
bio: With his family, made early fortune in animal feed. Then in 1995 two brothers went their own way including Liu Yongxing, who got part of the family's feed business. His East Hope Group is looking to expand its core feed business throughout Asia but in the past few years has successfully focused on the aluminum industry

name: Billionaires
bio: Flamboyant liquor tycoon, who is also a member of parliament, took over the United Breweries group from late father in 1983. Built it into world's third-largest spirits company. Best known for such brands as Kingfisher, also the name of his loss-making 2-year-old domestic airline. Is eyeing Scottish distiller Whyte & Mackay as takeover target. Toys include yachts, vintage cars and a stud farm.

name: Billionaires
bio: With former rival Tom L. Ward (see), founded natural gas outfit Chesapeake Energy 1989. Today company one of largest gas drillers in U.S. McClendon: graduated from Duke 1981. Part of investor group that bought pro basketball’s Seattle SuperSonics from Starbucks honcho Howard Schultz (see) last July. Republican backed Swift Boat veterans campaign against John Kerry 2004.

name: Billionaires
bio: Cogen Technologies founder sold nation’s then-largest privately held power company to Enron for $1.5 billion in 1999; took cash and stock. Dumped shares before energy giant’s spectacular fall. Hometown hero: brought pro football to Houston with Texans expansion team in 2002. Horse aficionado controls Stonerside Stables, home of Kentucky Derby, Belmont participant “Bob and John.” Goal: win both Super Bowl and Kentucky Derby. Sprucing up downtown Houston with gardens, pedestrian-friendly streets.

name: Billionaires
bio: Brash leader of money management outfit MFP Investors: more than $1.6 billion under management, at least half believed to be his. Today bets include Sears, Conseco, Tyco, AIG. Started at Heine Securities 1975; sole owner by 1988. Sold company in 1996 to Franklin Resources for $670 million and 5-year employment contract. Donated $18 million to University of Oklahoma to create the Price College of Business 1997.

name: Billionaires
bio: Father, Joseph, ran pharmacy in Brooklyn. Stewart took over after dropping out of law school, turned into pharmaceutical distributor Kinray. Highly automated fulfillment, fat operating margins. Estimated sales: $3.9 billion. Name-dropping stargazer bought East Hampton, N.Y. estate for $45 million a few years ago; uses spread to entertain celebrity friends with lavish summer barbecues.

name: Billionaires
bio: Former chemical engineer has been hailed as the staid chemical industry's answer to steel magnate Lakshmi Mittal (see) because of his dealmaking. Ineos, the chemical company he founded and now chairs, paid $8.7 billion for BP Group's Innovene business in 2005, creating Britain's largest and the world's third-largest chemical company. Last year funded the Everest expedition that allowed the youngest climber ever, then age 20, to reach the world's 7 highest peaks.

name: Billionaires
bio: Studied at Dartmouth, then law degree from Southern Methodist U 1978. Practiced bankruptcy law in Dallas, left to invest in oil and gas operations 1984. Started Chief Oil & Gas 1994; sold company to Devon Energy and Crosstex Energy for $2.5 billion cash last June. Now heads Chief Operating; company has drilling program on 20,000 acres leased from Ross Perot’s (see) Hillwood Development.

name: Billionaires
bio: Father, Robert Sr. (d. 2006), founded Rich Products after WWII with invention of world’s first frozen soy whipped topping. Diversified into nondairy coffee creamer, frozen breads, cookies, cakes. Dad died last February. Once reluctant heir, Robert Jr., inherited 60% of privately held company. Became president of company 1978; now chairman. Latest acquisitions: World Catch (seafood), KX Logistics (Chinese food). Sports fanatic tried out for 1964 U.S. Olympic hockey team; owns Triple-A Buffalo Bisons. Recently penned 2 books on fishing. Found muse through fishing obsession: “I had writer’s block for 50 years.”

name: Billionaires
bio: After World War II he and brother, Paul, set about rebuilding family’s candy company. Brothers still run the now $2 billion (estimated sales) confectioner Haribo. Hans is often the one to concoct new products and is credited with inventing more than 200 confections including Goldbären, Vademecum sugar-free gum and Maoam fruit chewies. Apparently gets his inspiration from reading comic books and watching movies for children. A bachelor with no children, reportedly had falling-out with his heir apparent, nephew Hans-Jürgen Riegel, who has left the company.

name: Billionaires
bio: The founder of Sammy, Japan's largest pachinko and slot machine maker moved into the videogame business in 2003 with the acquisition of ailing Sega Corp. That takeover helped drive sales to a record $4.8 billion in the year ended March 2006. Satomi last year shifted direction again, this time paying $44 million for U.K. gaming software company Sports Interactive followed by the $15 million purchase of U.S. software writer Secret Level.

name: Billionaires
bio: Middle son of construction-scion Onsi Sawiris. Samih runs family’s Orascom empire hotel division, which owns and operates hotels in Egypt, Jordan, Mauritius, Oman and the United Arab Emirates. Recently got rare permission from the Swiss government to develop a luxury resort in the Alpine village of Andermatt. Has a degree in engineering from Technical University in Berlin; speaks fluent German.

name: Billionaires
bio: Former Oracle salesman finally gave in to former boss and longtime rival Larry Ellison. Last year sold software maker Siebel Systems to Oracle for $5.9 billion. Personally reaped about $500 million. Minimized tax bill with “double dummy.” Established Siebel Scholars Program 1999, provides grants to computer science graduate students. Foundation supports Salvation Army, alma mater U of Illinois. Funds controversial Montana Meth Project ad campaign; scary TV commercials depict shots of meth users at their worst.

name: Billionaires
bio: Brother Mel (see) left native Brooklyn for Midwest, ended up in Army. Sold encyclopedias, spent time as a leasing agent. Duo made fortune covering the country with shopping malls, including Minnesota’s Mall of America. Cochair Simon Property Group; REIT owns or operates nearly 200 million square feet of leasable space at 284 properties in North America. Grander ambitions: building condos, hotels in new mall developments. Also own pro basketball’s Indiana Pacers.

name: Billionaires
bio: Obtained a national commercial television license in 1993; created Polsat, now one of the nation&#39s biggest television stations. Sold 25% stake of Polsat TV to Germany&#39s Axel Springer for $325 million last year and plans to list shares by 2008. Continues to deadlock with government over strategic direction for energy company PAK in which he has a majority stake via his Elektrim. Also through Elektrim involved in a conflict between France’s Vivendi and Germany’s Deutsche Telekom concerning shares of PTC, one of the biggest mobile operators in the region.

name: Billionaires
bio: Founded Kazakhstan’s largest bank, Kazkommertsbank, in 1990. Remains its chairman. Bank went public in London last November attracting investors interested in the bank’s exposure to Kazakhstan’s lucrative oil and gas sector. Attended Moscow State University with new Kazakh billionaire Timur Kulibaev (see), with whom he maintains important political ties. Owns a 3-bedroom apartment in New York City’s Time Warner Center.

name: Billionaires
bio: Affable hedge fund manager earned master’s from Carnegie Mellon 1982. Ran junk bond desk at Goldman Sachs, moved to hedge funds. Founded Appaloosa Management 1993; 30% average annual returns, including 150% in 2003. Returned 21% net of fees in 2005; large gains in energy (Arch Coal, Consolidated Energy), big cap, tech stocks.

name: Billionaires
bio: Owns Viessmann Werke GmbH, $1.6 billion (sales) maker of boilers and heating equipment. Grandfather founded group nearly 90 years ago. Company set up Viessman Academy to provide training for heating architects and engineers; also sponsors cold weather sports like skiing and sledding as well as Formula One racing. Viessman is president of the Kassel Chamber of Commerce, treasurer of Marburg University. Holds professional pilot's license.

name: Billionaires
bio: As she embarks on her third decade ruling daytime television, Oprah is still finding other worlds to conquer: on Broadway (The Color Purple), on radio (her new network, Oprah & Friends, debuted last year on XM Radio). Born in rural Mississippi, became TV newscaster in Nashville, Baltimore. Joined Chicago TV station, turned third-rated morning show into nation’s No. 1 talk show. The Oprah Winfrey Show launched nationally 1986; currently airs in 127 countries, drawing 48 million viewers a week. Owns property in Chicago, Hawaii, Santa Barbara, Calif. Gives to needy women, children via Oprah’s Angel Network and the Oprah Winfrey Foundation. Opened $40 million Oprah Winfrey Leadership Academy for Girls in January.

name: Billionaires
bio: With brothers Dirk and Robert (see both). Father, William Ziff Jr. (d. 2006), built Ziff-Davis publishing empire (PC Magazine, Car & Driver, Boating). Sold for $1.4 billion in 1994, retired to Florida. Siblings reinvest proceeds via Ziff Brothers Investments: hedge funds, corporate debt, equities, small stake in DreamWorks SKG. Passive investors in Och-Ziff Capital Management Group hedge fund group.

name: Billionaires
bio: With brothers Daniel and Robert (see both). Father, William Ziff Jr. (d. 2006), built Ziff-Davis publishing empire (PC Magazine, Car & Driver, Boating). Sold for $1.4 billion in 1994, retired to Florida. Siblings reinvest proceeds via Ziff Brothers Investments: hedge funds, corporate debt, equities, small stake in DreamWorks SKG. Passive investors in Och-Ziff Capital Management Group hedge fund group.

name: Billionaires
bio: With brothers Daniel and Dirk (see both). Father, William Ziff Jr. (d. 2006), built Ziff-Davis publishing empire (PC Magazine, Car & Driver, Boating). Sold for $1.4 billion in 1994, retired to Florida. Siblings reinvest proceeds via Ziff Brothers Investments: hedge funds, corporate debt, equities, small stake in DreamWorks SKG. Passive investors in Och-Ziff Capital Management Group hedge fund group.

name: Billionaires
bio: Philanthropist shares Koc Group fortune with brother Rahmi Koc and sister Suna Kirac (see both). Holds board seat at conglomerate but does not manage any business unit. Due to parasite in her blood spent years fighting illness in hospitals around the world; the experience moved her to build nursing education and research center in Turkey and to marry a doctor. Fluent in English and German.

name: Billionaires
bio: Cofounded do-it-yourself home improvement chain Home Depot with partner Bernard Marcus (see) after getting fired from now defunct Handy Dan Improvement Center in 1978. Hardware giant went public 3 years later; youngest American retailer to surpass $70 billion sales milestone. Hung up tool belt 2000. Owner of pro football’s Atlanta Falcons and Georgia Force arena gridiron squad. Last year pledged $2 million to fight youth obesity.

name: Billionaires
bio: Stanford professor introduced students Sergey Brin and Larry Page to venture capitalists Kleiner Perkins Caufield & Byers. Rewarded with chunk of Google stock. Founded networking equipment company Granite Systems with Andreas von Bechtolsheim (see), and sold to Cisco Systems in 1996. Backed VMWare. Tenured professor also leads research on such projects as distributed interactive simulation. Donated $21 million in Google stock to alma mater, the University of Waterloo.

name: Billionaires
bio: Former Procter & Gamble product manager developed Quicken personal finance software to combat wife’s checkbook-balancing complaints. Cofounded Intuit with Tom Proulx 1983; public a decade later. Today products include TurboTax, Property Manager, QuickBooks, Medical Expense Manager. Increased competition from Microsoft, H&R Block. Active philanthropist funds business school program at wife’s alma mater, U of Wisconsin; Intuit Tax Freedom Project donates free tax prep to 11 million low-income people annually.

name: Billionaires
bio: Media titan started in fabled mailroom at William Morris Agency, went on to program the ABC broadcast network, help run Paramount Pictures, create the Fox broadcasting network and run Fox film; later built up USA Networks. Now an e-commerce mogul with IAC/InterActive Corp. In 2005 split InterActiveCorp into 2 companies: travel-based Expedia (Hotels.com, Expedia.com), other businesses under IAC (Match.com, Ticketmaster). Shrewd negotiator now building $100 million all-glass office complex to house his companies in New York’s Chelsea neighborhood. Board member of Friends of the Global Fight; group combats AIDS, TB, malaria.

name: Billionaires
bio: Grandfather started rag-cleaning business 1929. Richard joined 1957 after college; CEO 11 years later. Expanded into uniform rental, cleaning. Took Cintas public 1983. Still nation’s largest uniform-rental firm: more than 5 million people wear company’s gear. Branching out into first-aid products, cleaning supplies. Retired 2003; son Scott runs outfit. Recently lost legal battle with ex-employees over back pay in California; other labor lawsuits pending. Generous supporter of education, veterans’ causes, Republican Party.

name: Billionaires
bio: Parents Donald and Doris developed real estate, then founded music-and-jeans store the Gap in San Francisco 1969. Public 1976; expanded with Banana Republic (1983), Old Navy (1994), Forth & Towne (2005). Now 3,100 stores worldwide. Parents handed control of company—and nearly half of their stock—to second generation 2004. Robert serves as chairman; brother William (see) ran company’s international stores until 1998; brother John (see) co-owner of pro baseball’s Oakland A’s.
title: Director

name: Billionaires
bio: Parents Donald and Doris developed real estate, then founded music-and-jeans store the Gap in San Francisco 1969. Public 1976; expanded with Banana Republic (1983), Old Navy (1994), Forth & Towne (2005). Now 3,100 stores worldwide. Parents handed control of company—and nearly half of their stock—to second generation 2004. Brother Robert (see) serves as chairman; William ran company’s international stores until 1998; brother John (see) co-owner of pro baseball’s Oakland A’s.
title: Director

name: Billionaires
bio: Chicago-born “Toxic Bob” made first fortune after stumbling onto one of the world’s largest nickel deposits in Voisey’s Bay, Nfld. Now touting copper and gold deposits discovered in Mongolia by publicly traded Ivanhoe Mines. He got a boost in 2006 when mining giant Rio Tinto agreed to buy 10% of Ivanhoe for $300 million and said it might up its stake to as much as 40%.

name: Billionaires
bio: Sold drug giant Ivax to Teva Pharmaceuticals for $7.6 billion in 2005; Israeli company now world’s largest generic-drug maker. Today pharma tycoon investing in dangerous habits: took 6% stake in cigarette producer Vector last June by swapping $50 million in company bonds. Studied French literature at U. of Pennsylvania. Invented disposable biopsy device 1971. Took over Key Pharmaceuticals, created new delivery systems for old drugs. Sold to Schering-Plough in 1986. Founded Ivax a year later. Sees big opportunities in small operations: “It’s easier to grow a great deal when you start a small company.”

name: Billionaires
bio: Dropped out of high school, joined Marines. Started cable TV empire with $1,500 in 1956 running wire from antennas. Amassed network of small cable franchises; unloaded to Time Warner for $2.8 billion in 1996. Plowed proceeds into private investment outfit Granite Associates: hedge funds, real estate, Time Warner stock. Upstate New York native now works for environmental, educational and medical causes. Built massive outdoor concert venue on site of original Woodstock festival.

name: Billionaires
bio: Piquant-hot-sauce owner married daughter of Pace Salsa founder David Pace. Started out cutting vegetables in production line, found calling in sales department. Became president 1977; with wife, bought company from family. Bought her half for $95 million after she sued for divorce 1991. Sold whole enchilada 1996 to Campbell Soup for $1.1 billion. Now runs private equity firm Silver Ventures; stakes in Desert Glory (tomatoes), San Antonio Farms (salsa), Ecce Panis (baked goods).

name: Billionaires
bio: High-risk investor husband, John Murdoch Harbert III (d. 1995), turned $6,000 winnings from craps table into myriad construction ventures: airports, power plants, Mideast water supply systems, South American pipelines. Bought coal reserves in eastern Kentucky, Tennessee late 1960s; traded for stock in Amoco during energy crisis a decade later. Today son Raymond manages family fortune.

name: Billionaires
bio: Salty-tongued tort lawyer now fighting for free. Waived $40 million fee after winning $180 million settlement on behalf of Baylor College of Medicine against Zurich Insurance in 2005; gave cash back to Baylor for cancer research. Son of grocer passed up family business to set own hours. Majored in English and history in college; still reads Byron over shrimp-and-beer dinners. Started in Harris County, Tex. DA’s office. Formed own firm 1955, built reputation trying personal injury cases. Big score: 1987 Texaco-Pennzoil merger; earned estimated $345 million in fees. Donates millions of dollars to alma mater U of Texas; funded more than 2,000 scholarships. “We’re trying to eradicate ignorance. It’s a losing fight.”

name: Billionaires
bio: Gave up day-to-day control of Japan's third-largest consumer finance company Promise in 2001 to grow mangoes and bananas on Japan's chilly northern island of Hokkaido. The lender he founded has recently taken a battering, with regulators last year ordering the industry to repay borrowers it had overcharged. It later slashed its annual profit forecast by two-thirds to $133 million.

name: Billionaires
bio: Son of a Moscow department store director who was sentenced to 8 years in prison for embezzlement of state property and died soon after release. Graduated from the Moscow Aviation Institute and set up a computer-trading firm in late 1980s. Later became friendly with the governor of Novgorod, Mikhail Prusak, and through privatization bought local fertilizer producer Azot. Renamed it Akron and made it the basis for his chemicals empire. A passionate collector of paintings by Russian artists of Jewish origin, chairs Russian Jewish Congress. Spends most of his time at his mansion in Geneva.

name: Billionaires
bio: Senior statesman of Turkish industrialists ran Koc Group until 2003. Manages to find common ground with Greek, Israeli, Arab and American investors in his 65,000-employee conglomerate. Credited as driving force behind the expansion of Turkish economic interests in Eastern Europe. Avid sailor spends months calling on ports around the world aboard his luxury yacht. Worked with Alexander Onassis Foundation to restore wall paintings in historic Antalya, Turkey church. Sisters Semahat Arsel and Suna Kirac share in family fortune (see both).

name: Billionaires
bio: A businessman with a murky past. Born in a small town near Moscow and a graduate of the State Institute of Physical Culture (sports). The Russian tabloid Versia once linked Kvetnoi with the feared Solntsevo crime group, one of the biggest and richest of the last decade. No clear evidence was presented. In 1995 joined Alisher Usmanov’s metals group, for a time serving as chief executive of an Usmanov company. In April 2006 sold out when Usmanov created a metals conglomerate that included the company Kvetnoi had a stake in.

name: Billionaires
bio: Soft-spoken buyout titan had a tough fall in 2005: After taking Warner Music public with Edgar Bronfman Jr., flipped commodities outfit Refco. Refco quickly fell apart; then-chief executive Phillip Bennett charged with securities fraud, conspiracy. Company’s assets bought up by London hedge fund Man Group. Lee claims he personally lost only $2 million. Harvard grad started investing with $150,000 inheritance 1974. Greatest hit: Snapple, bought for $135 million 1992, sold to Quaker Oats for $1.7 billion in 1994. Today invested in Dunkin’ Donuts, Michael Foods. Left Thomas H. Lee Partners to start Thomas H. Lee Equity Partners last March; believed to have been forced out by partners, he says he wants a fresh start. Now leveraging connections with hedge fund managers with his Blue Star fund-of-funds outfit.

name: Billionaires
bio: Princeton grad joined father’s auto insurance firm 1955; targeted high-risk drivers. Took Progressive public 1971. Today country’s third-largest auto insurer, caters to all drivers; sets rates using device installed in cars to monitor driving habits. Art enthusiast houses more than 6,000 pieces of contemporary art in Progressive offices nationwide. Donated $100 million to Princeton arts program. Spent millions against Bush in 2004; now giving to Democratic youth groups.

name: Billionaires
bio: U of Chicago grad founded mutual fund monitor Morningstar with $80,000 in 1984. Turned quarterly publication into ratings giant. Famous for 5-star rankings; now trying to bring transparency to secretive hedge fund industry. Took public last May. Bought Fast Company and Inc. magazines from Gruner & Jahr for $35 million in 2005; price less than one-tenth of what G&J paid for Fast Company in 2000. Also holds 50% stake in culture guide Time Out Chicago.

name: Billionaires
bio: Made first fortune as a surgeon: invented spinal implants, reaped a few hundred million dollars. Today holds more than 185 patents. Last year settled nasty intellectual property lawsuit with medical device maker Medtronic for $1.3 billion. Bone of contention: implant that stabilizes, helps fuse vertebrae. Now crusading to make trademark system more efficient: “I think the patent office could operate in a smarter, faster more open way.” Last year donated $10 million to saving unloved pets in Los Angeles.

name: Billionaires
bio: Charismatic leader of Nidec, $4.6 billion (sales) maker of micromotors used in many DVD players; net income for latest year more than tripled to $355 million. In 2003 built tallest building in Kyoto for group's headquarters.

name: Billionaires
bio: Runs Oberoi Constructions, privately held real estate firm in Mumbai started in 1985 by his father from the profits of family's saffron-trading business. Since taking over in 1997 Oberoi has built on inheritance with several upmarket residential and commercial projects. Got noticed when, backed by a venture capital firm, he scooped up GlaxoSmithkline's corporate headquarters for $24 million in a hotly contested auction in 2003. Recently, Morgan Stanley's real estate arm invested $152 million for a reported 10% stake. Wife Gayatri is a former Bollywood actress.

name: Billionaires
bio: Wharton dropout had first score with 1985 acquisition, merger of Triangle Industries and National Can. Sold company in 1990 for $830 million profit. Also Snapple: bought from Quaker Oats for $300 million; sold 3 years later for $1.5 billion. Now runs publicly traded buyout firm Triarc; owns fast food chain Arby's, food fighting with Heinz.

name: Billionaires
bio: This Winnipeg, Man.-born geologist made it big by finding natural gas in remote and often arctic-like areas. In the 1970s founded Paramount Resources, which developed huge natural gas inventories. Riddell split up the company by spinning out income trusts from Paramount's assets over the last 6 years. That strategy was recently dealt a blow by Canada's federal government, which has decided to end the favorable tax treatment of such trusts.

name: Billionaires
bio: Dropped out of college to flip burgers. Saved money, invested in oil, real estate. Now owns 41 acres on Las Vegas Strip, home to New Frontier hotel and casino. Land alone worth at least $1 billion. Now plans to knock down dark-and-dirty New Frontier to build a $2.4 billion megaresort called Montreux; Swiss-lakefront-theme property will include a 104,000-square-foot casino and a 465-foot-high observation wheel similar to the London Eye. Side bet: partners with Donald Trump (see) on 64-story Trump International Hotel; construction under way in Vegas, partners to reap $250 million each when completed. Still petitioning Kansas legislature to allow slot machines at his two Wichita dog tracks.

name: Billionaires
bio: Chairman of Seven Network, the TV and publishing conglomerate that competes with James Packer&#39s (see) PBL. Like Packer, already taking advantage of pending changes in Australia&#39s media-ownership laws. Spun Seven’s TV, magazine and Internet businesses into a 50-50 Seven joint venture with private equity firm Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Co. (KKR) and raised $2.5 billion in cash. Through Seven also bought significant stake in West Australian Newspapers. Also owns WesTrac, one of the largest Caterpillar equipment dealers with operations in Australia and northern China.

name: Billionaires
bio: Created Internet outfit Broadcast.com with lifelong business partner Mark Cuban (see); sold to Yahoo at height of bubble in 1999 for $5.7 billion. Now building small entertainment empire: owns 2929 Entertainment, Magnolia Pictures, Landmark Theaters, high-definition TV network HDNet; also a stake in Lion’s Gate. Wants to release movies simultaneously on the big screen, DVD and TV to keep marketing costs down, boost profits. Owns small stake in pro basketball’s Dallas Mavericks; leaves fighting with refs to Cuban. Philanthropist expanding his Afterschool All-Stars program for inner-city children. Mantra: Everything in life needs “constant analysis and reevaluation.”

name: Billionaires
bio: Workaholic sign seller started with family business in early teens. Dropped out of U of Nebraska to attend U.S. Merchant Marine Academy. Back to signage: took over family’s Whiteco Industries 1946. Sold billboard division to Chancellor Media for $960 million 1998; still thriving with real estate. In June sold 100 hotels to media mogul Robert Johnson (see) for $1.7 billion. Now tarting up China: Shanghai’s Whiteco Qingyu boasts more than 550 billboards worth $95,000 each. With wife, Barbara, gives to Midwest hospitals, universities.

name: Billionaires
bio: Started out in the "bowl of Malaysia" as a rice trader. Later got government backing. Today controls Malaysia Mining Corporation (MMC); has stakes in Malaysia’s Johor Port; the country’s largest independent power producer Malakoff; and natural gas distribution company Gas Malaysia. Has invested in MPH (a book retailer in Singapore and Malaysia). He&#39s contributed to a number of Islamic schools, mosques and Islamic arts.

name: Billionaires
bio: Former vending machine repairman built Silicon Valley commercial real estate empire 1960s with partner John Sobrato (see). Later founded Mission West Properties, REIT specializing in R&D facilities. Today firm’s 8 million-square-feet of real estate home to Microsoft, Apple Computer, NEC, Fujitsu. Developing single-family homes on 200 acres in San Jose. Also owns large chunk of Stratus Properties, stakes in more than 100 tech companies, including Valence (rechargeable batteries) and INS (IT consultants).

name: Billionaires
bio: Raised in a small town in Tennessee, studied chemical engineering in college. Took job at Bristol-Myers Squibb, headed personnel department. Took over Stryker Corp. after Lee Stryker died in a plane crash 1976. Turned small medical-instruments company known for selling hospital beds and cast cutters into dominant manufacturer known primarily for artificial hips, knees. Remains chairman. Philanthropy focused on education: “It took me from the back hills of a farm in western Tennessee to modern America.”

name: Billionaires
bio: Founded a flavorings and fragrance business a decade ago. Took a major chunk of it public through a backdoor listing in August 2006. Still chairman of the company, now called Huabao International Holdings, she's been making waves lately for selling shares. Holds several leadership positions in local industry groups.

name: Billionaires
bio: Sixth son of late Hyundai founder, his fortune comes from his stake in Hyundai Heavy Industries, the world&#39s biggest shipbuilder. Has always been more interested in politics and soccer than business. He is a national assemblyman and a member of the Fédération Internationale de Football Association (FIFA) executive committee; ran unsuccessfully for presidency in 2002. Older brother Chung Mong-Koo (see) is Hyundai’s chairman who was recently sentenced to 3 years in prison for embezzlement.

name: Billionaires
bio: High school dropout started his first magazine, International Musician, in 1974; built a stable of trade titles including at one time more than 40 adult entertainment publications with names like Asian Babes and Posh Housewives. Launched celebrity magazine OK! in Britain in 1993. Bought British newspaper group, Express, in 2000. Sold the porn magazines in 2004; now planning to list his adult television channels. Big gamble: has spent $83 million on a U.S. edition of O.K.!, launched in August 2005. For fun, plays drums with his band RD Crusaders; other band members include musicians from The Who and Led Zeppelin. Became chairman of Jewish children’s charity Norwood in November.

name: Billionaires
bio: Edwards has more at stake in the Canadian oil sands than possibly any other individual. His company, Canadian Natural Resources, has sketched out plans to spend $25 billion to turn the gucky mud found in northern Alberta into barrels of crude oil. This media-shy lawyer turned financier also owns big stakes in Ensign Energy, Canada's second-biggest oil services company, and Penn West, one of Canada's biggest energy trusts. Also owns Lake Louise, Canada's famous ski hill, and a chunk of the Calgary Flames hockey team.

name: Billionaires
bio: Picked up investing bug from father, Philip (d. 2004). Dad ran own investment firm, built reputation with buy-and-hold philosophy, early tech investments. Ken worked at father’s shop after college, struck out on own 1973. Father of the price/sales ratio, author (Super Stocks), long-running FORBES columnist lords it over Fisher Investments. Assets under management: $34 billion. History buff currently studying interaction between finance and behavioral psychology. Also owns $70 million in California real estate.

name: Billionaires
bio: Descendant of the first premier of the state of West Australia, Lord Forrest of Bunbury. Nicknamed Twiggy, Forrest founded Anaconda Nickel (now called Minara) in 1994, then 9 years later moved on to Fortescue Metals, of which he owns about half. Fortescue is attempting to develop a huge iron mine in Western Australia.

name: Billionaires
bio: President of Benesse, Japan's largest home schooling company with $2.9 billion sales. Claims that as many as 4 million Japanese children are signed up for its correspondence courses. Soichiro is also a collector of modern art, and the Benesse museum in southwestern Japan boasts works by famous artists including Jackson Pollock and Frank Stella.

name: Billionaires
bio: Erstwhile hippie opened first store in 1970 near U. of Pennsylvania with $4,000; sold trendy clothes to cash-strapped college kids. Expanded. Eschews advertising: lures customers with ever changing displays, vivid color schemes, inviting floor plan. Today Urban Outfitters operates under 3 brand lines (including Free People, Anthropologie). Employees travel around the world to spot new trends, buy merchandise.
title: Chairman, President & Chief Executive Officer
employment: {'name': 'Urban Outfitters Inc.', 'title': 'Chairman, President & Chief Executive Officer', 'totalEarningEst': False, 'salaryEst': False, 'salary': 1.0, 'government': False}

name: Billionaires
bio: Son of hotel magnate Conrad Hilton; initially resisted family business after father offered him management job paying paltry $160 a month. Finally joined company after stint as WWII Navy photographer. Rose from elevator operator to president 1966; chairman 1979. Sold stake in pro football’s San Diego Chargers; invested in casinos. Avid airman flies gliders at 750,000-acre Nevada ranch. Granddaughters creating rival fortunes; both Nicky and Paris command 5-figure fees to party at Vegas nightclubs.

name: Billionaires
bio: The former commercial director of Kuznetsk Coal became president of the Swiss firm Conares Holding in 1995, overseeing export sales and financing. The public learned about him for the first time in October 2004, when Mechel, the largest producer of special steel and alloys, listed on the NYSE and Iorikh was named general director; turned out to have the same stake as better-known partner Igor Zyuzin, also a billionaire. But between 2005 and 2006 the two became divided over the direction of the company, and by January 2007 Iorikh had sold his shares to Zyuzin. Latest move: registering a $900 million fund called Pala Investments Holdings on the tax haven island of Jersey to take stakes in the mining sector.

name: Billionaires
bio: Purchased pro football’s Dallas Cowboys and stadium 17 years ago with $140 million in oil money. “America’s team” now worth $970 million net of debt. Building new $1 billion stadium, most expensive sports venue in U.S. history; Cowboys Stadium scheduled to open for 2009 NFL season. Captain of 1964 Cotton Bowl-winning U. of Arkansas Razorbacks football team. Joined father’s insurance business after earning M.B.A. Struck gas in first 13 wells drilled in early 1970s. Also invested in poultry, cattle.

name: Billionaires
bio: The strength of the British pound sterling helped boost his portfolio of real estate in and around London. But this former art dealer&#39s primary passion—and source of wealth—is likely the largest private collection of Islamic art, including more than 20,000 objects spanning 1,400 years. Wants to open a London museum for it in 2009. A dual U.S.-British citizen, Khalili was appointed to the Chancellor&#39s Court of Benefactors at the University of Oxford, where he endowed the Khalili Research Centre for Art & Material Culture of the Middle East. Gave money in 2006 for the printing of 1,000 copies in Arabic of the self-authored Timeline History of Islamic Art & Architecture for Palestinian schoolchildren.

name: Billionaires
bio: Inherited shares of Koch Industries from father, Fred Koch (d. 1967). With brother Fred, sold stake to other brothers Charles and David (see both) for $1.3 billion 1983. Long feud: Bill and Fred claimed they were shortchanged. Settled in 2001. Reinvested proceeds in Oxbow holding company: petroleum coke, coal, natural gas. Sales: $1.5 billion. Avid sailor organizing fight against proposed wind farm in Nantucket Sound. Also recently filed lawsuit claiming wine expert conned him into buying bottles purportedly owned by Thomas Jefferson for $500,000 in 1987.

name: Billionaires
bio: Son of a dressmaker in Boston’s Chinatown district; observant Jewish father wanted Bob to be a rabbi. Went to Harvard Business School instead. Married Myra Hiatt, whose father ran packaging company Rand-Whitney. Joined, eventually bought company in 1972. Same year started International Forest Products: owns mills, manufactures and distributes paper and packaging products in 80 countries. Bought pro football’s New England Patriots in 1994, paying then-record $172 million. Franchise now worth $1.2 billion. Won Super Bowl in 2002, 2004, 2005.

name: Billionaires
bio: Youngest son of Hong Kong tycoon Li Ka-shing borrowed $125 million  from his father in 1991 to launch satellite outfit StarTV. Later sold to Rupert Murdoch for $950 million; used proceeds to start Pacific Century Group and buy Hong Kong&#39s largest fixed-line operator, now called PCCW. Tried to sell out of PCCW, source of half his wealth, last year. Saga of botched exit includes mainland politicos; his father, who apparently tried to engineer deal to buy him out; and at least 2 private equity outfits quite willing to take PCCW off his hands, if Beijing would let them. Redeemed something of his reputation as a dealmaker by selling a stake in Pacific Century Insurance for a nice premium and selling office space in Tokyo’s Marunouchi Building, of which he owns 55%. The windfall may be invested in his latest enterprise, a Chinese-language financial news venture.

name: Billionaires
bio: Son of Bob Magness (d. 1996), founder of cable television giant TCI. Inherited hundreds of millions of dollars in stock, thanks to $54 billion TCI-AT&T merger 1999. Forced to pry fortune from stepmother, Sharon, and former TCI honcho John Malone (see); settled differences years ago. Selling off what is now Liberty Media stock; invests in oil, gas, Colorado real estate.

name: Billionaires
bio: Former owner of pro football’s Minnesota Vikings sold team to Arizona businessman Reggie Fowler in February 2005; reinvesting proceeds in oil, real estate, car dealerships. Red dropped out of law school to sell cars; owned first dealership by age 25. Cofounded radio station empire Clear Channel Communications with Lowry Mays in 1972. Company sale to private equity firms Thomas H. Lee Partners and Bain Capital for $18.7 billion in jeopardy; radio giant’s largest shareholder, Fidelity Management & Research, plans to vote against takeover bid later this month. Owns real estate throughout Texas; developing apartments, industrial parks in Houston, Austin, San Antonio.

name: Billionaires
bio: Earned M.B.A. from Michigan State. Joined family grocery-distribution business 1959, worked night shift loading trucks. Sold to tennis partner Sam Walton for cash and Wal-Mart stock in 1990. Owns pro baseball’s Houston Astros; on spending spree. Lured pitcher Roger Clemens out of retirement with a $22 million contract last June; signed outfielder Carlos Lee to 6-year $100 million deal in November. Sits on board of Boy Scouts of America.

name: Billionaires
bio: Born in Kerala, in southern India, Menon migrated to Oman in 1976, and started an interior decorating business with a partner. Seeing an opportunity in real estate back home, he started Sobha Developers in 1995, named after his wife, in Bangalore. Went on to build several campuses for Infosys Technologies, cofounded by billionaire N.R. Narayana Murthy (see). Has 28 projects under way, including a mall with an Olympic-size skating rink. December listing on the Bombay Stock Exchange of Sobha, in which he holds 87%, made him a billionaire. His wife sits on the board. Son Ravi, an engineer from Purdue University, is vice chairman.

name: Billionaires
bio: Cofounded software firm Infosys, which he runs as chief executive and managing director. In bid to diversify company's 69,000-plus workforce is hiring graduates from U.S. universities. Awarded the Padma Bhushan, one of nation's highest civilian honors. Also sits on Reuters' board.

name: Billionaires
bio: Head of Turkey's Dogus Holding conglomerate relinquished some control of prized Garanti Bank, the country's third-largest, when he sold a quarter of it to General Electric for $1.6 billion in August 2005. Now he is looking for new investments with the cash in his vault. Dick Grasso lookalike also lords it over media properties capturing more than 10% of country's advertising market. Schooled at Boston College and Harvard's Presidential Management Program. Bankrolled movie Gallipoli about seminal Turkish military battle against the Allied offensive. Harvard Business School case study documents challenges in taking over his father's traditionally managed company.

name: Billionaires
bio: Wharton grad took over trucking firm started 1938 by father, Al, with one truck. Early adopter of satellite tracking technology, transportation logistics. Became one of nation’s largest haulers by buying up competitors. Today Schneider National has 15,500 drivers, 48,000 trailers covering more than 5 million miles every day. Now offering shippers capacity on four trains on a 700-mile route throughout Midwest. Also expanding into China. Director emeritus of pro football’s Green Bay Packers.

name: Billionaires
bio: Civil engineer joined father’s former employer Kiewit Construction Group (now Peter Kiewit Sons’). Took reins when President Bob Wilson stepped down 1979; moved company into telecom, fiber optics, power plants. Retired as Kiewit chairman, still chairs Level 3 Communications. Friend of Warren Buffett, sits on board of Berkshire Hathaway. Owns 25% of Omaha Royals minor league baseball team. At Scott’s 70th birthday party, Buffett donned Elvis suit, played ukulele. Deeply involved with Henry Doorly Zoo in Omaha: “It’s pretty difficult for people not to like animals, particularly babies.”

name: Billionaires
bio: Founded auto parts and repair outfit Auto-Teile-Unger in 1985. Sold 80% of company to a British investor group in 2002 for $800 million. Sold rest to Kohlberg Kravis Roberts in July 2004 for some $360 million. Retired, lives in Weide, Bavaria.

name: Billionaires
bio: Grandfather John T. Dorrance, inventor of condensed-soup process, bought out his uncle's Campbell Preserve Company in 1914. Passed company on to son, 3 daughters. Third generation still owns about half the company.

name: Billionaires
bio: His former Dutch TV production company, Endemol, launched reality-show craze with the creation of programs like Big Brother and Fear Factor. Made fortune when he later sold Endemol to Spanish telecom giant Telefónica in 2000 for $5.3 billion. After that turned his attention to theater, a passion he’s had since childhood. (At age 6 Van den Ende put on a puppet shows for neighborhood kids in his hometown.) Currently chairman at Stage Entertainment, a musical theater company and Endemol spinoff that is behind blockbuster musicals like The Lion King and Mamma Mia. Its U.S. division has won 46 Tony Awards. In 2006 Van den Ende invested in Dutch interactive TV company Fruitlounge Media. Humble beginnings; started career as party-supply salesman.

name: Billionaires
bio: Grandfather John T. Dorrance, inventor of condensed-soup process, bought out his uncle’s Campbell Preserve Company in 1914. Passed company on to son, 3 daughters. Third generation still owns about half the company. Interests include horses, art.

name: Billionaires
bio: Harvard M.B.A. held posts at Hasbro, Keds, Disney, Procter & Gamble before landing chief auctioneer spot at Ebay in 1998. Led company through Internet bubble and bust; spectacular rebound catering to loyal trading communities. Expanded past auctions: today company owns comparison-pricing site Shopping.com, Web-phone outfit Skype, stake in online classifieds business Craigslist. Recently announced purchase of online ticket seller StubHub. Also expanding overseas. “Meg” donated $30 million to alma mater Princeton to build Whitman College; opens next year.

name: Billionaires
bio: Property developer is benefiting from Chinese residents? demand for better homes. Merrill Lynch, Deutsche Bank and Temasek Holdings of Singapore recently paid $400 million for 8% of his company Hengda, which is based in China's Guangdong province.

name: Billionaires
bio: Father, Sidney, ran shoemaking business, invested in Florida real estate. Ed bought Miami TV station for $3.4 million in 1962, later dropped NBC affiliation, remade as a Fox station. Applied same formula to Boston outlet in 1993, though he still partners with NBC there. Recently purchased Boston TV station for $114 million. Son Andrew runs family’s real estate operation: 4.2 million square feet of commercial property, mostly in Broward County, Fla. Reaps large agriculture tax breaks for owning property designated as farmland.

name: Billionaires
bio: Michigan State grad left Wall Street in 1969 for a fresher perspective on markets; moved to Denver, founded mutual fund giant Janus. Enjoyed exceptional returns during bull markets of 1980s, 1990s; became fourth-largest mutual fund company in the country. Losses mounted in 2000; resigned chief exec post 2002. Stepped down as chairman 2 years later amid industry’s market-timing scandal; Janus fund managers accused of giving preferential treatment to short-term investors. Company settled with regulators for $100 million. Now tends horses at his Iron Rose Ranch in Carbondale, Colo.

name: Billionaires
bio: With partner Ihor Kolomoyskyy (see) controls secretive Privat group, a banking and industrial conglomerate. Began with Privatbank, which was founded with $1 million of capital in the early 1990s; today the bank is estimated to be worth $3 billion because of Ukraine’s banking boom. Avid tennis player sponsors invitation-only tournaments, including one held by the Cyprus branch of Privatbank and another in Croatia.

name: Billionaires
bio: Chicken champion last year celebrated his 60th year in the restaurant business. Opened Dwarf Grill sandwich shop with brother, Ben, 1946. Procured cheap chicken: used pieces discarded by Delta Airlines because they were too big to fit on meal tray. First customers were Ford factory, airport workers with round-the-clock shifts. Food-court zealot opened first Chick-fil-A fast-food store at Greenbriar Mall in Atlanta 1967. Sales up every year since; $2.2 billion in 2006. Child of Depression remains debt-shy: “Let the customers dictate how fast we can grow.” Devout Baptist keeps stores closed on Sundays; third generation vows to do same. Auto enthusiast owns a Batmobile used in film Batman Returns.

name: Billionaires
bio: Expat runs Hong Kong logistics firm started by his father in Tokyo 1949. Saw market in providing services for sellers who needed to move Asian products across the Pacific. “Chip” took over early 1980s, moved operation to Hong Kong. Privately held firm&#39s sales now thought to exceed $1.5 billion, with offices in 20 countries on 4 continents. Mainly focused on apparel and home products for clients like Nordstrom, Dillard’s, Saks, Neiman Marcus. Vintage-car afficionado shows collection annually at San Francisco&#39s “Classic Car” weekend.

name: Billionaires
bio: Cofounded back-office-software giant PeopleSoft; public 1992. Stepped down from day-to-day operations in 1999, continued as chairman until selling to Oracle’s Larry Ellison (see) for $11 billion in 2005. Cornell grad set up $10 million fund for ex-employees unable to find jobs. Early investor in background check firm HireRight. Now hoping to create new fortune with enterprise software startup Workday. Animal-loving philanthropist a trustee of Maddie’s Fund (named after his late miniature schnauzer) to help make America a “no-kill zone” for unwanted pets.
title: Chairman and co-CEO

name: Billionaires
bio: Unofficial czar of Turkey's medical and pharmaceutical sector got his last name from the honorary title given to his grandfather, Turkey's head pharmacist, 95 years ago. In 2006 his group of companies increased sales 13% to $2.6 billion. Overseeing expansion of ceramic tile manufacturing unit into Russia and Ireland. Along with wife, Oya, was a major benefactor of Istanbul's new Modern Art Gallery, a renovated 86,000-square-foot former customs warehouse on the Sea of Marmara. Oya serves as museum's director.

name: Billionaires
bio: Brooklyn-raised hedge fund titan dropped out of NYU’s M.B.A. program to work on Wall Street. Met first business partner, Ivan Boesky protégé John Mulheren, on floor of American Stock Exchange. Duo founded Jamie Securities; firm collapsed after Mulheren convicted for insider trading. Founded Millennium Partners hedge fund outfit 1990 with $35 million; returned 17% net of fees annually since. Today manages $8.4 billion. “Izzy” hates losses: fires traders who lose a predetermined amount of money. Stiff fees: charges 20% of profits, plus up to 4% of assets. Settled illegal-trading charges with SEC for $180 million in 2005; employees created 100 legal shell companies in a fraudulent scheme to market-time mutual funds. Personally paid $30 million. Lives in Manhattan’s famed 740 Park Avenue building.

name: Billionaires
bio: Pilot for father’s Pacific Southwest Airlines 1960s. Veered into cars: landed Toyota distributor 1968. Today Gulf States Toyota, which delivers vehicles and parts to dealers in Texas and 4 other Gulf states, the main engine behind supersecret Friedkin Cos. Estimated sales: more than $4 billion. Former Hollywood stunt pilot hunts big-game on his Tanzanian preserve. Friedkin Conservation Fund backs antipoaching, community-development efforts in Tanzania.

name: Billionaires
bio: Started small mortgage company in 1985 with $5,000 made delivering pizzas in college. Sold to Intuit for $532 million in 1999; bought it back 3 years later for $64 million. Early Internet embracer turned Quicken Loans into nation’s largest online mortgage company. Closed $18 billion in loans in 2006. Sports fanatic: purchased NBA’s Cleveland Cavaliers for $375 million; resigned star LeBron James to 3-year, $60 million contract. Plays pickup basketball, attempting to break Michigan’s steroid-free bench-press weightlifting record. Recently bought $32 million stake in Eprize.com, which runs online promotions for clients like Coca-Cola and Disney.

name: Billionaires
bio: Cofounder of software firm Infosys is company's president and chief operating officer. Also chairs Infosys Consulting, a subsidiary. Graduate of elite Indian Institute of Technology, Madras.

name: Billionaires
bio: Buyout specialist migrated with family from Israel 1968. Founded Gores Technology Group 1987 after selling computers out of his father’s basement. Prefers to buy divisions of technology firms, merge them. Conglomerate now has 11 companies, including Real Software, Proxicom, Wire One Communications.

name: Billionaires
bio: World’s biggest bond trader got start gambling. Duke grad arranged a Kentucky Derby pool in college; spent a summer as a slots worker at Harrah’s in Lake Tahoe. Then Vegas: turned $200 into $10,000 in 4 months playing blackjack. M.B.A. from UCLA, became securities analyst at Pacific Life. Discovered how to make money with bonds: trade, don’t buy and hold. Handed $10 million portfolio to manage 1973; earned $20 million bonuses 1980s. Bond division spun off to create Pimco. Public 1994. Sold to German insurance giant Allianz AG for $4.7 billion in 2000; personally made more than $400 million. Avid collector owns every stamp produced in the U.S. between 1847 and 1869, including rare “Z Grill” depicting Benjamin Franklin; only 2 known to exist.

name: Billionaires
bio: Cofounded publicly traded Harvey Norman electronics empire in Australia in 1982. Remains executive chairman. Group now benefiting from sales of high-tech items like plasma TVs. Expanding around the world; franchises shops in Ireland, Malaysia, New Zealand, Singapore and Slovenia. Next up: the U.K. Has a passion for horses: owns part of Magic Millions Thoroughbred auction house and personally owns some 900 horses.

name: Billionaires
bio: Elegant and well-dressed vice chair of Koc Group conglomerate graduated from Turkish prep school and college. Youngest sister of magnate Rahmi Koc, fluent in French and English, is former recipient of Woman of the Year contest sponsored by university women's group in Turkey. Honorary Fellow of London Business School also named a library for herself at a university founded by her family. Recently transferred some of her shares in Koc to her daughter Ipek; now fighting ALS.

name: Billionaires
bio: With partner Henadiy Boholyubov (see) controls the secretive Privat group, a banking and industrial conglomerate. Began with Privatbank, which was founded with $1 million of capital in the early 1990s; today the bank is estimated to be worth $3 billion because of Ukraine’s banking boom. Recently accused rival Victor Pinchuk (see) of looting steel mill Nikopol, brought a lawsuit against him in the U.S.; case was settled and dismissed. Lost court case back home when Kiev court of appeals ruled his ownership claims to a Ukraine television company were unfounded.

name: Billionaires
bio: Phoenix native partnered with advertising genius William Levine, who founded Outdoor Systems 1980 with billboards, bus station ads. Vietnam vet Moreno joined 1984. Took public 1996, sold to Infinity Broadcast Corp. 1999 for $8.7 billion in stock. Became Viacom following 2000 merger; today Moreno owns 8.8 million shares of Viacom worth $350 million, 10 million of CBS worth $315 million. Also owns Arizona commercial real estate; stakes in pro baseball’s Los Angeles Angels of Anaheim, basketball’s Phoenix Suns.

name: Billionaires
bio: Began business career with his father as a textiles trader in Hong Kong. Expanded to Macau to obtain export quotas and branched off into property investments. Today runs property developer Kowloon Development in Hong Kong along with wife Ng Chi Man and son Or Pui Kwan. Sold personal Macau property holdings to Kowloon subsidiary Polytec Asset Holdings. In 2006 Kowloon Development made property investments in mainland cities Shenyang and Foshan.

name: Billionaires
bio: Brewmaster of Turkey created one of the country's most popular brands, Efes Pilsen beer. He and fellow billionaire Yazici together control 38-year-old Anadolu Group conglomerate. Second-generation partnership with Yazici family continues as the group rapidly expands into Russia and former Soviet republics. Also a car guy: makes Isuzus in Turkish plants and imports to Turkey Lada and Kia cars made in Russia and Korea to then be distributed in Ukraine and Central Asia countries. Built hospital affiliated with Johns Hopkins Medical School; it opened in 2005. Ex-basketball player never misses Efes Pilsen basketball club's games. He has a 3,000-piece pen collection.

name: Billionaires
bio: Chile’s recent right-leaning failed presidential candidate made his fortune introducing his homeland to credit cards in the 1970s. Parlayed earnings into a 27% stake in airline LAN. Recent controversy: Chile’s securities regulator reportedly charged Pinera with using inside information to increase his LAN position in advance of positive earnings announcement. Pinera’s camp claims the charges were politically motivated and denies wrongdoing.

name: Billionaires
bio: Shrewd financier made fortune buying up distressed companies in tired industries like coal, steel and textiles; cleans up balance sheet, improves management, sells for profit. Lawyer’s son parked cars at racetrack in Monmouth, N.J. Summer job on Wall Street, joined Rothschild 1976. Started own private equity fund 1997; founded WL Ross & Co. 3 years later. Sold International Steel Group to Indian billionaire Lakshmi Mittal in 2004 for $4.5 billion; created world&#39s largest steel company. Personally netted $210 million following public offering of International Coal Group. Took heat last year after 12 coal miners suffocated after an explosion in Sago, W. Va.; WL Ross owns a portion of the mine, which had a history of safety violations. Money-management outfit Amvescap bought control of WL Ross for $375 million; Ross not ceding ownership in his $4.5 billion equity firms. Now investing in auto parts and reinsurance companies.

name: Billionaires
bio: Staunch conservative with tremendous political clout. Great-grandson of Richard Beatty Mellon is heir to T. Mellon & Sons banking fortune. Owns Pittsburgh’s Tribune-Review, slew of Pennsylvania radio stations. Aids in the dissemination of right-wing policy via think tank Heritage Foundation; also bankrolls Center for the Study of Popular Culture. Perhaps best known for unsuccessful “Arkansas Project” effort to dig up dirt on Bill Clinton.

name: Billionaires
bio: Graduate of Moscow State Institute of Steel & Alloys, which several of Russia’s tycoons attended. Worked as an economist in the Central Research Institute for Ferrous Metallurgy. In 1989 started a joint venture in scrap metal recycling with a $1.5 million loan from Sberbank. The firm then started buying up shares in pipe producer Vyksunsky Metallurgical Plant (VMP). By 1999 Sedykh and his partners were controlling shareholders of VMP. Later established the United Metallurgical Company, Russia&#39s second-largest-pipe producer and its largest maker of railway wheels.

name: Billionaires
bio: After bosses at San Jose State University turned down proposal for his adult education program, the humanities professor with Ph.D. from Cambridge, left to start for-profit University of Phoenix. Took public as Apollo Group 1994; today nation’s largest private university system. Son, Peter (see), serves as senior vice president. Company expected to restate earnings after an investigation revealed executives misdated certain stock option grants; late quarterly filing prompted Nasdaq to warn the company about delisting.

name: Billionaires
bio: After bosses at San Jose State University turned down proposal for dad John&#39s (see) education program, the humanities professor with Ph.D. from Cambridge, left to start for-profit University of Phoenix. Took public as Apollo Group 1994; today nation’s largest private university. Company expected to restate earnings after an investigation revealed executives misdated certain stock option grants; late quarterly filing prompted Nasdaq to warn the company about delisting. Other investments: CallWave (communications), Ecliptic Enterprises (images from space).

name: Billionaires
bio: Bartender’s son raised in Illinois projects. Paid way through Southern Illinois U. selling life insurance, working construction jobs. Founded Excel Communications 1988, multilevel marketer of long-distance service, telecommunications products. Sold to Teleglobe 1998 for $3.5 billion. Co-owner of WinStar Farm in Kentucky; state-of-the-art horse breeding and training grounds home to one-time Kentucky Derby, Belmont runner-up, Bluegrass Cat. Devout Christian attends weekly Bible study; sponsors 2 nationally competitive youth basketball teams.

name: Billionaires
bio: Call-center king got start selling necklaces to Saks Fifth Avenue. Then real estate. Founded TeleTech in 1982 after noticing a weakness in how companies handle customers over the phone; driven to provide better customer service, database management. Public 1996. Today 47,000 employees handle calls for scores of companies in 29 languages. Sales: $1.2 billion. Stock has surged 200% in past 12 months.

name: Billionaires
bio: Considered the brains behind Turkcell. His idea for a mobile phone company was eventually funded by billionaire Mehmet Karamehmet. Sat on Turkcell board from 1993 until May 2005. Still owns a big stake in the NYSE-listed telecom stock. Bought one of Turkey's largest hotels in Izmir, the Grand Efes, for $121 million in October 2005. Started Turkish search engine Hakia in 2006. Rents out his 120-foot yacht, Jasmin, docked at Antibes, France, for $70,000 per week in the low season.

name: Billionaires
bio: Outspoken head of 81-year-old Bajaj group; Its Bajaj Auto, country’s second-largest motorcycle manufacturer, is aiming to close gap with rival Hero Honda. After long, drawn-out spat with brother agreed to divide family assets. Has handed over charge to sons Rajiv and Sanjiv. Is considering demerging Bajaj Auto to create separate finance company to be run by younger son Sanjiv. Elected to parliament last June.

name: Billionaires
bio: Maryland native spent high school summers mowing lawns, pumping gas. Graduated Salisbury State, founded Aerotek with $3,500 at age 23; company provides engineers to aerospace industry. Now holds majority stake in job outsourcer Allegis Group. Nation’s third-largest staffing firm places construction, medical, call-center workers. “Shots” owns pro football’s Baltimore Ravens.

name: Billionaires
bio: Chairman and chief executive of Fuyao Glass Industry Group, which makes glass used in automobiles.
