Rumored to have been interested in buying an auto parts plant in the U.S. from financially strapped Ford.  Cao's Fuyao said in December that its earnings last year would increase by more than 50% because of strong exports to such customers as Audi, Ford, Fiat and Nissan.

name: Billionaires
bio: Savvy entrepreneur founded 3 billion-dollar companies: Netscape, Healtheon (now WebMD), Silicon Graphics. Silicon Valley became an “insanely depressing place”; cashed out shares in all 3 firms before they lost all their value. Reinvested in Neoteris (computer security), MyCFO.com (wealth management), real estate. Owns majority stake in Hyperion Development Group construction outfit; building 2 condo complexes in Miami. Also has 30% stake in photo-sharing site Shutterfly; company public last September.

name: Billionaires
bio: Founded NetEase as an Internet portal. Took it public on Nasdaq in 2000. Shifted most of its business to online gaming. Ding, who is chief executive, may have to shift again as shares have stalled amid stiff competition. He was China's richest man in 2003.

name: Billionaires
bio: Maritime lover got sea legs as a kid; rebuilt small boat and sailed around Lake Washington. Later crafted sailboats in his Seattle garage before founding Bayliner Marine Corp. 1955. Doubled revenue every 3 years; sold to Brunswick for $425 million 1986. Invested proceeds in stocks, bonds, real estate. Spends days flying helicopters, skiing, cruising in new 164-foot yacht, Evviva. Last year donated $5.4 million to Arizona State University for student entrepreneurs.

name: Billionaires
bio: An immigrant from Korea, Han runs Japan's largest chain of pachinko gambling parlors, Maruhan. Sales in the past decade have grown tenfold to $14 billion; net income reached $105 million. Company is celebrating its 50th anniversary in May 2007. Han's success has earned him plaudits in his native Korea, including a handful of honorary doctorates from universities.

name: Billionaires
bio: Geologist father and uncle ran modest oil-drilling firm until late 1970s. Headington studied, played tennis at U. of Oklahoma; took over operation following father’s death. Today Headington Oil produces 6.7 million barrels of oil and natural gas equivalent a year; employs 12 drilling rigs across Texas, Montana and North Dakota. Drilling expected to double over next year.

name: Billionaires
bio: Numbers junkie earned Harvard math and physics degrees in 3 years. Piloted B-17 bomber in WWII. First job: statistician at Occidental Life. Earned $225 a month, quit after realizing salesmen made more. Created property and casualty insurance company. Then Mercury General 1962. Targeted customers having trouble getting auto insurance, used snoop unit to flush out suspicious claims. Took public 1985. Believes ZIP codes key statistic to setting insurance rates; now fighting California officials, who say motorists’ driving records are more important. Said to relax in the evenings with a lapful of trade magazines and agent reports.

name: Billionaires
bio: An original investor in $2.6 billion (sales) Amdocs, a customer-relationship management-and-billing software firm for large telecom outfits. (One out of every 2 phone calls made in North America relies on Amdocs software.) Has cashed out nearly $1 billion worth of shares since Amdocs went public in 1998. Also a part owner of Aurec Group, an Israeli private-equity firm with cable and telecom investments. A former diver, Kahn lives on Beit Yanay beach, north of Tel Aviv, and spends a lot of time on his yacht. Founded Coral World International, a string of aquariums in Eilat, Israel; Maui, Hawaii; and Perth, Australia. Son, Benjamin, is a marine biologist.

name: Billionaires
bio: Money man emigrated from Moscow with his parents to U.S. 1976; became U.S. citizen. Returned to Russia mid-1990s to head Credit Suisse First Boston's Moscow operation. Became chief of Alfa Bank. Today invests via Pamplona Capital Management. Lives in London.

name: Billionaires
bio: Born in then Soviet Republic of Estonia and graduated from the Moscow Power Engineering Institute; served as commercial director at a small firm founded with the institute’s help. In 1992 was hired by Alfa Group to oversee establishment of a privatization-investment fund; months later became chief executive of Alfa Capital, the group’s fund-management company. After expanding Alfa Capital became responsible for all of the bank&#39s investment units. Also board chairman of Alfa’s Altimo telecom-holding company.

name: Billionaires
bio: Queens-born investment banker made small fortune taking Ross Perot’s Electronic Data Systems public in 1968. Made hundreds of millions providing seed money for Home Depot. Still in spotlight as defendant in New York attorney general&#39s lawsuit over pay package awarded to former NYSE chief Richard Grasso; his lawyers have asked for case to be dismissed. Staunchly defends his role as chair of Big Board’s compensation committee. More trouble: shareholder outrage over Home Depot ex-chief Robert Nardelli&#39s oversize pay package led to his ouster; Langone now to leave Home Depot board in 2008.

name: Billionaires
bio: With three brothers, made initial fortune in animal feed. Youngest of the siblings, split from the family in1995. Now focused on turning his New Hope Group into an agribusiness force, making everything from dairy products to feed. Also the largest shareholder in Minsheng Bank, China's biggest nongovernment-owned bank.

name: Billionaires
bio: The son of a farmer, Lu opened a bicycle repair shop in the 1960s. Built the small business into an auto parts empire. Today the Wanxiang Group is diversifying, with investments in banking, agriculture, real estate and infrastructure.

name: Billionaires
bio: Chairs $3 billion (revenues) Mahindra & Mahindra, country’s leading tractormaker, which recently celebrated its 60th year. Has joint venture with Nissan and Renault to make cars, to be launched this year, and one with British communications group BT, which listed last August. Nephew Anand runs show as vice chairman and managing director.

name: Billionaires
bio: Fashionista sister of Ferit Sahenk and heir to Dogus Holding fortune built by father, Ayhan. Has handled retail partnerships with luxury brands Tods and Armani. Advocate of women's leadership and one of Turkey's top 100 taxpayers. Also holds title of president at family's active charitable foundation, the sponsor of a well-known 3-day annual international mountain bike festival in Turkey's Cappadocia region. Active in the International Myeloma Foundation. Also has a huge antique collection.

name: Billionaires
bio: Owns half of German publishing house, Verlagsgruppe Holtzbrinck. Heads its S. Fischer Verlag unit, which dates back to 1886; were original publishers of Thomas Mann, Franz Kafka and Hermann Hesse. Brother Stefan von Holtzbrinck owns the rest. Other brother, Dieter, sold his share to siblings last summer.

name: Billionaires
bio: The King of Caffeine. Son of blue-collar parents raised in housing projects in Brooklyn. Studied, played football at Northern Michigan U. Moved back to New York, sold pots and pans for Swedish housewaresmaker. Landed marketing gig at small coffee-bean store called Starbucks. Traveled to Italy, became obsessed with opening espresso bar. Bosses said no. Started rival store 1985; made his java with Starbucks beans. Bought company 2 years later for $3.8 million. Tapped late 1980s health craze; created skim-milk-based drinks. Took public 1992. Today boasts 12,000 stores worldwide; opens 5 new shops a day. Serves 40 million customers weekly. Provides health benefits to employees working more than 20 hours a week. Recently penned letter to Starbucks board worrying stores have become "cookie cutter." Sold Seattle Supersonics to Oklahoma City mogul Clayton Bennett for $325 million last July. Cofounded venture fund Maveron; sits on DreamWorks board.
title: Chairman and CEO

name: Billionaires
bio: Onetime baker broke ground on properties in the 1960s. Today A.G. Spanos Cos. is one of the country’s largest apartment developers. Containing market downturn because not as nationally exposed as other builders. Owns pro football’s San Diego Chargers; sons manage team.

name: Billionaires
bio: His grandmother began making camellia-based hair oils and creams as a sideline. His father is Sun Sung-Whan, who took over the business in 1943 and ran it for more than 5 decades, transformed it into Amorepacific, one of South Korea's biggest cosmetic companies. Suh, who grew up next door to the company's headquarters, was the only one of 6 siblings to take an interest in the business. Joined Amorepacific in the 1980s after earning an M.B.A. from Cornell University in upstate New York. Became chief executive in 1997 and immediately began steering the business overseas. That same year launched Lolita Lempicka perfume, which now sells in 80 countries. Is also expanding in such markets as China, the U.S. and Japan.

name: Billionaires
bio: His timber flagship Rimbunan Hijau celebrated its 30th anniversary in 2006 by inaugurating 2 palm oil mills and 2 resorts in his native Sarawak. The group, which has concessions in New Zealand, central Africa, Papua New Guinea and Russia, has been the subject of intense scrutiny by environmental groups. It claims to be implementing sustainable-forest-management practices, which bring benefits to the local communities and economies. While his logging empire grows, Tiong is also busy creating a global Chinese media group. His Ming Pao Enterprises, which serves Chinese-language markets in Hong Kong. Malaysia and the U.S., listed its lifestyle magazine arm, One Media Group. Tiong also listed his Sarawak palm oil interests in Malaysia in 2006.

name: Billionaires
bio: Romania’s first billionaire. Outstanding athlete, he competed in the the 1960 Olympic Games as an ice hockey player. Later switched to tennis, eventually coaching several tennis greats including Boris Becker, Steffi Graf and Goran Ivanisevic. Used his connections and wealth to invest back home after the fall of communism. Amassed companies in banking, insurance, auto leasing and retail; later sold off stakes to Western companies and plowed proceeds into Romanian real estate. In January he and Olympian Nadia Comaneci led the celebrations to mark Romania’s entry into the European Union.

name: Billionaires
bio: With half-brother Dieter and half-sister Monika Schoeller, inherited publishing house, Verlagsgruppe Holtzbrinck, from their father George who founded it in 1948. Since 2001 has run the $2.7 billion (sales) company, which owns German newspaper Die Zeit and publishing houses, including Henry Holt and Macmillan. Last summer he and Monika bought out Dieter’s one-third share; each now own 50% of the group. A lawyer, Stefan apprenticed at Bloomsbury Publishing in London before joining Holtzbrinck in 1994.

name: Billionaires
bio: Chairman of the Golden Eagle Retail Group, an operator and developer of 8 high end retail stores in China. Also has other property interests. Received an undergraduate degree from Chinese Culture University in Taiwan in 1969 and an M.B.A. from Southeastern Louisiana University in 1973. Wang is a U.S. citizen.

name: Billionaires
bio: “Wyly Coyote” investigated for using illegal offshore tax shelters to buy art, luxury items; in January Bank of America fined $3 million by the NASD for failing to follow anti-money-laundering rules in its handling of accounts held by Wyly and brother Charles. Louisiana native’s parents ran a local newspaper. Sam cleaned presses, sold ads; then studied at Louisiana Tech. Worked at IBM, Honeywell. Founded supercomputer operator University Computing with $1,000 in 1963; $57 million (sales) by 1968. Added investments in insurance, oil, restaurants. Bought controlling interest in arts-and-crafts chain Michaels Stores 1982; shares bought out by Bain Capital and Stephen Schwarzmann’s (see) Blackstone Group for $6 billion. Sold Sterling Software to Computer Associates in 2000 for $4 billion. Also director, largest stockholder of clean-energy producer Green Mountain Energy.

name: Billionaires
bio: As a boy, worked at his father’s little grocery store in Istanbul and learned how to trade. Founder of Anadolu Group, brewer and distributor of beer and soft drinks, and holder of a 40% stake in all 7 of Coca-Cola&#39s Turkish bottling and distributing companies. Got to watch his Efes Pilsen basketball club win the European championship in 1996 and 2000. Has helped open thousands of summer sports camps throughout Turkey to generate interest in basketball. Longtime business partner of fellow billionaire Tuncay Ozilhan (see).

name: Billionaires
bio: In 1987 opened a minigrocery store in a school looking to catch business from picky kids and their parents. Zong's beverage maker Wahaha, (the company is named after a word in Chinese that sounds like an infant laughing) has thrived amid a boom in the country's drinks industry. It is now one of China's largest privately held businesses, with plants in 28 Chinese provinces.

name: Billionaires
bio: Founder and chairman of MBI International, a diversified group with investments in luxury real estate and food. His hotel portfolio includes some of the toniest addresses in Europe, such as Vienna's Grand Hotel Wien and the Berners Hotel in London's West End. His AJWA Industries is one of the largest processors of grain and vegetable oil in the Middle East. Active philanthropist founded the MBI Al Jaber Foundation which, among other things, grants scholarships to Middle Eastern students to study conflict resolution at the City University, London. Also serves as Unesco Special Envoy, actively promoting educational reform in the Arab world.

name: Billionaires
bio: Press-shy hedge fund operator grew up in Raleigh, N.C. Taunted by peers for wearing glasses. Bookworm studied literature at Middlebury College, took summer job on sportfishing boat where he met former New York Stock Exchange board member Walter Frank. Took Frank’s advice and enrolled in Columbia Business School. Launched Moore Capital hedge fund group 1989: predicted Gulf War’s effect on oil, returned a career-high 86%. Today macro-minded Moore Capital has 4 funds. Total assets under management: more than $10 billion. Flagship fund, Moore Global Investments, has returned 24% since 1990. Big-game aficionado hosts hunting parties on 435-acre Robin’s Island in the Great Peconic Bay. Once paid rock band The Pretenders to perform at his birthday party.

name: Billionaires
bio: Son of Lebanese immigrants studied at U of Southern California, then University of San Diego Law School. Started in real estate development, moved on to invest with Robert Bass (see). Founded Colony Capital 1991, bought up bad real estate loans from busted S&Ls. Now owns casinos in Atlantic City, Gulf Coast and Europe, plus luxury hotels and apartment buildings. Bought Raffles Hotel in Singapore last year; then teamed up with Prince Alwaleed bin Talal Alsaud (see) to buy Canada’s Fairmont hotels last year. Now duo scouring the Middle East and North Africa for future hotel and resort projects. Splits time between his Santa Barbara mansion and his $3,000-a-night Costa Smeralda resort in Sardinia. Avid surfer, polo player.

name: Billionaires
bio: Software titan held posts at Oracle, Apple before launching salesforce.com in 1999. Goal: take traditional customer databases online. "We plan to defeat Oracle, SAP and Microsoft in the business applications market." Sales: $500 million. Stock up 95% since last July. Active philanthropist gives 1% of company's equity, manpower and profits to various causes. Last year published tome The Business of Changing the World.

name: Billionaires
bio: Former Pizza Hut store manager served the masses online with AOL. Now pushes vacation homes for upper class via Exclusive Resorts. Invested $500 million last April in health and wellness concerns. AOL founder made biggest bet in tech boom, merging with staid Time Warner. Ensuing debacle prompted resignation as chairman 2003. Other investments include real estate, pineapple farming in his native Hawaii.

name: Billionaires
bio: Chen's main source of wealth is Zijin Mining, a Hong Kong-listed mining outfit that operates gold mines in China. Zijin is leading an investor group looking to take over Monterrico Metals, a British copper firm. The bid is part of a wave of international mergers and acquisitions by Chinese companies in the minerals industry.

name: Billionaires
bio: Made initial fortune as a supplier of toys to such companies as Hasbro and Mattel. Sales at his privately held toymaker Early Light Industrial exceeded $500 million in 2006. But big wealth comes from real estate: since Asia's financial crisis has accumulated scores of properties in Hong Kong. Holds stake in Regal Hotels International Holding in Hong Kong.

name: Billionaires
bio: Runs chipmaker Marvell Semiconductor with husband Sehat Sutardja (see). Chinese immigrants met at UC, Berkeley; Dai studied computer science, Sutardja studied electrical engineering (and has claimed to be the world’s best analog chip designer). Founded Marvell in 1995 with Sutardja’s brother Pantas; sold hyperfast chips for routers, hard drives, Wi-Fi equipment. Public offering 2000. Sales: $2 billion. Last June announced intentions to buy Intel’s cell phone chip business for $600 million; hoping to “Marvell-ize” it into profitability. Marvell one of more than 100 companies under investigation by the SEC and the Justice Department for backdating stock options.
title: Co-founder

name: Billionaires
bio: Roman Abramovich’s (see) much lower-profile right-hand man worked with him 10 years ago at Abramovich’s Runicom. Was also main oil trader at Abramovich’s Sibneft (sold in 2005 to Gazprom).

name: Billionaires
bio: Top dog at venture firm Kleiner Perkins Caufield & Byers has logged nearly 3 decades in Silicon Valley. Studied electrical engineering at Rice U, then Harvard M.B.A. Spent 1980s thinking computers might work better if they were linked together; persuaded partners to fund a few guys from Stanford. Result: Sun Microsystems. Bet the Internet would be even bigger than the PC during 1990s; scored with investments in Amazon, Netscape. Best bet: Google. Also some duds: AtHome, Handspring. Aided user-generated-content craze with Zazzle, PodShow. Firm now investing in solar cells, other “clean” tech. Fights poverty and AIDS in Africa with U2’s Bono. Net worth estimate probably low.

name: Billionaires
bio: Athletic-shoe pioneer shelved sneaker war with rival Nike by merging Reebok with Germany’s Adidas in 2005 for $3.8 billion; personally reaped $600 million. Bought U.S. distribution rights for small British shoe company 1979. Added women’s sneakers amid 1980s aerobics craze. Nike pulled ahead early 1990s; shareholders demanded Fireman step down 1996. Responded with 2-year deadline to increase sales or step down. Did just that; returned 1999, restored business. Also owns golf courses.

name: Billionaires
bio: Robert Galvin, who helped transform Motorola from a family business into a global telecommunications giant, died on October 11, 2011 at age 89. His father, Paul (d. 1959), founded Galvin Manufacturing Corp. in 1928, renaming it Motorola in 1947. The company made car radios and 5-pound Handie-Talkie 2-way crystal radio for WWII. Robert started in the stockroom in 1940 and worked his way  up to CEO in 1959. As CEO, Galvin helped the company shepherd in an era of global cellular technology. Under his helm, Motorola unveiled the first portable cell phone prototype in 1971. In 1988 Galvin stepped down as CEO; in 2001 he retired from the board. Galvin was an advisor to US presidents and cabinet leaders from the Eisenhower to the Bush administrations. During his retirement, he established two non-profit think tanks to tackle infrastructure problems. The Perfect Power Institute, aims to transform the electricity industry; Galvin Transportation Initiative, sought to eliminate urban auto congestion.

name: Billionaires
bio: Through his Win Corp. owns 24 regional TV stations as well as the property on which they sit. Changes in Australian media ownership rules expected this year could make Win a prime buyout target, but Gordon will entertain only bids of at least $780 million. Also owns public shares in PBL, Ten Network and Sunraysia Television. Worked at Paramount International Television for 35 years. Lives in Bermuda.

name: Billionaires
bio: Founded Near East University, a large university in north Cyprus, the part of the island Turkey recognizes as the Turkish Republic of Northern Cyprus. When he was a child making cars from mud, Gunsel dreamed of building an automobile factory. In a former dumping ground he built his university, as well as a gas station, hotel, bank and publishing business. He mortgaged his apartment, which he inherited from his father, to open the university in 1978. Most of his net worth comes from the value of the land on which his university sits.

name: Billionaires
bio: Former billionaire Michael Heisley passed away in late April 2014 at age 77. He founded Heico Companies, a Chicago holding company that specialized in buying underperforming or bankrupt companies to turn them around. He started in 1979 by buying Conco, a maker of sewer and drain equipment, with $150,000 in profit from selling his home and $10 million in bank loans. Heico expanded and bought several struggling Rust Belt manufacturers. He bought the Vancouver Grizzlies NBA basketball team and moved them to Memphis. He sold the team to a group led by technology billionaire Robert Pera in 2012. The Grizzlies made the playoffs in 2011.  Heisley was last on the Forbes Billionaires list in 2012. He fell off the list the following year.

name: Billionaires
bio: Former Exxon geologist founded Hilcorp Energy with partner Thomas Hook 1989; bought former Goldman Sachs banker out in 2003 for $500 million. Produced 2.9 million barrels of oil in 2005. Owns 9.2 million barrels of proven Gulf Coast reserves, 3.4 million in South Louisiana. Gives to Houston Zoo, Contemporary Arts Museum.

name: Billionaires
bio: Father, Louis, opened popcorn stand in 1915, grew into major sports concessions business. Jeremy took over company after father’s death, transformed Delaware North into global player in food and hospitality. Heightened airport security and waning popularity of amusement parks pushing business past hot dogs and cotton candy. Heavily invested in new $1.4 billion Wembley National Stadium; 90,000-seat sports-and-concert venue outside London to open late 2007. Horse lover.

name: Billionaires
bio: A former top manager at a state arms plant, Liang got into the construction-equipment industry because he was impressed with the success of companies in that field in the U.S. and Japan. Chairman of Sany Heavy Industry, he recently sparked an intense debate over the role of foreign investment in China's privatization when he complained publicly about an investment in Sany rival Xugong Group Construction Machinery by well-connected U.S. private equity firm Carlyle Group.

name: Billionaires
bio: Father got start making watering cans in summer and hot water bottles in winter. Eventually founded Loh KG 1961. Friedhelm, his second-born son, took over 13 years later. Company, now known as the Friedhelm Loh Group, makes switch boxes that protect electrical circuits, postboxes, intercom systems and steel sheeting; has $2.1 billion in sales, 10,000 employees. Known for his religious beliefs, has established the Christian Media Foundation, group of publishers of Christian literature. Avid collector of antique cars.

name: Billionaires
bio: Son of famed wildcatter W. A. (Monty) Moncrief Sr. Graduated Culver Military Academy 1937, studied petroleum engineering at University of Texas. Then stint in Navy in WWII. Went into business with father, became 50-50 partners. Dad: quit Marlin Oil 1927, dug dry holes for 4 years. Then first find: northernmost extension of east Texas field. Junior became operations man. Acquired one-third of giant natural gas field Madden Deep in Wyoming 1972; field grosses at least $2 million a day.

name: Billionaires
bio: With partner John Arrillaga, became 2 of Silicon Valley’s biggest commercial landlords converting farmland bought in the 1960s into pricey office space. Lifelong partners shun debt, the media.

name: Billionaires
bio:
Former credit analyst made fortune issuing junk bonds secured by metals companies he acquired; stopped interest payments, sent companies into bankruptcy, bought company assets back for pennies on the dollar. Bought military contractor AM General for $133 million in 1992; maker of U.S. Army’s all-terrain Humvee vehicles created luxury-SUV market with 2.5-ton Hummer. Sold majority stake to 
Ronald Perelman’s (see) MacAndrews & Forbes holding company for $930 million in 2004. Construction now finished on his palatial compound in the Hamptons: 100,000 square feet, 29 bedrooms, 2 bowling alleys, 39 bathrooms, parking for 200 cars; 68-acre beachfront estate almost fills entire page on Google Maps.

name: Billionaires
bio: Australia’s first female billionaire. Sole heir to once deeply troubled estate left by late father. Battled for 14 years to win control of his assets from her stepmother. Legal hurdles cleared in 2003 in time to catch boom in iron-ore demand. Her annual royalty from a unit of Anglo-Australian mining giant Rio Tinto has effectively doubled to about $47 million.
title: Executive Chairman

name: Billionaires
bio: Revered macro hedge fund manager returned cash to investors from his Tiger Fund 2002 after suffering 2 years of tech-related losses; personally netted $570 million. Today Tiger now manages money for 1 client: Robertson. North Carolina native took job as a sales trainee at Kidder, Peabody age 25. At 42 headed Kidder’s money management arm. Raised $8.8 billion to start Tiger Management fund (named after his moniker for people he likes). Became world’s biggest hedge fund. Mentor to the next generation of hedge fund gurus, including Ken Griffin and Louis Bacon (see both); many of his “Tiger Cubs” are graduates of University of Virginia. Now trying to make new fortune in wine. Started R.P. Imports in 2005 to bring 5 selections of his New Zealand TeAwa label to major U.S. markets. Obsessed with New Zealand: in addition to vineyards, built golf courses, private resorts there.

name: Billionaires
bio:
Once a single mother living on welfare in a coldwater flat in Edinburgh, Scotland, Rowling is now the only billionaire author on our list. The novelist has announced that the 7th (and last) installment of the Harry Potter series, "Harry Potter and 
the Deathly Hallows" will be published July 21. Worldwide sales of the Potter books have topped 325 million copies. The film seriesfrom which Rowling enjoys a cut of royalties and merchandisin has already grossed $3.5 billion, and there's no doubt three more movies to come.
title: Author

name: Billionaires
bio: Widow of Brazilian billionaire banker Edmond Safra, who died in a fire in his Monaco apartment 1999. Lily is a socialite and philanthropist who splits her time between London and New York, and has homes in Geneva and Monaco. Last year she got Empress Bianca, a novel, pulled from publication because she claimed it was a thinly veiled, defamatory portrayal of her. The author, Lady Colin Campbell, has since changed the parts of the novel that might be regarded by Safra as identifying biographical features and is considering an offer from a different British publisher.

name: Billionaires
bio: Computer science professor left Columbia to trade on Wall Street; joined Morgan Stanley’s quantitative trading unit 1986. Launched eponymous hedge fund 2 years later. Son of efficient-markets theorist made fortune exploiting market inefficiencies with sophisticated computer models. Strong investment in human capital: devotes an “unusually large” portion of its budget to recruitment; only 1 in 500 applicants accepted. No longer involved in day-to-day operations. Now pursuing biosciences passion: funding medical research using computational techniques to develop drugs. Hopes to advance medicine with a small group of geniuses and lots of powerful computers.

name: Billionaires
bio: Runs chipmaker Marvell Semiconductor with wife Weili Dai (see). Chinese immigrants met at UC, Berkeley; Dai studied computer science, Sutardja studied electrical engineering (and has claimed to be the world’s best analog chip designer). Founded Marvell in 1995 with Sutardja’s brother Pantas; sold hyperfast chips for routers, hard drives, Wi-Fi equipment. Public offering 2000. Sales: $2 billion. Last June announced intentions to buy Intel’s cell phone chip business for $600 million; hoping to “Marvell-ize” it into profitability.

name: Billionaires
bio: At the young age of 26 took over Enka construction chairman post from his father Sarik Tara (see). Entered the billionaires ranks for the first time this year after Enka's market cap grew to $6 billion. Known for his modest character, his office has bare white walls. Attended a German high school in Istanbul and business school at Stanford; fluent in German and English.

name: Billionaires
bio: Made fortune in rice crackers and other junk food sold throughout Taiwan and China. His company, Want Want, traces its roots back to Taiwan, where it was founded by his father in 1962 as I Lan Foods Industrial Co., an exporter of canned agricultural products. Company later signed an agreement with Japan's Iwatsuka Confectionary Co. to use its equipment, which allowed it to enter the rice cracker market in Taiwan. Formally entered the China market in 1992. Company's shares trade on Singapore's exchange. The family also operates a hotel in downtown Taipei. Normally low-key Tsai made headlines last year when he called in reporters to have a look at his newly purchased private plane.

name: Billionaires
bio: Son of Ulker Food Company's founder Sabri Ulker took chairman title from his father in 2000. The $6.6 billion (sales) group, which makes cookies, cakes and candy bars, is expanding abroad; owns factories in Uzbekistan, Ukraine and Saudi Arabia. Murat worked in the company's export department for 2 years. Enjoys sailing, hunting and travel.

name: Billionaires
bio: Ukraine’s youngest billionaire started out as finance director of bank Finance & Credit in 1992. Eventually gained a majority stake in its holding company, Finance & Credit Group. Revamping the group’s major asset, iron pellet producer Poltavsky GOK, in anticipation of a public offering.  Also a deputy in Ukraine’s parliament.
